	<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Mexico</h1>
	
	<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
		<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
		<div id="contentSub"></div>
		
		
		
		<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
		<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the federal republic in North America. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Mexico_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Mexico (disambiguation)">Mexico (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"United Mexican States" redirects here. For the historical states, see <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Republic" title="First Mexican Republic">First Mexican Republic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Federal_Republic_of_Mexico" title="Second Federal Republic of Mexico">Second Federal Republic of Mexico</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in the southern portion of North America</div>
<p>
<span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mexico&amp;params=23_N_102_W_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">23°N</span> <span class="longitude">102°W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">&#xfeff; / &#xfeff;</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">23°N 102°W</span><span style="display:none">&#xfeff; / <span class="geo">23; -102</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>
</p>

href="/wiki/Spanish_American_wars_of_independence#New_Spain_and_Central_America" title="Spanish American wars of independence">Recognized</a> </div></th><td>December 28, 1836</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/1824_Constitution_of_Mexico" title="1824 Constitution of Mexico">First constitution</a> </div></th><td>October 4, 1824</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Federal_Constitution_of_the_United_Mexican_States_of_1857" title="Federal Constitution of the United Mexican States of 1857">Second constitution</a> </div></th><td>February 5, 1857</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">Current constitution</a> </div></th><td>February 5, 1917</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Mexico" title="Geography of Mexico">Area </a></th></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;Total</div></th><td>1,972,550&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (761,610&#160;sq&#160;mi)&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">13th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;Water&#160;(%)</div></th><td>2.5</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:left;"><a style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;2019 estimate</div></th><td>126,577,691<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">10th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;Density</div></th><td>61/km<sup>2</sup> (158.0/sq&#160;mi)&#32;(<a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a>&#160;<span style="font-weight:normal;">(<a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>)</span></th><td>2018&#160;estimate</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;Total</div></th><td><span class="nowrap">$2.575 trillion<sup id="cite_ref-imf-mx_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf-mx-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup></span>&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">11th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;Per capita</div></th><td>$20,645<sup id="cite_ref-imf-mx_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf-mx-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">64th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a>&#160;<span style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;Total</div></th><td><span class="nowrap">$1.199 trillion<sup id="cite_ref-imf-mx_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf-mx-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup></span>&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">16th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;Per capita</div></th><td>$9,614<sup id="cite_ref-imf-mx_5-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf-mx-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">69th</a>)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini</a>&#160;<span style="font-weight:normal;">(2016)</span></th><td><img alt="Negative increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Increase_Negative.svg/11px-Increase_Negative.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Negative increase" width="11" height="11" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300" />&#160;0.774<sup id="cite_ref-UNDP2018_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNDP2018-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><br /><span style="white-space:nowrap;"><span style="color:forestgreen">high</span></span>&#160;·&#160;<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">74th</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Currency</th><td><a href="/wiki/Mexican_peso" title="Mexican peso">Peso</a> (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">MXN</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th scope="row">Time zone</th><td><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>−8 to −5</span> (<i>See</i> <a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>−7 to −5</span> (varies)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Mexico" title="Telephone numbers in Mexico">+52</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:MX" title="ISO 3166-2:MX">MX</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/.mx" title=".mx">.mx</a></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em;">
<li value="1"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_iboxa"><b><a href="#ref_iboxa">^</a></b></span> Article 4.° of the <a href="/wiki/General_Law_of_Linguistic_Rights_of_the_Indigenous_Peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="General Law of Linguistic Rights of the Indigenous Peoples">General Law of Linguistic Rights of the Indigenous Peoples</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup></li><li value="2"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_iboxb"><b><a href="#ref_iboxb">^</a></b></span> Spanish is <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> the official language in the Mexican federal government.</li>
</ol></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Mexico</b> (<a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i lang="es">México</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[ˈmexiko]</a></span>&#32;<span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Es-mx-M%C3%A9xico.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20" /></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Es-mx-M%C3%A9xico.ogg" class="internal" title="Es-mx-México.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>; <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Nahuatl languages">Nahuatl languages</a>: <i lang="nah">Mēxihco</i>), officially the <b>United Mexican States</b> (Spanish: <i lang="es">Estados Unidos Mexicanos</i><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-presidencia.gob.mx_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-presidencia.gob.mx-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cia.gov_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[esˈtaðos uˈniðos mexiˈkanos]</a></span>&#32;<span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Es-mx-Estados_Unidos_Mexicanos.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20" /></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b9/Es-mx-Estados_Unidos_Mexicanos.ogg" class="internal" title="Es-mx-Estados Unidos Mexicanos.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), is a country in the southern portion of <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>. It is <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_Mexico" title="Borders of Mexico">bordered</a> to the north by the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>; to the south and west by the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>; to the southeast by <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belize" title="Belize">Belize</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a>; and to the east by the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> Covering almost 2,000,000 square kilometers (770,000&#160;sq&#160;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-cia.gov_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> the nation is the fourth largest country in the Americas by total area and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by area">13th largest independent state</a> in the world. With an estimated population of over 129 million people,<sup id="cite_ref-countries_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-countries-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> Mexico is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population">tenth most populous country</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone#Hispanosphere" title="Hispanophone">most populous Spanish-speaking country</a> in the world, while being the second most populous nation in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-countries_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-countries-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> Mexico is a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a> comprising 31 <a href="/wiki/States_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="States of Mexico">states</a> plus <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City (CDMX)</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> which is the <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">capital city</a> and its <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Mexico" title="List of cities in Mexico">most populous city</a>. Other <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_of_Mexico" title="Metropolitan areas of Mexico">metropolises</a> in the country include <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monterrey" title="Monterrey">Monterrey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puebla_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Puebla City">Puebla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toluca" title="Toluca">Toluca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tijuana" title="Tijuana">Tijuana</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n,_Guanajuato" title="León, Guanajuato">León</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_Mexico" title="Pre-Columbian Mexico">Pre-Columbian Mexico</a> dates to about 8000 BC and is identified as one of six <a href="/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization" title="Cradle of civilization">cradles of civilization</a><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> and was home to many advanced <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">Mesoamerican</a> civilizations such as the <a href="/wiki/Olmec" class="mw-redirect" title="Olmec">Olmec</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toltec" title="Toltec">Toltec</a>, <a href="/wiki/Teotihuacan" title="Teotihuacan">Teotihuacan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_civilization" title="Zapotec civilization">Zapotec</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Maya</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Aztec" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec">Aztec</a> before <a href="/wiki/First_contact_(anthropology)" title="First contact (anthropology)">first contact</a> with <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europeans</a>. In 1521, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Aztec_Empire" title="Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire">conquered and colonized</a> the territory from its politically powerful base in <a href="/wiki/Mexico-Tenochtitlan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexico-Tenochtitlan">Mexico-Tenochtitlan</a> (part of Mexico City), which was administered as the <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">viceroyalty of New Spain</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholic Church</a> played a powerful role in governing the country as millions were converted to the faith, although <a href="/wiki/Charles_III_of_Spain" title="Charles III of Spain">King Charles III</a> expelled the <a href="/wiki/Jesuits" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesuits">Jesuits</a> in the 1770s.<sup id="cite_ref-hist_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hist-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> The territory became a <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> following its recognition in 1821 after the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">Mexican War of Independence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hist_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hist-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> The post-independence period was tumultuous, characterized by <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico#Independence" title="Economic history of Mexico">economic inequality</a> and many contrasting political changes. The <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War" title="Mexican–American War">Mexican–American War</a> (1846–1848) led to a <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_Mexico" title="Territorial evolution of Mexico">territorial loss</a> of part of the huge northern territories to the United States. The <a href="/wiki/Pastry_War" title="Pastry War">Pastry War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Franco-Mexican_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Franco-Mexican War">Franco-Mexican War</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Reform_War" title="Reform War">civil war</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Mexico" title="Emperor of Mexico">two empires</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Porfiriato" title="Porfiriato">Porfiriato</a> occurred in the 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-hist_19-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hist-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> The Porfiriato ended with the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a> in 1910, which culminated in the promulgation of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">1917 Constitution</a> and the emergence of an authoritarian <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party state</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> once described as the "perfect dictatorship",<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> that ruled for much of the 20th century until the opposition victories led Mexico to <a href="/wiki/Democratic_transition" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic transition">democratic transition</a> in the 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">15th largest nominal GDP</a><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">11th largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Mexico" title="Economy of Mexico">Mexican economy</a> is strongly linked to those of its 1994 <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">North American Free Trade Agreement</a> (NAFTA) partners, especially the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> In 1994, Mexico became the first Latin American member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD). It is classified as an <i>upper-middle income country</i> by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a><sup id="cite_ref-wb-upper-middle_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wb-upper-middle-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a> by several analysts.<sup id="cite_ref-Globalization_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Globalization-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Limits_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Limits-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AIA_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AIA-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Principles_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Principles-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> The country is considered both a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> and is often identified as an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Emerging Powers">emerging global power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> Due to its rich <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Mexico" title="Culture of Mexico">culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico" title="History of Mexico">history</a>, Mexico ranks <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Mexico" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Mexico">first in the Americas and seventh in the world</a> for number of <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> Mexico is an ecologically <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries"><i>megadiverse country</i></a>, ranking fifth in the world for its <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> Mexico receives a huge number of tourists every year: in 2018, it was the sixth most-visited country in the world, with 39 million international arrivals.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> Mexico is a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> (UN), the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO), the <a href="/wiki/G8%2B5" title="G8+5">G8+5</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Uniting_for_Consensus" title="Uniting for Consensus">Uniting for Consensus</a> group of the UN, and the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Alliance" title="Pacific Alliance">Pacific Alliance</a> <a href="/wiki/Trade_bloc" title="Trade bloc">trade bloc</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Mexico" title="Name of Mexico">Name of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CodexMendoza01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/CodexMendoza01.jpg/220px-CodexMendoza01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="260" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/CodexMendoza01.jpg/330px-CodexMendoza01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/CodexMendoza01.jpg/440px-CodexMendoza01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="622" data-file-height="735" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:CodexMendoza01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Depiction of the founding myth of <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">Mexico-Tenochtitlan</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Codex_Mendoza" title="Codex Mendoza">Codex Mendoza</a></div></div></div>
<p><i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text"><a href="/wiki/Name_of_Mexico" title="Name of Mexico">Mēxihco</a></i> is the <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a> term for the heartland of the <a href="/wiki/Aztec_Empire" title="Aztec Empire">Aztec Empire</a>, namely the <a href="/wiki/Valley_of_Mexico" title="Valley of Mexico">Valley of Mexico</a> and surrounding territories, with its people being known  as the <a href="/wiki/Mexica" title="Mexica">Mexica</a>.  The terms are plainly linked; it is generally believed that the <a href="/wiki/Toponym" class="mw-redirect" title="Toponym">toponym</a> for the valley was the origin of the primary <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Aztec_Triple_Alliance" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec Triple Alliance">Aztec Triple Alliance</a>, but it may have been the other way around.<sup id="cite_ref-Bright2004_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bright2004-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> In the colonial era, back when Mexico was called <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a>, this territory became the <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">Intendency of Mexico</a>. After New Spain achieved independence from the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a>, said territory came to be known as the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">State of Mexico</a>, with the new country being named after its capital: <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>, which itself was founded in 1524 on top of the ancient Mexica capital of <a href="/wiki/Mexico-Tenochtitlan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexico-Tenochtitlan">Mexico-Tenochtitlan</a>.
</p><p>Traditionally, the name <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">Tenochtitlan</i> was believed to come from <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a> <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">tetl</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Nahuatl" title="Help:IPA/Nahuatl">[ˈtetɬ]</a></span> ("rock") and <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">nōchtli</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Nahuatl" title="Help:IPA/Nahuatl">[ˈnoːtʃtɬi]</a></span> ("<a href="/wiki/Opuntia" title="Opuntia">prickly pear</a>") and is often thought to mean "Among the prickly pears [growing among] rocks". However, one attestation in the late 16th-century manuscript known as "the Bancroft dialogues" suggests the second vowel was short, so that the true etymology remains uncertain.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The suffix <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">-co</i> is the Nahuatl <a href="/wiki/Locative" class="mw-redirect" title="Locative">locative</a>, making the word <i>Mexico</i> a place name. Beyond that, the etymology is uncertain. It has been suggested that it is derived from <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text"><a href="/wiki/Mextli" class="mw-redirect" title="Mextli">Mextli</a></i> or <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">Mēxihtli</i>, a secret name for the god of war and patron of the Mexica, <a href="/wiki/Huitzilopochtli" class="mw-redirect" title="Huitzilopochtli">Huitzilopochtli</a>, in which case <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">Mēxihco</i> means "place where Huitzilopochtli lives".<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> Another hypothesis suggests that <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">Mēxihco</i> derives from a <a href="/wiki/Portmanteau" title="Portmanteau">portmanteau</a> of the Nahuatl words for "moon" (<i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">Mētztli</i>) and navel (<i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">xīctli</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-edomex_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edomex-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> This meaning ("at the navel of the moon") might refer to Tenochtitlan's position in the middle of <a href="/wiki/Lake_Texcoco" title="Lake Texcoco">Lake Texcoco</a>. The system of interconnected lakes, of which Texcoco formed the center, had the form of a rabbit, which the Mesoamericans <a href="/wiki/Pareidolia" title="Pareidolia">pareidolically</a> associated with the <a href="/wiki/Moon_rabbit" title="Moon rabbit">moon rabbit</a>. Still another hypothesis suggests that the word is derived from <i lang="nah" title="Nahuatl languages collective text">Mēctli</i>, the name of the goddess of <a href="/wiki/Agave_americana" title="Agave americana">maguey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-edomex_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edomex-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The name of the city-state was transliterated to Spanish as <i lang="es" title="Spanish language text">México</i> with the phonetic value of the letter <i lang="es" title="Spanish language text">x</i> in <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Spanish" class="mw-redirect" title="Medieval Spanish">Medieval Spanish</a>, which represented the <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_postalveolar_fricative" title="Voiceless postalveolar fricative">voiceless postalveolar fricative</a> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ʃ]</span>. This sound, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Voiced_postalveolar_fricative" title="Voiced postalveolar fricative">voiced postalveolar fricative</a> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ʒ]</span>, represented by a <i lang="es" title="Spanish language text">j</i>, evolved into a <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative" title="Voiceless velar fricative">voiceless velar fricative</a> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[x]</span> during the 16th century. This led to the use of the variant <i lang="es-ES" title="Spanish language text">Méjico</i> in many publications in Spanish, most notably in Spain, whereas in Mexico and most other Spanish–speaking countries, <i lang="es-419" title="Spanish language text">México</i> was the preferred spelling. In recent years, the <a href="/wiki/Real_Academia_Espa%C3%B1ola" class="mw-redirect" title="Real Academia Española">Real Academia Española</a>, which regulates the Spanish language, determined that both variants are acceptable in Spanish but that the normative recommended <a href="/wiki/Spelling" title="Spelling">spelling</a> is <i lang="es" title="Spanish language text">México</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup> The majority of publications in all Spanish-speaking countries now adhere to the new norm, even though the alternative variant is still occasionally used.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, the 'x' in Mexico represents neither the original nor the current sound, but the consonant cluster <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ks]</span>.
</p><p>The official name of the country has changed as the <a href="/wiki/Form_of_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Form of government">form of government</a> has changed. The declaration of independence signed on November 6, 1813 by the deputies of the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_An%C3%A1huac" class="mw-redirect" title="Congress of Anáhuac">Congress of Anáhuac</a> called the territory <i><a href="/wiki/Solemn_Act_of_the_Declaration_of_Independence_of_Northern_America" title="Solemn Act of the Declaration of Independence of Northern America">América Septentrional</a></i> (Northern America). On two occasions (1821–1823 and 1863–1867), the country was known as <i lang="es" title="Spanish language text">Imperio Mexicano</i> (<a href="/wiki/Mexican_Empire_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Mexican Empire (disambiguation)">Mexican Empire</a>). All three federal constitutions (1824, 1857 and 1917, the current constitution) used the name <i lang="es" title="Spanish language text">Estados Unidos Mexicanos</i><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup>—or the variant <i lang="es" title="Spanish language text">Estados-Unidos Mexicanos</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> all of which have been translated as "United Mexican States". The phrase <i lang="es" title="Spanish language text">República Mexicana</i>, "Mexican Republic", was used in the 1836 Constitutional Laws.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico" title="History of Mexico">History of Mexico</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Roman_Catholicism_in_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Roman Catholicism in Mexico">History of Roman Catholicism in Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico" title="Economic history of Mexico">Economic history of Mexico</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico_City" title="History of Mexico City">History of Mexico City</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Columbian_Mexico">Pre-Columbian Mexico</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_Mexico" title="Pre-Columbian Mexico">Pre-Columbian Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_chronology" title="Mesoamerican chronology">Mesoamerican chronology</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Baja_California_Sur.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Baja_California_Sur.jpg/220px-Baja_California_Sur.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Baja_California_Sur.jpg/330px-Baja_California_Sur.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Baja_California_Sur.jpg/440px-Baja_California_Sur.jpg 2x" data-file-width="604" data-file-height="453" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Baja_California_Sur.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rock_Paintings_of_Sierra_de_San_Francisco" title="Rock Paintings of Sierra de San Francisco">Cave art painting occurred about 7,500 years old in Baja California Peninsula</a>. Culturally and geographically very distinct from Mesoamerica, indigenous peoples inhabited the region since the end of the <a href="/wiki/Pleistocene" title="Pleistocene">Pleistocene</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The earliest <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">human</a> artifacts in Mexico are chips of <a href="/wiki/Stone_tool" title="Stone tool">stone tools</a> found near campfire remains in the Valley of Mexico and radiocarbon-dated to circa 10,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-Werner2001_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Werner2001-60">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> Mexico is the site of the domestication of maize, tomato, and <a href="/wiki/Phaseolus" title="Phaseolus">beans</a>, which produced an agricultural surplus. This enabled the transition from <a href="/wiki/Paleo-Indians" title="Paleo-Indians">paleo-Indian</a> hunter-gatherers to sedentary agricultural villages beginning around 5000 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-EvansWebster2013_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EvansWebster2013-61">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the subsequent formative eras, maize cultivation and cultural traits such as a mythological and religious complex, and a <a href="/wiki/Vigesimal" title="Vigesimal">vigesimal</a> numeric system, were diffused from the Mexican cultures to the rest of the <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">Mesoamerican</a> culture area.<sup id="cite_ref-MacLachlan_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacLachlan-62">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> In this period, villages became more dense in terms of population, becoming socially stratified with an artisan class, and developing into <a href="/wiki/Chiefdom" title="Chiefdom">chiefdoms</a>. The most powerful rulers had religious and political power, organizing the construction of large ceremonial centers developed.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest complex civilization in Mexico was the <a href="/wiki/Olmec" class="mw-redirect" title="Olmec">Olmec</a> culture, which flourished on the Gulf Coast from around 1500 BC. Olmec cultural traits diffused through Mexico into other formative-era cultures in Chiapas, Oaxaca and the Valley of Mexico. The formative period saw the spread of distinct religious and symbolic traditions, as well as artistic and architectural complexes.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup> The formative-era of Mesoamerica is considered one of the six independent <a href="/wiki/Cradles_of_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Cradles of civilization">cradles of civilization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:15-07-13-Teotihuacan-RalfR-WMA_0257.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/15-07-13-Teotihuacan-RalfR-WMA_0257.jpg/220px-15-07-13-Teotihuacan-RalfR-WMA_0257.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/15-07-13-Teotihuacan-RalfR-WMA_0257.jpg/330px-15-07-13-Teotihuacan-RalfR-WMA_0257.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/15-07-13-Teotihuacan-RalfR-WMA_0257.jpg/440px-15-07-13-Teotihuacan-RalfR-WMA_0257.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5641" data-file-height="3766" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:15-07-13-Teotihuacan-RalfR-WMA_0257.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>View of the <a href="/wiki/Pyramid_of_the_Moon" title="Pyramid of the Moon">Pyramid of the Moon</a> and entrance to the <a href="/wiki/Quetzalpap%C3%A1lotl_Palace" class="mw-redirect" title="Quetzalpapálotl Palace">Quetzalpapálotl Palace</a>. During its peak in the Classic era, <a href="/wiki/Teotihuacan" title="Teotihuacan">Teotihuacán</a> dominated the Valley of Mexico and exerted political and cultural influence in other areas, such <a href="/wiki/Spearthrower_Owl" title="Spearthrower Owl">as in the Petén Basin</a>.</div></div></div><p> In the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_chronology" title="Mesoamerican chronology">pre-classical period</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Maya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_civilization" title="Zapotec civilization">Zapotec</a> civilizations developed complex centers at <a href="/wiki/Calakmul" title="Calakmul">Calakmul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Monte_Alb%C3%A1n" title="Monte Albán">Monte Albán</a>, respectively. During this period the first true <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_writing_systems" title="Mesoamerican writing systems">Mesoamerican writing systems</a> were developed in the <a href="/wiki/Epi-Olmec_culture" title="Epi-Olmec culture">Epi-Olmec</a> and the Zapotec cultures. The Mesoamerican writing tradition reached its height in the Classic <a href="/wiki/Maya_Script" class="mw-redirect" title="Maya Script">Maya Hieroglyphic script</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In Central Mexico, the height of the classic period saw the ascendancy of <a href="/wiki/Teotihuacan" title="Teotihuacan">Teotihuacán</a>, which formed a military and commercial empire whose political influence stretched south into the Maya area as well as north. Teotihuacan, with a population of more than 150,000 people, had some of the largest <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_pyramid" class="mw-redirect" title="Mesoamerican pyramid">pyramidal structures</a> in the pre-Columbian Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> After the collapse of Teotihuacán around 600 AD, competition ensued between several important political centers in central Mexico such as <a href="/wiki/Xochicalco" title="Xochicalco">Xochicalco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cholula_(Mesoamerican_site)" title="Cholula (Mesoamerican site)">Cholula</a>. At this time, during the Epi-Classic, <a href="/wiki/Nahua_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Nahua people">Nahua peoples</a> began moving south into Mesoamerica from the North, and became politically and culturally dominant in central Mexico, as they displaced speakers of <a href="/wiki/Oto-Manguean_languages" title="Oto-Manguean languages">Oto-Manguean languages</a>.
</p>
<h4><span id="Post-classic_period_.28ca._1000.E2.80.931519_AD.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-classic_period_(ca._1000–1519_AD)">Post-classic period (ca. 1000–1519 AD)</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Templo_Mayor_50.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Templo_Mayor_50.jpg/220px-Templo_Mayor_50.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Templo_Mayor_50.jpg/330px-Templo_Mayor_50.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Templo_Mayor_50.jpg/440px-Templo_Mayor_50.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3280" data-file-height="2460" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Templo_Mayor_50.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mexico-Tenochtitlan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexico-Tenochtitlan">Mexico-Tenochtitlan</a> <a href="/wiki/Templo_Mayor" title="Templo Mayor">Templo Mayor</a> ruins in downtown Mexico City.</div></div></div>
<p>During the early post-classic, Central Mexico was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Toltec" title="Toltec">Toltec</a> culture, <a href="/wiki/Oaxaca" title="Oaxaca">Oaxaca</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Mixtec_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Mixtec civilization">Mixtec</a>, and the lowland Maya area had important centers at <a href="/wiki/Chich%C3%A9n_Itz%C3%A1" class="mw-redirect" title="Chichén Itzá">Chichén Itzá</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mayap%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Mayapán">Mayapán</a>.
</p><p>Toward the end of the post-Classic period, the Mexica established dominance, establishing a political and economic empire based in the city of Tenochtitlan (modern Mexico City), extending from central Mexico to the border with Guatemala.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">Alexander von Humboldt</a> popularized the modern usage of "<a href="/wiki/Aztec" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec">Aztec</a>" as a collective term applied to all the people linked by trade, custom, religion, and language to the <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">Mexica state</a> and Ēxcān Tlahtōlōyān, the <a href="/wiki/Aztec_Empire" title="Aztec Empire">Triple Alliance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> In 1843, with the publication of the work of William H. Prescott, it was adopted by most of the world, including 19th-century Mexican scholars who considered it a way to distinguish present-day Mexicans from pre-conquest Mexicans. This usage has been the subject of debate since the late 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Port_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Port-70">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Aztec empire was an informal or hegemonic empire because it did not exert supreme authority over the conquered lands; it was satisfied with the payment of tributes from them. It was a discontinuous empire because not all dominated territories were connected; for example, the southern peripheral zones of <a href="/wiki/Soconusco" title="Soconusco">Xoconochco</a> were not in direct contact with the center. The hegemonic nature of the Aztec empire was demonstrated by their restoration of local rulers to their former position after their city-state was conquered. The Aztec did not interfere in local affairs, as long as the tributes were paid.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg/220px-Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg/330px-Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg/440px-Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Murales_Rivera_-_Markt_in_Tlatelolco_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1945 Mural by Diego Rivera depicting the view from the <a href="/wiki/Tlatelolco_(altepetl)" title="Tlatelolco (altepetl)">Tlatelolco</a> markets into Mexico-Tenochtitlan, the largest city in the Americas at the time.</div></div></div>
<p>The Aztec of Central Mexico built a tributary empire covering most of central Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Human_sacrifice_in_Aztec_culture" title="Human sacrifice in Aztec culture">The Aztec were noted for practicing human sacrifice</a> on a large scale. Along with this practice, they avoided killing enemies on the battlefield. Their warring casualty rate was far lower than that of their Spanish counterparts, whose principal objective was immediate slaughter during battle.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> This distinct Mesoamerican cultural tradition of human sacrifice ended with the gradually Spanish conquest in the 16th century. Over the next centuries many Mexican indigenous cultures were gradually subjected to Spanish colonial rule by more conquests.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Conquest_of_the_Aztec_Triple_Alliance_.281519.E2.80.931521.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Conquest_of_the_Aztec_Triple_Alliance_(1519–1521)">Conquest of the Aztec Triple Alliance (1519–1521)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish conquest of Mexico">Spanish conquest of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg/220px-Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg/330px-Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg/440px-Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg 2x" data-file-width="618" data-file-height="495" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cortez_%26_La_Malinche.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Image of <a href="/wiki/Hern%C3%A1n_Cort%C3%A9s" title="Hernán Cortés">Hernán Cortés</a> and <a href="/wiki/La_Malinche" title="La Malinche">La Malinche</a> meeting <a href="/wiki/Moctezuma_II" title="Moctezuma II">Moctezuma II</a> from the <i><a href="/wiki/Lienzo_de_Tlaxcala" class="mw-redirect" title="Lienzo de Tlaxcala">Lienzo de Tlaxcala</a></i>, created c. 1550 by the Tlaxcalans to remind the Spanish of their loyalty and the importance of <a href="/wiki/Tlaxcala_(Nahua_state)" title="Tlaxcala (Nahua state)">Tlaxcala</a> during the conquest.</div></div></div>
<p>The Spanish first learned of Mexico during the <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_Grijalva" title="Juan de Grijalva">Juan de Grijalva</a> expedition of 1518. The natives kept "repeating: <i>Colua, Colua</i>, and <i>Mexico, Mexico</i>, but we [explorers] did not know what <i>Colua</i> or <i>Mexico</i> meant", until encountering Montezuma's governor at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Boca_del_R%C3%ADo,_Veracruz" title="Boca del Río, Veracruz">Rio de las Banderas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Diaz_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diaz-75">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>33–36</span></sup>  The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Aztec_Empire" title="Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire">Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire</a> began in February 1519 when <a href="/wiki/Hern%C3%A1n_Cort%C3%A9s" title="Hernán Cortés">Hernán Cortés</a> arrived at the port in <a href="/wiki/Veracruz,_Veracruz" class="mw-redirect" title="Veracruz, Veracruz">Veracruz</a> with ca. 500 <a href="/wiki/Conquistador" title="Conquistador">conquistadores</a>. After taking control of that city, he moved on to the Aztec capital. In his search for gold and other riches, Cortés decided to invade and conquer the Aztec empire.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>When the Spaniards arrived, the ruler of the Aztec empire was <a href="/wiki/Moctezuma_II" title="Moctezuma II">Moctezuma II</a>, who was later killed. His successor and brother <a href="/wiki/Cuitl%C3%A1huac" title="Cuitláhuac">Cuitláhuac</a> took control of the Aztec empire, but was among the first to fall from the first <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> <a href="/wiki/Epidemic" title="Epidemic">epidemic</a> in the area a short time later.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> Unintentionally introduced by Spanish conquerors, among whom <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> was endemic, the infectious disease ravaged Mesoamerica in the 1520s. It killed more than 3 million natives as they had no <a href="/wiki/Immunity_(medical)" title="Immunity (medical)">immunity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> Other sources, however, mentioned that the death toll of the Aztecs might have reached 15 million (out of a population of less than 30 million) although such a high number conflicts with the 350,000 Aztecs who ruled an empire of 5 million or 10 million.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> Severely weakened, the Aztec empire was easily defeated by Cortés and his forces on his second return with the help of state of <a href="/wiki/Tlaxcala" title="Tlaxcala">Tlaxcala</a> whose population estimate was 300,000.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> The native population declined 80–90% by 1600 to 1–2.5 million. Any population estimate of pre-Columbian Mexico is bound to be a guess but 8–12 million is often suggested for the area encompassed by the modern nation.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Leutze,_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg/220px-Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="193" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg/330px-Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg/440px-Leutze%2C_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1050" data-file-height="921" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Leutze,_Emanuel_%E2%80%94_Storming_of_the_Teocalli_by_Cortez_and_His_Troops_%E2%80%94_1848.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Storming of the <a href="/wiki/Teocalli" title="Teocalli">Teocalli</a> by Cortés and his troops. <a href="/wiki/Emanuel_Leutze" title="Emanuel Leutze">Emanuel Leutze</a>. Painting, 1848</div></div></div>
<p>Smallpox was a devastating disease: it generally killed Aztecs but not Spaniards, who as Europeans had already been exposed to it in their cities for centuries and therefore had developed <a href="/wiki/Adaptive_immune_system" title="Adaptive immune system">acquired immunity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> The deaths caused by smallpox are believed to have triggered a rapid growth of Christianity in Mexico and the Americas. At first, the Aztecs believed the epidemic was a punishment from an angry god, but they later accepted their fate and no longer resisted the Spanish rule.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> Many of the surviving Aztecs believed that smallpox could be credited to the superiority of the Christian god, which resulted in their acceptance of Catholicism and yielding to the Spanish rule throughout Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The territory became part of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> under the name of <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a> in 1535.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a> was systematically rebuilt by Cortés following the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Tenochtitlan" title="Fall of Tenochtitlan">Fall of Tenochtitlan</a> in 1521. Much of the identity, traditions and architecture of Mexico developed during the 286-year colonial period.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain_.281521.E2.80.931821.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain_(1521–1821)">Viceroyalty of New Spain (1521–1821)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Estatua_ecuestre_de_Carlos_IV.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Estatua_ecuestre_de_Carlos_IV.jpg/220px-Estatua_ecuestre_de_Carlos_IV.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Estatua_ecuestre_de_Carlos_IV.jpg/330px-Estatua_ecuestre_de_Carlos_IV.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Estatua_ecuestre_de_Carlos_IV.jpg/440px-Estatua_ecuestre_de_Carlos_IV.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3774" data-file-height="2548" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Estatua_ecuestre_de_Carlos_IV.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Equestrian_statue_of_Charles_IV" class="mw-redirect" title="Equestrian statue of Charles IV">Equestrian statue of Charles IV</a>, Mexico City, <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Tols%C3%A1" title="Manuel Tolsá">Manuel Tolsá</a>. The Spanish Monarch was the maximum authority in New Spain and ruled via a <a href="/wiki/List_of_viceroys_of_New_Spain" title="List of viceroys of New Spain">viceroy</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The capture of Tenochtitlan and refounding of Mexico City in 1521 was the beginning of a 286-year-long colonial era during which Mexico was known as <i>Nueva España</i> (New Spain). The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_New_Spain" title="Kingdom of New Spain">Kingdom of New Spain</a> was created from the remnants of the Aztec hegemonic empire. In 1524, <a href="/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor">King Charles I</a> created the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_Indies" title="Council of the Indies">Council of the Indies</a> to rule the country and to limit <a href="/wiki/Hern%C3%A1n_Cort%C3%A9s" title="Hernán Cortés">Hernán Cortés's</a> power, but three years later power was transferred to a court known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Real_Audiencia" title="Real Audiencia">Real Audiencia</a>.</i><sup id="cite_ref-files_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-files-86">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> Subsequent enlargements, such as the conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Tarascan_state" title="Tarascan state">Tarascan state</a>, resulted in the creation of the <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">Viceroyalty of New Spain</a> in 1535. The Viceroyalty at its greatest extent included the territories of modern Mexico, Central America as far south as Costa Rica, and the western United States. The Viceregal capital Mexico City also administrated the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_West_Indies" title="Spanish West Indies">Spanish West Indies</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Florida" title="Spanish Florida">Spanish Florida</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-files_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-files-86">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The indigenous population stabilized around one to one and a half million individuals in the 17th century from the most commonly accepted five to thirty million <a href="/wiki/Population_history_of_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Population history of indigenous peoples of the Americas">pre-contact population</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-McCaa_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCaa-87">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> The population decline, perhaps between 50%-85% at its height,<sup id="cite_ref-McCaa_87-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCaa-87">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> was primarily the result of communicable diseases, particularly <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a>, introduced during the <a href="/wiki/Columbian_Exchange" class="mw-redirect" title="Columbian Exchange">Columbian Exchange</a>, although some scholars blame the harsh rule and slavery.<sup id="cite_ref-McCaa_87-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCaa-87">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> During the three hundred years of the colonial era, Mexico received between 400,000 and 500,000 Europeans,<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> between 200,000 and 250,000 African slaves.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> and between 40,000 and 120,000 Asians.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup> The 18th century saw a great increase in the percentage of mestizos.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Colonial <a href="/wiki/Law_in_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Law in Spain">law with Spanish roots</a> was introduced and attached to native customs creating a hierarchy between local jurisdiction (the <a href="/wiki/Cabildo_(council)" title="Cabildo (council)">Cabildos</a>) and the Spanish Crown. Upper administrative offices were closed to native-born people, even those of pure Spanish blood (<a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">criollos</a>). Administration was based on the <a href="/wiki/Racial_separation" class="mw-redirect" title="Racial separation">racial separation</a>, among "Republics" of Spaniards, Amerindians and <i><a href="/wiki/Castas" class="mw-redirect" title="Castas">castas</a></i>, autonomous and directly dependent on the king himself.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz_(1772).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz_%281772%29.jpg/170px-Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz_%281772%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="214" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz_%281772%29.jpg/255px-Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz_%281772%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz_%281772%29.jpg/340px-Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz_%281772%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="968" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz_(1772).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Portrait of Sor <a href="/wiki/Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz" title="Juana Inés de la Cruz">Juana Inés de la Cruz</a>, oil on canvas, 1772</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Indies" class="mw-redirect" title="Council of Indies">Council of Indies</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mendicant_order" class="mw-redirect" title="Mendicant order">mendicant religious orders</a>, which arrived in Mesoamerica as early as 1524, labored to generate capital for the crown of Spain and convert the Amerindian populations to Catholicism. The 1531 <a href="/wiki/Marian_apparition" title="Marian apparition">Marian apparitions</a> to Saint <a href="/wiki/Juan_Diego" title="Juan Diego">Juan Diego</a> gave impetus to the evangelization of central Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-huff_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-huff-94">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Virgin_of_Guadalupe" class="mw-redirect" title="Virgin of Guadalupe">Virgin of Guadalupe</a> became a symbol of <i>criollo</i> patriotism<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup> and was used by the insurgents who followed <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo" class="mw-redirect" title="Miguel Hidalgo">Miguel Hidalgo</a> during the War of Independence.<sup id="cite_ref-huff_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-huff-94">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> Some <a href="/wiki/Marrano" title="Marrano">Crypto-Jewish</a> families emigrated to Mexico to escape the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Inquisition" title="Spanish Inquisition">Spanish Inquisition</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>The rich deposits of silver, particularly in <a href="/wiki/Zacatecas" title="Zacatecas">Zacatecas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guanajuato" title="Guanajuato">Guanajuato</a>, resulted in silver extraction dominating the economy of New Spain. <a href="/wiki/Royal_fifth" title="Royal fifth">Taxes on silver production</a> became a major source of income for Spain. Other important industries were the <a href="/wiki/Haciendas" class="mw-redirect" title="Haciendas">haciendas</a> (functioning under the <a href="/wiki/Encomienda" title="Encomienda">encomienda</a> and <a href="/wiki/Repartimiento" title="Repartimiento">repartimiento</a> systems) and mercantile activities in the main cities and ports.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> Wealth created during the colonial era spurred the development of <a href="/wiki/New_Spanish_Baroque" title="New Spanish Baroque">New Spanish Baroque</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>As a result of its trade links with Asia, the rest of the Americas, Africa and Europe and the <a href="/wiki/Global_silver_trade_from_the_16th_to_18th_centuries" title="Global silver trade from the 16th to 18th centuries">profound effect of New World silver</a>, central Mexico was one of the first regions to be incorporated into a <a href="/wiki/Globalized" class="mw-redirect" title="Globalized">globalized</a> economy. Being at the crossroads of trade, people and cultures, Mexico City has been called the "first <a href="/wiki/World_city" class="mw-redirect" title="World city">world city</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Nao_de_China" class="mw-redirect" title="Nao de China">Nao de China</a></i> (Manila Galleons) operated for two and a half centuries and connected New Spain with Asia. Goods were taken from Veracruz to Atlantic ports in the Americas and Spain. Veracruz was also the main port of entry in mainland New Spain for European goods, immigrants, and African slaves. The <i><a href="/wiki/Camino_Real_de_Tierra_Adentro" title="Camino Real de Tierra Adentro">Camino Real de Tierra Adentro</a></i> connected Mexico City with the interior of New Spain. Mexican silver pesos became the first globally used currency and the silver mined in Mexico were used to run commerce and wage crusades in two sides of globe, at the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a>, where Spain fought against the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Caliphate" title="Ottoman Caliphate">Ottoman Caliphate</a>, and at <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> where the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> fought against the <a href="/wiki/Brunei_Sultanate" class="mw-redirect" title="Brunei Sultanate">Brunei Sultanate</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Guanajuato_night.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Guanajuato_night.JPG/220px-Guanajuato_night.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Guanajuato_night.JPG/330px-Guanajuato_night.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Guanajuato_night.JPG/440px-Guanajuato_night.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2816" data-file-height="2112" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Guanajuato_night.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Guanajuato_City" title="Guanajuato City">Guanajuato City</a> became the world's leading silver producer in the 18th century as a result of the <i><a href="/wiki/Mother_lode" title="Mother lode">veta madre</a></i>.</div></div></div>
<p>Due to the importance of New Spain administrative base, Mexico was the location of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_the_First_Print_Shop_in_the_Americas" title="House of the First Print Shop in the Americas">first printing shop</a> (1539),<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Royal_and_Pontifical_University_of_Mexico" title="Royal and Pontifical University of Mexico">first university</a> (1551),<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alameda_Central" title="Alameda Central">first public park</a> (1592),<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Biblioteca_Palafoxiana" title="Biblioteca Palafoxiana">first public library</a> (1640) in the Americas,<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> among other institutions. Important artists of the colonial period, include the writers <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ruiz_de_Alarc%C3%B3n" title="Juan Ruiz de Alarcón">Juan Ruiz de Alarcón</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sor_Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz" class="mw-redirect" title="Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz">Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz</a>, painters <a href="/wiki/Crist%C3%B3bal_de_Villalpando" title="Cristóbal de Villalpando">Cristóbal de Villalpando</a> and <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Cabrera_(painter)" title="Miguel Cabrera (painter)">Miguel Cabrera</a>, and architect <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Tols%C3%A1" title="Manuel Tolsá">Manuel Tolsá</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_San_Carlos" title="Academy of San Carlos">Academy of San Carlos</a> (1781) was the first major school and museum of art in the Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup> Scientist <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_del_R%C3%ADo_Fern%C3%A1ndez" class="mw-redirect" title="Andrés Manuel del Río Fernández">Andrés Manuel del Río Fernández</a> discovered the element <a href="/wiki/Vanadium" title="Vanadium">vanadium</a> in 1801.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Spanish forces, sometimes accompanied by native allies, led expeditions to conquer territory or quell rebellions through the colonial era. Notable Amerindian revolts in sporadically populated northern New Spain include the <a href="/wiki/Chichimeca_War" title="Chichimeca War">Chichimeca War</a> (1576–1606),<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tepehu%C3%A1n_Revolt" title="Tepehuán Revolt">Tepehuán Revolt</a> (1616–1620),<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Pueblo_Revolt" title="Pueblo Revolt">Pueblo Revolt</a> (1680). To protect Mexico from the attacks of English, French, and Dutch <a href="/wiki/Pirates" class="mw-redirect" title="Pirates">pirates</a> and protect the Crown's monopoly of revenue, only two ports were open to foreign trade—Veracruz on the Atlantic and Acapulco on the Pacific. Among the best-known pirate attacks are the 1663 <a href="/wiki/Sack_of_Campeche_(1663)" title="Sack of Campeche (1663)">Sack of Campeche</a><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> and 1683 <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Veracruz" title="Attack on Veracruz">Attack on Veracruz</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Many Mexican cultural features including <a href="/wiki/Tequila" title="Tequila">tequila</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> first distilled in the 16th century, <a href="/wiki/Charreria" class="mw-redirect" title="Charreria">charreria</a> (17th),<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mariachi" title="Mariachi">mariachi</a> (18th) and <a href="/wiki/Mexican_cuisine" title="Mexican cuisine">Mexican cuisine</a>, a fusion <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">of American</a> and European (<a href="/wiki/Spanish_cuisine" title="Spanish cuisine">particularly Spanish</a>) cuisine, arose during the colonial era.
</p>
<h3><span id="War_of_Independence_.281810.E2.80.931821.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="War_of_Independence_(1810–1821)">War of Independence (1810–1821)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">Mexican War of Independence</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Miguel_Hidalgo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Miguel_Hidalgo.jpg/170px-Miguel_Hidalgo.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="209" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Miguel_Hidalgo.jpg/255px-Miguel_Hidalgo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Miguel_Hidalgo.jpg/340px-Miguel_Hidalgo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1015" data-file-height="1247" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Miguel_Hidalgo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo_y_Costilla" title="Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla">Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla</a></div></div></div>
<p>On September 16, <a href="/wiki/1810_in_Mexico" title="1810 in Mexico">1810</a>, a "loyalist revolt" against the ruling <a href="/wiki/Junta_(governing_body)" title="Junta (governing body)">junta</a> was declared by priest <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo_y_Costilla" title="Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla">Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla</a>, in the small town of <a href="/wiki/Dolores_Hidalgo" title="Dolores Hidalgo">Dolores</a>, Guanajuato.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> This event, known as the <a href="/wiki/Cry_of_Dolores" title="Cry of Dolores">Cry of Dolores</a> (Spanish: <i>Grito de Dolores</i>) is commemorated each year, on September 16, as Mexico's independence day.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> The first insurgent group was formed by Hidalgo, the Spanish <a href="/wiki/Viceregal" class="mw-redirect" title="Viceregal">viceregal</a> army captain <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_Allende" title="Ignacio Allende">Ignacio Allende</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Militia" title="Militia">militia</a> captain <a href="/wiki/Juan_Aldama" title="Juan Aldama">Juan Aldama</a> and <i>La Corregidora</i> (English: "The Magistrate") <a href="/wiki/Josefa_Ortiz_de_Dom%C3%ADnguez" title="Josefa Ortiz de Domínguez">Josefa Ortiz de Domínguez</a>. Hidalgo and some of his soldiers were captured and <a href="/wiki/Executed_by_firing_squad" class="mw-redirect" title="Executed by firing squad">executed by firing squad</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chihuahua,_Chihuahua" class="mw-redirect" title="Chihuahua, Chihuahua">Chihuahua</a>, on July 31, 1811.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>17–27</span></sup>
</p><p>Following Hidalgo's death, the leadership was assumed by <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_L%C3%B3pez_Ray%C3%B3n" title="Ignacio López Rayón">Ignacio López Rayón</a> and then by the priest <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Morelos" title="José María Morelos">José María Morelos</a>, who occupied key southern cities with the support of <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Matamoros" title="Mariano Matamoros">Mariano Matamoros</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Bravo" title="Nicolás Bravo">Nicolás Bravo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>35–37</span></sup> In one notable incident, Nicolas Bravo captured 200 royalist soldiers, whom Morelos ordered should be executed in revenge of the murder of Bravo's father. In an act of mercy, Bravo instead pardoned the prisoners, most of whom then joined the insurgent cause.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>40–41</span></sup> In 1813 the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Chilpancingo" title="Congress of Chilpancingo">Congress of Chilpancingo</a> was convened and, on November 6, signed the "<a href="/wiki/Solemn_Act_of_the_Declaration_of_Independence_of_Northern_America" title="Solemn Act of the Declaration of Independence of Northern America">Solemn Act of the Declaration of Independence of Northern America</a>". This Act also abolished slavery and the caste system.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>44–50</span></sup> Morelos was captured and executed on December 22, <a href="/w/index.php?title=1815_in_Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1815 in Mexico (page does not exist)">1815</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>46</span></sup>
</p>
