<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG/220px-Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG/330px-Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG/440px-Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3056" data-file-height="2292" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Abrazo_de_Acatempan.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Depiction of the <i>Abrazo de Acatempan</i> between <a href="/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_de_Iturbide" title="Agustín de Iturbide">Agustín de Iturbide</a>, left, and <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Vicente Guerrero</a></div></div></div>
<p>In subsequent years, the insurgency was near collapse, but in 1820 <a href="/wiki/Viceroy" title="Viceroy">Viceroy</a> <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ruiz_de_Apodaca" class="mw-redirect" title="Juan Ruiz de Apodaca">Juan Ruiz de Apodaca</a> sent an army under the <a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">criollo</a> general <a href="/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_de_Iturbide" title="Agustín de Iturbide">Agustín de Iturbide</a> against the troops of <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Vicente Guerrero</a>. Instead, Iturbide approached Guerrero to join forces, and on August 24, <a href="/wiki/1821_in_Mexico" title="1821 in Mexico">1821</a> representatives of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Crown" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish Crown">Spanish Crown</a> and Iturbide signed the "<a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Treaty of Córdoba">Treaty of Córdoba</a>" and the "<a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Independence_of_the_Mexican_Empire" title="Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire">Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire</a>", which recognized the <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Independence of Mexico">independence of Mexico</a> under the terms of the "<a href="/wiki/Plan_of_Iguala" title="Plan of Iguala">Plan of Iguala</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>53–80</span></sup>
</p><p>Mexico's short recovery after the War of Independence was soon cut short again by the civil wars, foreign invasion and occupation, and institutional instability of the mid-19th century, which lasted until the government of <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">Porfirio Díaz</a> reestablished conditions that paved the way for economic growth. The conflicts that arose from the mid-1850s had a profound effect because they were widespread and made themselves perceptible in the vast rural areas of the countries, involved clashes between castes, different ethnic groups, and haciendas, and entailed a deepening of the political and ideological divisions between republicans and monarchists.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="First_Empire_and_First_Republic_.281821.E2.80.931846.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="First_Empire_and_First_Republic_(1821–1846)">First Empire and First Republic (1821–1846)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Empire" title="First Mexican Empire">First Mexican Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Republic" title="First Mexican Republic">First Mexican Republic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Centralist_Republic_of_Mexico" title="Centralist Republic of Mexico">Centralist Republic of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexico%27s_Territorial_Evolution.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Mexico%27s_Territorial_Evolution.png/220px-Mexico%27s_Territorial_Evolution.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Mexico%27s_Territorial_Evolution.png/330px-Mexico%27s_Territorial_Evolution.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Mexico%27s_Territorial_Evolution.png/440px-Mexico%27s_Territorial_Evolution.png 2x" data-file-width="1669" data-file-height="1518" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexico%27s_Territorial_Evolution.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_Mexico" title="Territorial evolution of Mexico">territorial evolution of Mexico</a> after independence, noting the secession of <a href="/wiki/Federal_Republic_of_Central_America" title="Federal Republic of Central America">Central America</a> (purple), <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">Chiapas</a> annexed from <a href="/wiki/Captaincy_General_of_Guatemala" title="Captaincy General of Guatemala">Guatemala</a> (blue), losses to the U.S. (red, white and orange) and the reannexation of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Republic of Yucatán">Republic of Yucatán</a> (red)</div></div></div>
<p>Agustín de Iturbide became constitutional emperor of the <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Empire" title="First Mexican Empire">First Mexican Empire</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=1822_in_Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1822 in Mexico (page does not exist)">1822</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>87–88</span></sup> A revolt against him in 1823 established the <a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Republic" title="First Mexican Republic">United Mexican States</a>. In <a href="/w/index.php?title=1824_in_Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1824 in Mexico (page does not exist)">1824</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_1824" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of 1824">Republican Constitution</a> was drafted and <a href="/wiki/Guadalupe_Victoria" title="Guadalupe Victoria">Guadalupe Victoria</a> became the first president of the newly born country.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>94–95</span></sup> Central America, including Chiapas, left the union. In 1829 president <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Guerrero" title="Vicente Guerrero">Guerrero</a> abolished slavery.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> The first decades of the post-independence period were marked by a chronic <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico" title="Economic history of Mexico">economic instability</a>, which led to the <a href="/wiki/Pastry_War" title="Pastry War">first French invasion</a> in <a href="/wiki/1836_in_Mexico" title="1836 in Mexico">1836</a>. There was constant strife between Liberals, supporters of a <a href="/wiki/Federal_republic" title="Federal republic">federal form of government</a>, and Conservatives, who proposed a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">hierarchical form of government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>101–115, 125–127</span></sup>
</p><p>During this period, the frontier borderlands from north to south, including <a href="/wiki/Jalisco" title="Jalisco">Jalisco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yucatan" class="mw-redirect" title="Yucatan">Yucatan</a>, became quite isolated from the government in Mexico City, and its lack of an industrial base and monopolistic economic policies caused suffering.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>88–89</span></sup> With limited trade, the people had difficulty meeting tax payments and resented the central government's actions in collecting customs. Resentment built up from California to Texas. Both the mission system and the <i><a href="/wiki/Presidios" class="mw-redirect" title="Presidios">presidios</a></i> had collapsed after the Spanish withdrew from the colony, causing great disruption especially in Alta California and New Mexico. The people in the borderlands had to raise local militias to protect themselves from hostile Native Americans.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>128–129</span></sup> These areas developed in different directions from the center of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-115">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Wanting to stabilize and develop the frontier, Mexico encouraged immigration into present-day Texas, as they were unable to persuade people from central Mexico to move into those areas. They allowed for religious freedom for the new settlers, who were primarily Protestant English speakers from the United States. Within several years, the Anglos far outnumbered the <a href="/wiki/Tejano" title="Tejano">Tejano</a> in the area. Itinerant traders traveled through the area, working by free-market principles. The Tejano grew more separate from the government and due to its neglect, many supported the idea of independence and joined movements to that end, collaborating with the English-speaking Americans.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-115">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>General <a href="/wiki/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna" title="Antonio López de Santa Anna">Antonio López de Santa Anna</a>, a centralist and two-time dictator, approved the <a href="/wiki/Siete_Leyes" title="Siete Leyes">Siete Leyes</a> (Seven Laws) in 1836, a radical amendment that institutionalized the centralized form of government. When he suspended the 1824 Constitution, civil war spread across the country. Three new governments declared independence: the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Texas" title="Republic of Texas">Republic of Texas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_the_Rio_Grande" title="Republic of the Rio Grande">Republic of the Rio Grande</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Republic of Yucatán">Republic of Yucatán</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>129–137</span></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Second_Republic_and_Second_Empire_.281846.E2.80.931867.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_Republic_and_Second_Empire_(1846–1867)">Second Republic and Second Empire (1846–1867)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Second_Mexican_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Mexican Republic">Second Mexican Republic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Mexican_Empire" title="Second Mexican Empire">Second Mexican Empire</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BenitoJuarez.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/BenitoJuarez.jpg/170px-BenitoJuarez.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/BenitoJuarez.jpg/255px-BenitoJuarez.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b3/BenitoJuarez.jpg 2x" data-file-width="328" data-file-height="440" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BenitoJuarez.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Benito_Ju%C3%A1rez" title="Benito Juárez">Benito Juárez</a>, 26th President of Mexico and implanter of <a href="/wiki/La_Reforma" title="La Reforma">La Reforma</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/1846" title="1846">1846</a> United States annexation of the Republic of Texas and subsequent American military incursion into territory that was part of Coahuila (also claimed by Texas) instigated the <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War" title="Mexican–American War">Mexican–American War</a>. 26,922 regular U.S. soldiers and 73,260 volunteers served at some time during the war;<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> including those killed and wounded in action and killed by disease, total U.S. have been over 27,000.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>156</span></sup> The Mexican army was comparable in size, although its soldiers were poorly equipped, poorly trained, and poorly organized. <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War_campaigns" title="Mexican–American War campaigns">Major battles</a> were fought in Monterrey, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Buena_Vista" title="Battle of Buena Vista">Buena Vista</a>, Veracruz, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cerro_Gordo" title="Battle of Cerro Gordo">Cerro Gordo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Contreras" title="Battle of Contreras">Padierna</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Chapultepec" title="Battle of Chapultepec">the military academy at Chapultepec</a>. Hundreds of civilians were killed during the three-day bombardment of Veracruz<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ni%C3%B1os_H%C3%A9roes" title="Niños Héroes">Six teenage cadets</a> were killed during the final defense of Mexico City at Chapultepec. The war was settled in <a href="/wiki/1848" title="1848">1848</a> via the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Guadalupe_Hidalgo" title="Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo">Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>154</span></sup> Mexico was forced to give up more than one-third of its land (2,378,000&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (918,000&#160;sq&#160;mi)) to the U.S., including <a href="/wiki/Alta_California" title="Alta California">Alta California</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santa_Fe_de_Nuevo_M%C3%A9xico" title="Santa Fe de Nuevo México">Santa Fe de Nuevo México</a> and the territory claimed by Texas.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>156</span></sup> A much smaller transfer of territory in what is today southern <a href="/wiki/Arizona" title="Arizona">Arizona</a> and southwestern <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">New Mexico</a>—known as the <a href="/wiki/Gadsden_Purchase" title="Gadsden Purchase">Gadsden Purchase</a>—occurred in 1854.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Caste_War_of_Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Caste War of Yucatán">Caste War of Yucatán</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Maya_peoples" title="Maya peoples">Maya</a> uprising that began in 1847, was one of the most successful modern Native American revolts.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> Maya rebels, or <a href="/wiki/Cruzob" class="mw-redirect" title="Cruzob">Cruzob</a>, maintained relatively independent enclaves in the peninsula until the 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Dissatisfaction with Santa Anna's return to power led to the liberal "<a href="/wiki/Plan_of_Ayutla" title="Plan of Ayutla">Plan of Ayutla</a>", initiating an era known as <a href="/wiki/La_Reforma" title="La Reforma">La Reforma</a> ("The Reform"). The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_1857" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of 1857">new Constitution drafted in 1857</a> established a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federalism</a> as the form of government, civil marriage, freedom of the press, and educational freedom (lay education).<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>191</span></sup> As the Conservatives refused to recognize it, the <a href="/wiki/Reform_War" title="Reform War">Reform War</a> began in 1858, during which both groups had their own governments. The war ended in 1861 with victory by the Liberals, led by president <a href="/wiki/Benito_Ju%C3%A1rez" title="Benito Juárez">Benito Juárez</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>195</span></sup> who was an ethnic <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_peoples" title="Zapotec peoples">Zapotec</a>.
</p><p>By <a href="/w/index.php?title=1861_in_Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1861 in Mexico (page does not exist)">1861</a>, 91% of the government's income was destined for payment of the foreign debt or maintenance of the army, leaving only 9% for everything else. Juarez decided to suspend debt payments for two years, prompting England, France, and Spain to agree to military intervention. Juarez negotiated with representatives of the three countries after they occupied the port of Veracruz until a French warship arrived and the captain announced they intended to overthrow the elected president and install conservative <a href="/wiki/Juan_Almonte" title="Juan Almonte">Juan Almonte</a> as president. Upon learning this the French and English ships withdrew, but the French decided to advance on the city of Puebla.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>203–206</span></sup> General <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_Zaragoza" title="Ignacio Zaragoza">Ignacio Zaragoza</a> defeated the invaders at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Puebla" title="Battle of Puebla">Battle of Puebla</a> on <a href="/wiki/Cinco_de_Mayo" title="Cinco de Mayo">May 5, 1862</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>207</span></sup> which is widely celebrated as the <i>Cinco de Mayo</i> holiday in both Mexico and the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> Following this French defeat, emperor <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_III" title="Napoleon III">Napoleon III</a> sent 50,000 reinforcements and on March 16, <a href="/wiki/1863_in_Mexico" title="1863 in Mexico">1863</a> fought a second battle in Puebla, easily defeating the Mexican army led by <a href="/wiki/Jes%C3%BAs_Gonz%C3%A1lez_Ortega" title="Jesús González Ortega">Jesús González Ortega</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>208</span></sup>
</p><p>Juarez was forced to retreat north, and the conservatives offered a throne to Archduke <a href="/wiki/Maximilian_I_of_Mexico" title="Maximilian I of Mexico">Ferdinand Maximilian</a> of <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">Austria</a>. Maximilian established the <a href="/wiki/Second_Mexican_Empire" title="Second Mexican Empire">Second Mexican Empire</a> in <a href="/wiki/1864_in_Mexico" title="1864 in Mexico">1864</a>, quickly surrounding himself with liberals and adopting many of the policies of the <i>Reforma</i>. Meanwhile, Napoleon III feared a European war and withdrew his troops in <a href="/w/index.php?title=1866_in_Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1866 in Mexico (page does not exist)">1866</a>. The Republicans were able to defeat the empire, and Maximilian was captured and executed in <a href="/wiki/Quer%C3%A9taro_City" title="Querétaro City">Querétaro</a> on June 19, <a href="/wiki/1867_in_Mexico" title="1867 in Mexico">1867</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>208–217</span></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Porfiriato_.281876.E2.80.931911.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Porfiriato_(1876–1911)">Porfiriato (1876–1911)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">Porfirio Díaz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porfiriato" title="Porfiriato">Porfiriato</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">Porfirio Díaz</a>, a republican general during the French intervention, was elected the 29th president in 1876. The 1880 election was won by <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Gonz%C3%A1lez_Flores" title="Manuel González Flores">Manuel González Flores</a>. Díaz was reelected in 1884 and ruled until 1911. The period, known as the Porfiriato, was characterized by economic stability and growth, significant foreign investment and influence, investments in the arts and sciences and an expansion of the <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Mexico" title="Rail transport in Mexico">railroad network</a> and telecommunications.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup> The period was concurrent with the <a href="/wiki/Gilded_Age" title="Gilded Age">Gilded Age</a> in the U.S. and <a href="/wiki/Belle_%C3%89poque" title="Belle Époque">Belle Époque</a> in France and was also marked by economic inequality, and political repression. The economy has been described as semi-colonial, as foreign (mostly British and American) investment was encouraged at the expense of the Mexican people and land was controlled by local <i>caciques</i> (petty tyrants).<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>265–271</span></sup>
</p><p>Díaz ruled with a group of confidants that became known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Cient%C3%ADfico" title="Científico">científicos</a></i> ("scientists"). The most influential <i>cientifco</i> was Secretary of Finance <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Yves_Limantour" title="José Yves Limantour">José Yves Limantour</a>. The Porfirian regime was influenced by <a href="/wiki/Positivism" title="Positivism">positivism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cientifico_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cientifico-125">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> They rejected theology and <a href="/wiki/Idealism" title="Idealism">idealism</a> in favor of scientific methods being applied towards national development.<sup id="cite_ref-cientifico_125-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cientifico-125">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> Various iconic buildings and monuments were initiated by Díaz, including the <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palacio de Bellas Artes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Correos_de_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Palacio de Correos de Mexico">Palacio de Correos de Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monumento_a_la_Independencia" class="mw-redirect" title="Monumento a la Independencia">Monumento a la Independencia</a> and the Palacio Legislativo (which became the <a href="/wiki/Monumento_a_la_Revoluci%C3%B3n" title="Monumento a la Revolución">Monumento a la Revolución</a>).
</p>
<h3><span id="Mexican_Revolution_.281910.E2.80.931920.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mexican_Revolution_(1910–1920)">Mexican Revolution (1910–1920)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Madero_en_Cuernavaca.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Madero_en_Cuernavaca.jpg/220px-Madero_en_Cuernavaca.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Madero_en_Cuernavaca.jpg/330px-Madero_en_Cuernavaca.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e5/Madero_en_Cuernavaca.jpg 2x" data-file-width="425" data-file-height="297" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Madero_en_Cuernavaca.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Francisco_I._Madero" title="Francisco I. Madero">Francisco I. Madero</a> with <a href="/wiki/Emiliano_Zapata" title="Emiliano Zapata">Emiliano Zapata</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Cuernavaca" title="Cuernavaca">Cuernavaca</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a></div></div></div>
<p>President Díaz announced in 1908 that he would retire in 1911, resulting in the development of new coalitions. But then he ran for reelection anyway and in a show of U.S. support, Díaz and <a href="/wiki/William_Howard_Taft" title="William Howard Taft">William Howard Taft</a> planned a summit in El Paso, Texas, and Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, for October 16, 1909, an historic first meeting between a Mexican and a U.S. president and also the first time an American president would cross the border into Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-Harris2009_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harris2009-126">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> Both sides agreed that the disputed <a href="/wiki/Chamizal_dispute" title="Chamizal dispute">Chamizal strip</a> connecting El Paso to Ciudad Juárez would be considered neutral territory with no flags present during the summit, but the meeting focused attention on this territory and resulted in assassination threats and other serious security concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-Harris2009_126-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harris2009-126">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On the day of the summit, <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Russell_Burnham" title="Frederick Russell Burnham">Frederick Russell Burnham</a>, the celebrated scout, and Private C.R. Moore, a <a href="/wiki/Texas_Ranger_Division" title="Texas Ranger Division">Texas Ranger</a>, discovered a man holding a concealed <a href="/wiki/Protector_Palm_Pistol" title="Protector Palm Pistol">palm pistol</a> standing at the El Paso Chamber of Commerce building along the procession route, and they disarmed the assassin within only a few feet of Díaz and Taft.<sup id="cite_ref-Harris2009_126-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harris2009-126">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> Both presidents were unharmed and the summit was held.<sup id="cite_ref-Harris2009_126-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harris2009-126">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> Díaz was re-elected in 1910, but alleged electoral fraud forced him into exile in France and sparked the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">1910 Mexican Revolution</a>, initially led by <a href="/wiki/Francisco_I._Madero" title="Francisco I. Madero">Francisco I. Madero</a>.
</p><p>Madero was elected president but <a href="/wiki/Decena_tr%C3%A1gica" class="mw-redirect" title="Decena trágica">overthrown and murdered</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d&#39;état">coup d'état</a> two years later directed by conservative general <a href="/wiki/Victoriano_Huerta" title="Victoriano Huerta">Victoriano Huerta</a>. That event re-ignited the civil war, involving figures such as <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Villa" class="mw-redirect" title="Francisco Villa">Francisco Villa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Emiliano_Zapata" title="Emiliano Zapata">Emiliano Zapata</a>, who formed their own forces. A third force, the <a href="/wiki/Ej%C3%A9rcito_Constitucionalista" class="mw-redirect" title="Ejército Constitucionalista">constitutional army</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Venustiano_Carranza" title="Venustiano Carranza">Venustiano Carranza</a> managed to bring an end to the war, and radically amended the 1857 Constitution to include many of the social premises and demands of the revolutionaries into what was eventually called the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">1917 Constitution</a>. It is estimated that the war killed 900,000 of the 1910 population of 15 million.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>U.S.interference in the internal affairs of Mexico was notorious. American troops were sent to put down the 1906 <a href="/wiki/Cananea_strike" title="Cananea strike">Cananea strike</a>, and President <a href="/wiki/William_Howard_Taft" title="William Howard Taft">Taft's Administration</a>, U.S. officials often protected investors' interests over helping end the brutalities of the Diaz regime. The U.S. government supported the anti-reelectionist movement, agreed with Bernardo Reyes and Félix Díaz's revolt against Francisco I. Madero, helped the revolutionaries defeat Huerta, and invaded Veracruz in 1914.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup> Following an incursion into <a href="/wiki/Columbus,_New_Mexico" title="Columbus, New Mexico">Columbus, New Mexico</a>, the U.S. sent 10,000 troops led by General <a href="/wiki/John_J._Pershing" title="John J. Pershing">John J. Pershing</a> in an unsuccessful attempt to capture <a href="/wiki/Pancho_Villa_Expedition" title="Pancho Villa Expedition">Pancho Villa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Zimmermann_Telegram" title="Zimmermann Telegram">Zimmermann Telegram</a> of <a href="/wiki/1917_in_Mexico" title="1917 in Mexico">1917</a> involved an attempt by Germany to incite a war between the U.S. and Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As part of his plan to consolidate power, Carranza had peasant-leader <a href="/wiki/Emiliano_Zapata" title="Emiliano Zapata">Emiliano Zapata</a> assassinated in <a href="/wiki/1918_in_Mexico" title="1918 in Mexico">1918</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>312</span></sup> President Carranza was assassinated in <a href="/wiki/1920_in_Mexico" title="1920 in Mexico">1920</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Adolfo_de_la_Huerta" title="Adolfo de la Huerta">Adolfo de la Huerta</a> became interim president, followed by General <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Obreg%C3%B3n" title="Álvaro Obregón">Álvaro Obregón</a>. Obregon instituted land redistribution and pushed public education. <a href="/wiki/Plutarco_El%C3%ADas_Calles" title="Plutarco Elías Calles">Plutarco Elías Calles</a> became president in <a href="/w/index.php?title=1924_in_Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1924 in Mexico (page does not exist)">1924</a>; his goal was to improve the finances of the country by establishing the <i>Banco de Mexico</i> (Bank of Mexico) and the <i>Banco de Credito Ágricola</i> (Agricultural Credit Bank). Calles wanted to enforce the anti-clerical aspects of the 1917 Constitution, sparking the <a href="/wiki/Cristero_War" title="Cristero War">Cristero War</a>, particularly in the western part of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-miranda_112-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miranda-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>327–330</span></sup>
</p><p>Obregon was elected a second time in <a href="/wiki/1928_in_Mexico" title="1928 in Mexico">1928</a>, only to be assassinated two weeks before taking office. This was the period known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Maximato" title="Maximato">Maximato</a>,</i> when Calles dominated Mexican politics as its "Maximum Leader". Calles declared that the Revolution had moved from <i>caudillismo</i> (strongmen) to the <i>era institucional</i> (institutional era). To this end, he founded the "National Revolutionary Party" (PRN), precursor to the <a href="/wiki/Institutional_Revolutionary_Party" title="Institutional Revolutionary Party">Institutional Revolutionary Party</a> that ruled the country as a one-party state for 70 years.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Early-20th-century_stability_and_one-party_rule_.281920.E2.80.932000.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early-20th-century_stability_and_one-party_rule_(1920–2000)">Early-20th-century stability and one-party rule (1920–2000)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Institutional_Revolutionary_Party" title="Institutional Revolutionary Party">Institutional Revolutionary Party</a></div>
<p>In 1929, revolutionary general and former president of Mexico <a href="/wiki/Plutarco_El%C3%ADas_Calles" title="Plutarco Elías Calles">Plutarco Elías Calles</a> founded the National Revolutionary Party (PNR), later renamed the <a href="/wiki/Institutional_Revolutionary_Party" title="Institutional Revolutionary Party">Institutional Revolutionary Party</a> (PRI). Despite not holding the presidency, Calles remained the key political figure during the period known as the <a href="/wiki/Maximato" title="Maximato">Maximato</a> (1929-1934). The Maximato ended during the presidency of <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A1zaro_C%C3%A1rdenas" title="Lázaro Cárdenas">Lázaro Cárdenas</a>, who expelled Calles from the country and implemented many economic and social reforms. This included the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_oil_expropriation" title="Mexican oil expropriation">Mexican oil expropriation</a> in March 1938, which nationalized the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">U.S.</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">Anglo</a>-<a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Dutch</a> oil company known as the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Eagle_Petroleum_Company" title="Mexican Eagle Petroleum Company">Mexican Eagle Petroleum Company</a>. This movement would result in the creation of the state-owned Mexican oil company <a href="/wiki/Pemex" title="Pemex">Pemex</a>. This sparked a diplomatic crisis with the countries whose citizens had lost businesses by Cárdenas's radical measure, but since then the company has played an important role in the economic development of Mexico. Cárdenas's successor, <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Avila_Camacho" class="mw-redirect" title="Manuel Avila Camacho">Manuel Ávila Camacho</a> (1940-1946) was more moderate, and relations between the U.S. and Mexico vastly improved during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, when Mexico was a significant ally, providing manpower and materiel to aid the war effort. In 1946 with the election of <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Alem%C3%A1n_Vald%C3%A9s" title="Miguel Alemán Valdés">Miguel Alemán</a>, the first civilian president in the post-revolutionary period, Mexico embarked on an aggressive program of economic development, known as the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_miracle" title="Mexican miracle">Mexican miracle</a>, which was characterized by industrialization, urbanization, and the increase of inequality in Mexico between urban and rural areas.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Estudiantes_sobre_cammi%C3%B3n_quemado_(A68).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Estudiantes_sobre_cammi%C3%B3n_quemado_%28A68%29.JPG/220px-Estudiantes_sobre_cammi%C3%B3n_quemado_%28A68%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="135" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Estudiantes_sobre_cammi%C3%B3n_quemado_%28A68%29.JPG/330px-Estudiantes_sobre_cammi%C3%B3n_quemado_%28A68%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Estudiantes_sobre_cammi%C3%B3n_quemado_%28A68%29.JPG/440px-Estudiantes_sobre_cammi%C3%B3n_quemado_%28A68%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4512" data-file-height="2772" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Estudiantes_sobre_cammi%C3%B3n_quemado_(A68).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Students in a burned bus during the <a href="/wiki/Tlatelolco_massacre" title="Tlatelolco massacre">protests of 1968</a></div></div></div>
<p>Although the economy continued to flourish for some, <a href="/wiki/Distribution_of_wealth" title="Distribution of wealth">social inequality</a> remained a factor of discontent. Moreover, the PRI rule became increasingly authoritarian and at times oppressive in what is now referred to as 'Mexico's dirty war'<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup> (see the <a href="/wiki/Tlatelolco_massacre" title="Tlatelolco massacre">1968 Tlatelolco massacre</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-MMex_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MMex-135">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> which claimed the life of around 300 protesters based on conservative estimates and as many as 800 by the protesters).<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Electoral reforms and high oil prices followed the administration of <a href="/wiki/Luis_Echeverr%C3%ADa" title="Luis Echeverría">Luis Echeverría</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Crandall_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Crandall-138">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> mismanagement of these revenues led to inflation and exacerbated the <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_debt_crisis" title="Latin American debt crisis">1982 Crisis</a>. That year, <a href="/wiki/1980s_oil_glut" title="1980s oil glut">oil prices plunged</a>, interest rates soared, and the government defaulted on its <a href="/wiki/Debt" title="Debt">debt</a>. <a href="/wiki/Miguel_de_la_Madrid" title="Miguel de la Madrid">President Miguel de la Madrid</a> resorted to currency devaluations which in turn sparked inflation.
</p><p>In the 1980s the first cracks emerged in PRI's dominance. In <a href="/wiki/Baja_California" title="Baja California">Baja California</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ernesto_Ruffo_Appel" title="Ernesto Ruffo Appel">Ernesto Ruffo Appel</a> was elected as governor. In 1988, alleged <a href="/wiki/Electoral_fraud" title="Electoral fraud">electoral fraud</a> prevented the leftist candidate <a href="/wiki/Cuauht%C3%A9moc_C%C3%A1rdenas" title="Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas">Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas</a> from winning the national presidential elections, giving <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Salinas_de_Gortari" title="Carlos Salinas de Gortari">Carlos Salinas de Gortari</a> the presidency and leading to massive protests in <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nafta.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nafta.jpg/220px-Nafta.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nafta.jpg/330px-Nafta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nafta.jpg/440px-Nafta.jpg 2x" data-file-width="715" data-file-height="481" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Nafta.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>NAFTA signing ceremony, October 1992. From left to right: (standing) President <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Salinas_de_Gortari" title="Carlos Salinas de Gortari">Carlos Salinas de Gortari</a> (Mexico), President <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a> (U.S.), and Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Brian_Mulroney" title="Brian Mulroney">Brian Mulroney</a> (Canada); (seated) <a href="/wiki/Jaime_Serra_Puche" title="Jaime Serra Puche">Jaime Serra Puche</a> (Mexico), <a href="/wiki/Carla_Hills" class="mw-redirect" title="Carla Hills">Carla Hills</a> (U.S.), and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Wilson_(Canadian_politician)" title="Michael Wilson (Canadian politician)">Michael Wilson</a> (Canada)</div></div></div>
<p>Salinas embarked on a program of <a href="/wiki/Neoliberalism" title="Neoliberalism">neoliberal</a> reforms which fixed the exchange rate, controlled inflation, and culminated with the signing of the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">North American Free Trade Agreement</a> (NAFTA), which came into effect on January 1, 1994. The same day, the <a href="/wiki/Zapatista_Army_of_National_Liberation" title="Zapatista Army of National Liberation">Zapatista Army of National Liberation</a> (EZLN) started a two-week-long armed rebellion against the federal government, and has continued as a non-violent opposition movement against <a href="/wiki/Neoliberalism" title="Neoliberalism">neoliberalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Globalization" title="Globalization">globalization</a>.
</p><p>In 1994, Salinas was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Ernesto_Zedillo" title="Ernesto Zedillo">Ernesto Zedillo</a>, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_peso_crisis" title="Mexican peso crisis">Mexican peso crisis</a> and a $50 billion <a href="/wiki/IMF" class="mw-redirect" title="IMF">IMF</a> bailout. Major macroeconomic reforms were started by President Zedillo, and the economy rapidly recovered and growth peaked at almost 7% by the end of 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_Mexico">Contemporary Mexico</span></h3>
<p>In 2000, after 71 years, the PRI lost a presidential election to <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Fox" title="Vicente Fox">Vicente Fox</a> of the opposition <a href="/wiki/National_Action_Party_(Mexico)" title="National Action Party (Mexico)">National Action Party</a> (PAN). In the 2006 presidential election, <a href="/wiki/Felipe_Calder%C3%B3n" title="Felipe Calderón">Felipe Calderón</a> from the PAN was declared the winner, with a very narrow margin (0.58%) over leftist politician <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador" title="Andrés Manuel López Obrador">Andrés Manuel López Obrador</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Party_of_the_Democratic_Revolution" title="Party of the Democratic Revolution">Party of the Democratic Revolution</a> (PRD).<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup> López Obrador, however, <a href="/wiki/Controversies_of_the_2006_Mexican_general_election" title="Controversies of the 2006 Mexican general election">contested the election</a> and pledged to create an "alternative government".<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After twelve years, in 2012, the PRI won the presidency again with the election of <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Pe%C3%B1a_Nieto" title="Enrique Peña Nieto">Enrique Peña Nieto</a>, the governor of the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">State of Mexico</a> from 2005 to 2011. However, he won with a plurality of about 38%, and did not have a legislative majority.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In his third presidential run, former mayor of Mexico City Andrés Manuel López Obrador won the 2018 presidential election with over 50% of the vote. His political coalition, led by a left-wing party <a href="/wiki/National_Regeneration_Movement" title="National Regeneration Movement">MORENA</a>, which was founded after the 2012 elections by Andres, includes parties and politicians from all over the political spectrum and also obtained a majority in both the upper and lower congress chambers. AMLO's (one of his many nicknames) success is attributed to the country's other strong political alternatives exhausting their chances as well as the politician adopting a moderate discourse with focus in conciliation.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Mexico" title="Geography of Mexico">Geography of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_topo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Mexico_topo.jpg/280px-Mexico_topo.jpg" decoding="async" width="280" height="184" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Mexico_topo.jpg/420px-Mexico_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Mexico_topo.jpg/560px-Mexico_topo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="922" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_topo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Topographic map of Mexico</div></div></div>
<p>Mexico is located between latitudes <a href="/wiki/14th_parallel_north" title="14th parallel north">14°</a> and <a href="/wiki/33rd_parallel_north" title="33rd parallel north">33°N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/86th_meridian_west" title="86th meridian west">86°</a> and <a href="/wiki/119th_meridian_west" title="119th meridian west">119°W</a> in the southern portion of North America. Almost all of Mexico lies in the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Plate" title="North American Plate">North American Plate</a>, with small parts of the <a href="/wiki/Baja_California_peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Baja California peninsula">Baja California peninsula</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Plate" title="Pacific Plate">Pacific</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cocos_Plate" title="Cocos Plate">Cocos Plates</a>. <a href="/wiki/Geophysics" title="Geophysics">Geophysically</a>, some geographers include the territory east of the <a href="/wiki/Isthmus_of_Tehuantepec" title="Isthmus of Tehuantepec">Isthmus of Tehuantepec</a> (around 12% of the total) within Central America.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Geopolitics" title="Geopolitics">Geopolitically</a>, however, Mexico is entirely considered part of North America, along with Canada and the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yucatan_chix_crater.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Yucatan_chix_crater.jpg/220px-Yucatan_chix_crater.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="246" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Yucatan_chix_crater.jpg/330px-Yucatan_chix_crater.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Yucatan_chix_crater.jpg/440px-Yucatan_chix_crater.jpg 2x" data-file-width="715" data-file-height="799" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Yucatan_chix_crater.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Location in the Yucatán peninsula of the <a href="/wiki/Chicxulub_crater" title="Chicxulub crater">Chicxulub crater</a>. The scientific consensus is that the <a href="/wiki/Chicxulub_impactor" title="Chicxulub impactor">Chicxulub impactor</a> was responsible for the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous%E2%80%93Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event">Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Mexico's total area is 1,972,550&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (761,606&#160;sq&#160;mi), making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area">world's 13th largest country by total area</a>. It has coastlines on the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_California" title="Gulf of California">Gulf of California</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico" title="Gulf of Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a>, the latter two forming part of the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> Within these seas are about 6,000&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (2,317&#160;sq&#160;mi) of islands (including the remote Pacific <a href="/wiki/Guadalupe_Island" title="Guadalupe Island">Guadalupe Island</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Revillagigedo_Islands" title="Revillagigedo Islands">Revillagigedo Islands</a>). From its farthest land points, Mexico is a little over 2,000&#160;mi (3,219&#160;km) in length.
</p><p>On its north, Mexico shares a 3,141&#160;km (1,952&#160;mi) <a href="/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border" title="Mexico–United States border">border with the United States</a>. The meandering <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Bravo_del_Norte" class="mw-redirect" title="Río Bravo del Norte">Río Bravo del Norte</a> (known as the Rio Grande in the United States) defines the border from <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Ju%C3%A1rez" title="Ciudad Juárez">Ciudad Juárez</a> east to the Gulf of Mexico. A series of natural and artificial markers delineate the United States-Mexican border west from Ciudad Juárez to the Pacific Ocean. <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> made the construction of a border wall (on the U.S. side) an element of his 2016 presidential campaign. On its south, Mexico shares an 871&#160;km (541&#160;mi) border with Guatemala and a 251&#160;km (156&#160;mi) border with Belize.
</p><p>Mexico is crossed from north to south by two mountain ranges known as <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Madre_Oriental" title="Sierra Madre Oriental">Sierra Madre Oriental</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Madre_Occidental" title="Sierra Madre Occidental">Sierra Madre Occidental</a>, which are the extension of the <a href="/wiki/Rocky_Mountains" title="Rocky Mountains">Rocky Mountains</a> from northern North America. From east to west at the center, the country is crossed by the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Mexican_Volcanic_Belt" title="Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt">Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt</a> also known as the Sierra Nevada. A fourth mountain range, the <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Madre_del_Sur" title="Sierra Madre del Sur">Sierra Madre del Sur</a>, runs from <a href="/wiki/Michoac%C3%A1n" title="Michoacán">Michoacán</a> to <a href="/wiki/Oaxaca" title="Oaxaca">Oaxaca</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nationsencyclopedia1_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nationsencyclopedia1-148">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As such, the majority of the Mexican central and northern territories are located at high altitudes, and the highest elevations are found at the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt: <a href="/wiki/Pico_de_Orizaba" title="Pico de Orizaba">Pico de Orizaba</a> (5,700&#160;m or 18,701&#160;ft), <a href="/wiki/Popocat%C3%A9petl" title="Popocatépetl">Popocatépetl</a> (5,462&#160;m or 17,920&#160;ft) and <a href="/wiki/Iztaccihuatl" title="Iztaccihuatl">Iztaccihuatl</a> (5,286&#160;m or 17,343&#160;ft) and the <a href="/wiki/Nevado_de_Toluca" title="Nevado de Toluca">Nevado de Toluca</a> (4,577&#160;m or 15,016&#160;ft). Three major urban agglomerations are located in the valleys between these four elevations: <a href="/wiki/Toluca" title="Toluca">Toluca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greater_Mexico_City" title="Greater Mexico City">Greater Mexico City</a> and <a href="/wiki/Puebla,_Puebla" class="mw-redirect" title="Puebla, Puebla">Puebla</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nationsencyclopedia1_148-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nationsencyclopedia1-148">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Mexico" title="Climate of Mexico">Climate of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Mexico_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/280px-Mexico_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="280" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Mexico_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/420px-Mexico_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Mexico_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/560px-Mexico_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="765" data-file-height="765" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mexico map of <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Cancer" title="Tropic of Cancer">Tropic of Cancer</a> effectively divides the country into temperate and tropical zones. Land north of the twenty-fourth parallel experiences cooler temperatures during the winter months. South of the twenty-fourth parallel, temperatures are fairly constant year round and vary solely as a function of elevation. This gives Mexico one of the world's most diverse weather systems.
</p><p>Areas south of the 24th parallel with elevations up to 1,000&#160;m (3,281&#160;ft) (the southern parts of both coastal plains as well as the <a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n_Peninsula" title="Yucatán Peninsula">Yucatán Peninsula</a>), have a yearly median temperature between 24 to 28&#160;°C (75.2 to 82.4&#160;°F). Temperatures here remain high throughout the year, with only a 5&#160;°C (9&#160;°F) difference between winter and summer median temperatures. Both Mexican coasts, except for the south coast of the Bay of Campeche and northern Baja, are also vulnerable to serious <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclone" title="Tropical cyclone">hurricanes</a> during the summer and fall. Although low-lying areas north of the 24th parallel are hot and humid during the summer, they generally have lower yearly temperature averages (from 20 to 24&#160;°C or 68.0 to 75.2&#160;°F) because of more moderate conditions during the winter.
</p><p>Many large cities in Mexico are located in the Valley of Mexico or in adjacent valleys with altitudes generally above 2,000&#160;m (6,562&#160;ft). This gives them a year-round temperate climate with yearly temperature averages (from 16 to 18&#160;°C or 60.8 to 64.4&#160;°F) and cool nighttime temperatures throughout the year.
</p><p>Many parts of Mexico, particularly the north, have a dry climate with sporadic rainfall while parts of the tropical lowlands in the south average more than 2,000&#160;mm (78.7&#160;in) of annual precipitation. For example, many cities in the north like <a href="/wiki/Monterrey" title="Monterrey">Monterrey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hermosillo" title="Hermosillo">Hermosillo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mexicali" title="Mexicali">Mexicali</a> experience temperatures of 40&#160;°C (104&#160;°F) or more in summer. In the <a href="/wiki/Sonoran_Desert" title="Sonoran Desert">Sonoran Desert</a> temperatures reach 50&#160;°C (122&#160;°F) or more.
</p><p>In 2012, Mexico passed a comprehensive climate change bill, a first in the developing world, that has set a goal for the country to generate 35% of its energy from clean energy sources by 2024, and to cut emissions by 50% by 2050, from the level found in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup> During the 2016 <a href="/wiki/North_American_Leaders%27_Summit" title="North American Leaders&#39; Summit">North American Leaders' Summit</a>, the target of 50% of electricity generated from renewable sources by 2025 was announced.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:left;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Chapultepec_Zoo_-_Jaguar_(02).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Chapultepec_Zoo_-_Jaguar_%2802%29.jpg/220px-Chapultepec_Zoo_-_Jaguar_%2802%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Chapultepec_Zoo_-_Jaguar_%2802%29.jpg/330px-Chapultepec_Zoo_-_Jaguar_%2802%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Chapultepec_Zoo_-_Jaguar_%2802%29.jpg/440px-Chapultepec_Zoo_-_Jaguar_%2802%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/Jaguar" title="Jaguar">jaguar</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Chapultepec_Zoo" title="Chapultepec Zoo">Chapultepec Zoo</a>. The zoo is known for its success in breeding programs of <a href="/wiki/Threatened_species" title="Threatened species">threatened species</a>.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexican_wolf_lounging.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Mexican_wolf_lounging.jpg/220px-Mexican_wolf_lounging.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Mexican_wolf_lounging.jpg/330px-Mexican_wolf_lounging.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Mexican_wolf_lounging.jpg/440px-Mexican_wolf_lounging.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1504" data-file-height="1000" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Mexican_wolf" title="Mexican wolf">Mexican wolf</a>.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Axolote.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Axolote.jpg/220px-Axolote.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Axolote.jpg/330px-Axolote.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Axolote.jpg/440px-Axolote.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Axolotl" title="Axolotl">Axolotl</a>, <a href="/wiki/Endemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic">endemic</a> to <a href="/wiki/Valley_of_Mexico" title="Valley of Mexico">Valle de México</a>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Mexico ranks fourth<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> in the world in biodiversity and is one of the 17 <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>. With over 200,000 different species, Mexico is home of 10–12% of the world's biodiversity.<sup id="cite_ref-SEMARNAT_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEMARNAT-153">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> Mexico ranks first in biodiversity in <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptiles</a> with 707 known species, second in mammals with 438 species, fourth in <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibians</a> with 290 species, and fourth in flora, with 26,000 different species.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> Mexico is also considered the second country in the world in <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystems</a> and fourth in overall species.<sup id="cite_ref-SNIB_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SNIB-155">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup> About 2,500 species are protected by Mexican legislations.<sup id="cite_ref-SNIB_155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SNIB-155">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2002<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Mexico had the second fastest rate of deforestation in the world, second only to Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2002_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2002-156">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> The government has taken another initiative in the late 1990s to broaden the people's knowledge, interest and use of the country's esteemed biodiversity, through the <a href="/wiki/Comisi%C3%B3n_Nacional_para_el_Conocimiento_y_Uso_de_la_Biodiversidad" title="Comisión Nacional para el Conocimiento y Uso de la Biodiversidad">Comisión Nacional para el Conocimiento y Uso de la Biodiversidad</a>.
</p><p>In Mexico, 170,000 square kilometres (65,637&#160;sq&#160;mi) are considered "Protected Natural Areas". These include 34 biosphere reserves (unaltered ecosystems), 67 <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Mexico" title="List of national parks of Mexico">national parks</a>, 4 natural monuments (protected in perpetuity for their aesthetic, scientific or historical value), 26 areas of protected flora and fauna, 4 areas for natural resource protection (conservation of soil, hydrological basins and forests) and 17 sanctuaries (zones rich in diverse species).<sup id="cite_ref-SEMARNAT_153-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEMARNAT-153">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The discovery of the Americas brought to the rest of the world many widely used <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">food crops</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edible_plants_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect" title="Edible plants (disambiguation)">edible plants</a>. Some of Mexico's native <a href="/wiki/Culinary_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Culinary art">culinary</a> ingredients include: chocolate, <a href="/wiki/Avocado" title="Avocado">avocado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">tomato</a>, maize, <a href="/wiki/Vanilla" title="Vanilla">vanilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guava" title="Guava">guava</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chayote" title="Chayote">chayote</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dysphania_ambrosioides" title="Dysphania ambrosioides">epazote</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sweet_potato" title="Sweet potato">camote</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%ADcama" class="mw-redirect" title="Jícama">jícama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nopal" title="Nopal">nopal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zucchini" title="Zucchini">zucchini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crataegus_mexicana" title="Crataegus mexicana">tejocote</a>, <a href="/wiki/Corn_smut" title="Corn smut">huitlacoche</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sapote" title="Sapote">sapote</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mamey_sapote" class="mw-redirect" title="Mamey sapote">mamey sapote</a>, many varieties of <a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">beans</a>, and an even greater variety of <a href="/wiki/Chili_pepper" title="Chili pepper">chiles</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Habanero" title="Habanero">habanero</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Jalape%C3%B1o" title="Jalapeño">jalapeño</a>. Most of these names come from indigenous languages like <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a>.
</p><p>Because of its high biodiversity Mexico has also been a frequent site of <a href="/wiki/Bioprospecting" title="Bioprospecting">bioprospecting</a> by international research bodies.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup> The first highly successful instance being the discovery in 1947 of the tuber "<a href="/wiki/Mexican_barbasco_trade" title="Mexican barbasco trade">Barbasco</a>" (<i><a href="/wiki/Dioscorea_composita" title="Dioscorea composita">Dioscorea composita</a></i>) which has a high content of <a href="/wiki/Diosgenin" title="Diosgenin">diosgenin</a>, revolutionizing the production of <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_hormones" class="mw-redirect" title="Synthetic hormones">synthetic hormones</a> in the 1950s and 1960s and eventually leading to the invention of <a href="/wiki/Combined_oral_contraceptive_pill" title="Combined oral contraceptive pill">combined oral contraceptive pills</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_Mexico" title="Federal government of Mexico">Federal government of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador,_presidente_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador%2C_presidente_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg/170px-Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador%2C_presidente_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="218" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador%2C_presidente_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg/255px-Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador%2C_presidente_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/27/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador%2C_presidente_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg 2x" data-file-width="297" data-file-height="381" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador,_presidente_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador" title="Andrés Manuel López Obrador">Andrés Manuel López Obrador</a>, assumed office on December 1, 2018</div></div></div>
<p>The United Mexican States are a federation whose government is <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative</a>, democratic and <a href="/wiki/Republicanism" title="Republicanism">republican</a> based on a presidential system according to the 1917 Constitution. The constitution establishes three levels of government: the federal Union, the state governments and the municipal governments. According to the constitution, all constituent states of the federation must have a republican form of government composed of three branches: the executive, represented by a governor and an appointed cabinet, the legislative branch constituted by a <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_state_legislatures" title="List of Mexican state legislatures">unicameral congress</a> <sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="The material near this tag possibly contains original research. (September 2017)">original research?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> and the judiciary, which will include a state Supreme Court of Justice. They also have their own civil and judicial codes.
</p><p>The federal <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislature</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_the_Union" title="Congress of the Union">Congress of the Union</a>, composed of the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_the_Republic_(Mexico)" title="Senate of the Republic (Mexico)">Senate of the Republic</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Mexico)" title="Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)">Chamber of Deputies</a>. The Congress makes <a href="/wiki/Federal_law" title="Federal law">federal law</a>, declares war, imposes taxes, approves the national budget and international treaties, and ratifies diplomatic appointments.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-160">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The federal Congress, as well as the state legislatures, are elected by a system of <a href="/wiki/Parallel_voting" title="Parallel voting">parallel voting</a> that includes plurality and <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> The Chamber of Deputies has 500 deputies. Of these, 300 are elected by <a href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Plurality voting system">plurality vote</a> in <a href="/wiki/Single-member_district" title="Single-member district">single-member districts</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Federal_electoral_districts_of_Mexico" title="Federal electoral districts of Mexico">federal electoral districts</a>) and 200 are elected by proportional representation with <a href="/wiki/Closed_list" title="Closed list">closed party lists</a><sup id="cite_ref-COFIPE_congreso_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COFIPE_congreso-162">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> for which the country is divided into five electoral constituencies.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> The Senate is made up of 128 senators. Of these, 64 senators (two for each state and two for Mexico City) are elected by plurality vote in pairs; 32 senators are the first minority or first-runner up (one for each state and one for Mexico City), and 32 are elected by proportional representation from national closed party lists.<sup id="cite_ref-COFIPE_congreso_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-COFIPE_congreso-162">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive</a> is the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Mexico" title="President of Mexico">President of the United Mexican States</a>, who is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">government</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the Mexican military forces. The President also appoints the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Executive_Cabinet" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican Executive Cabinet">Cabinet</a> and other officers. The President is responsible for executing and enforcing the law, and has the power to <a href="/wiki/Veto" title="Veto">veto</a> bills.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Suprema4.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Suprema4.jpg/220px-Suprema4.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Suprema4.jpg/330px-Suprema4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Suprema4.jpg/440px-Suprema4.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Suprema4.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Site of the <a href="/wiki/National_Supreme_Court_of_Justice" title="National Supreme Court of Justice">Supreme Court of Justice</a></div></div></div>
<p>The highest organ of the <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial branch</a> of government is the <a href="/wiki/National_Supreme_Court_of_Justice" title="National Supreme Court of Justice">Supreme Court of Justice</a>, the national <a href="/wiki/Supreme_court" title="Supreme court">supreme court</a>, which has eleven judges appointed by the President and approved by the Senate. The Supreme Court of Justice interprets laws and judges cases of federal competency. Other institutions of the judiciary are the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Electoral_Tribunal" title="Federal Electoral Tribunal">Federal Electoral Tribunal</a>, collegiate, unitary and district tribunals, and the Council of the Federal Judiciary.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Mexico" title="Politics of Mexico">Politics of Mexico</a></div>
<p>Three parties have historically been the dominant parties in Mexican politics: the <a href="/wiki/Institutional_Revolutionary_Party" title="Institutional Revolutionary Party">Institutional Revolutionary Party</a> (PRI), a center-left party and member of <a href="/wiki/Socialist_International" title="Socialist International">Socialist International</a><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> that was founded in 1929 to unite all the factions of the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a> and held an almost hegemonic power in Mexican politics since then; the <a href="/wiki/National_Action_Party_(Mexico)" title="National Action Party (Mexico)">National Action Party</a> (PAN), a conservative party founded in 1939 and belonging to the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Democrat_Organization_of_America" title="Christian Democrat Organization of America">Christian Democrat Organization of America</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Party_of_the_Democratic_Revolution" title="Party of the Democratic Revolution">Party of the Democratic Revolution</a> (PRD) a left-wing party,<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup> founded in 1989 as the successor of the coalition of socialists and liberal parties. PRD emerged after what has now been proven was a stolen election in <a href="/wiki/1988_in_Mexico" title="1988 in Mexico">1988</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> and has won numerous state and local elections since then. PAN won its first governorship in <a href="/wiki/1989_in_Mexico" title="1989 in Mexico">1989</a>, and won the presidency in <a href="/wiki/2000_in_Mexico" title="2000 in Mexico">2000</a> and <a href="/wiki/2006_in_Mexico" title="2006 in Mexico">2006</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A new political party, <a href="/wiki/National_Regeneration_Movement" title="National Regeneration Movement">National Regeneration Movement</a> (MORENA), a leftist-populist party, emerged after the <a href="/wiki/2012_in_Mexico" title="2012 in Mexico">2012</a> election and dominated the <a href="/wiki/2018_Mexican_general_election" title="2018 Mexican general election">2018 Mexican general election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">Law enforcement</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Mexico" title="Law enforcement in Mexico">Law enforcement in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:FederalPoliceDF.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/FederalPoliceDF.jpg/170px-FederalPoliceDF.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="302" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/FederalPoliceDF.jpg/255px-FederalPoliceDF.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/FederalPoliceDF.jpg/340px-FederalPoliceDF.jpg 2x" data-file-width="576" data-file-height="1024" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:FederalPoliceDF.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Federal_Police_(Mexico)" title="Federal Police (Mexico)">Federal Police</a> headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a></div></div></div>
<p>Public security is enacted at the three levels of government, each of which has different prerogatives and responsibilities. Local and state police departments are primarily in charge of law enforcement, whereas the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Federal_Police" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican Federal Police">Mexican Federal Police</a> are in charge of specialized duties. All levels report to the Secretaría de Seguridad Pública (Secretary of Public Security). The General Attorney's Office (Procuraduría General de la República, PGR) is the <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive power</a>'s agency in charge of investigating and prosecuting crimes at the federal level, mainly those related to drug and arms trafficking,<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> espionage, and bank robberies.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> The PGR operates the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Ministerial_Police" title="Federal Ministerial Police">Federal Ministerial Police</a> (Policia Federal Ministerial, PMF) an investigative and preventive agency.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup>
