</p><p>While the government generally respects the human rights of its citizens, serious abuses of power have been reported in security operations in the southern part of the country and in indigenous communities and poor urban neighborhoods.<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-175">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> The National Human Rights Commission has had little impact in reversing this trend, engaging mostly in documentation but failing to use its powers to issue public condemnations to the officials who ignore its recommendations.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup> By law, all defendants have the rights that assure them fair trials and humane treatment; however, the system is overburdened and overwhelmed with several problems.<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_175-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-175">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite the efforts of the authorities to fight crime and fraud, most Mexicans have low confidence in the police or the judicial system, and therefore, few crimes are actually reported by the citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_175-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-175">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> The <i>Global Integrity Index</i> which measures the existence and effectiveness of national anti-corruption mechanisms rated Mexico 31st behind Kenya, Thailand, and Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup> In 2008, president Calderón proposed a major reform of the judicial system, which was approved by the Congress of the Union, which included oral trials, the presumption of innocence for defendants, the authority of local police to investigate crime—until then a prerogative of special police units—and several other changes intended to speed up trials.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Crime">Crime</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Mexico" title="Crime in Mexico">Crime in Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Drug_War" title="Mexican Drug War">Mexican Drug War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking_in_Mexico" title="Human trafficking in Mexico">Human trafficking in Mexico</a></div>
<p>Drug cartels are a major concern in Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-Cartel_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cartel-179">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Drug_War" title="Mexican Drug War">Mexico's drug war</a> (2006-2019) left over 120,000 dead and perhaps another 37,000 missing.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> The Mexican <a href="/wiki/Drug_cartel" title="Drug cartel">drug cartels</a> have as many as 100,000 members.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> Mexico's <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_y_Geograf%C3%ADa" class="mw-redirect" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía">National Geography and Statistics Institute</a> estimated that in 2014, one-fifth of Mexicans were victims of some sort of crime.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg/220px-Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg/330px-Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg/440px-Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2288" data-file-height="1520" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ayotz1napa_ohs202.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Demonstration on September 26, 2015, in the first anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/2014_Iguala_mass_kidnapping" title="2014 Iguala mass kidnapping">disappearance of the 43 students</a> in the Mexican town of <a href="/wiki/Iguala" title="Iguala">Iguala</a></div></div></div>
<p>President <a href="/wiki/Felipe_Calder%C3%B3n" title="Felipe Calderón">Felipe Calderón</a> made eradicating organized crime one of the top priorities of his administration by deploying military personnel to cities where drug cartels operate. This move was criticized by the opposition parties and the National Human Rights Commission for escalating the violence,<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> but its effects have been positively evaluated by the US State Department's <a href="/wiki/Bureau_for_International_Narcotics_and_Law_Enforcement_Affairs" class="mw-redirect" title="Bureau for International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs">Bureau for International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs</a> as having obtained "unprecedented results" with "many important successes".<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Since President Felipe Calderón launched a crackdown against cartels in 2006, more than 28,000 alleged criminals have been successfully killed.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> Of the total drug-related violence 4% are innocent people,<sup id="cite_ref-MSNBC_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSNBC-187">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> mostly by-passers and people trapped in between shootings; 90% accounts for criminals and 6% for military personnel and police officers.<sup id="cite_ref-MSNBC_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSNBC-187">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> In October 2007, President Calderón and US president <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> announced the <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida_Initiative" title="Mérida Initiative">Mérida Initiative</a>, a plan of law enforcement cooperation between the two countries.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>More than 100 journalists and <a href="/wiki/List_of_journalists_and_media_workers_killed_in_Mexico" title="List of journalists and media workers killed in Mexico">media workers have been killed or disappeared</a> since 2000, and most of these crimes remained unsolved, improperly investigated, and with few perpetrators arrested and convicted.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/2014_Iguala_mass_kidnapping" title="2014 Iguala mass kidnapping">mass kidnapping</a> of the 43 students in <a href="/wiki/Iguala" title="Iguala">Iguala</a> on September 26, 2014 triggered nationwide protests against the government's weak response to the disappearances and widespread corruption that gives free rein to criminal organizations.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Three_Amigos_2016.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/The_Three_Amigos_2016.jpg/220px-The_Three_Amigos_2016.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/The_Three_Amigos_2016.jpg/330px-The_Three_Amigos_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/The_Three_Amigos_2016.jpg/440px-The_Three_Amigos_2016.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2106" data-file-height="1550" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Three_Amigos_2016.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Former President <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Pe%C3%B1a_Nieto" title="Enrique Peña Nieto">Enrique Peña Nieto</a> with Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Justin_Trudeau" title="Justin Trudeau">Justin Trudeau</a> of Canada and President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> of the United States at the 2016 <a href="/wiki/North_American_Leaders%27_Summit" title="North American Leaders&#39; Summit">North American Leaders' Summit</a></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Mexico" title="Foreign relations of Mexico">Foreign relations of Mexico</a></div>
<p>The foreign relations of Mexico are directed by the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Mexico" title="President of Mexico">President of Mexico</a><sup id="cite_ref-CPEUM89_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CPEUM89-192">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> and managed through the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Mexico)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SRE_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SRE-193">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> The principles of the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy" title="Foreign policy">foreign policy</a> are constitutionally recognized in the Article 89, Section 10, which include: respect for <a href="/wiki/International_law" title="International law">international law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">legal equality of states</a>, their <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Independence" title="Independence">independence</a>, trend to <a href="/wiki/Non-interventionism" title="Non-interventionism">non-interventionism</a> in the domestic affairs of other countries, <a href="/wiki/Dispute_resolution" title="Dispute resolution">peaceful resolution of conflicts</a>, and promotion of <a href="/wiki/International_security" title="International security">collective security</a> through active participation in <a href="/wiki/International_organizations" class="mw-redirect" title="International organizations">international organizations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CPEUM89_192-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CPEUM89-192">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> Since the 1930s, the <a href="/wiki/Estrada_Doctrine" title="Estrada Doctrine">Estrada Doctrine</a> has served as a crucial complement to these principles.<sup id="cite_ref-estradadoctrine_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-estradadoctrine-194">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico is founding member of several international organizations, most notably the United Nations,<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Velázquez_Flores_2007,_p._145_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Velázquez_Flores_2007,_p._145-196">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/OPANAL" title="OPANAL">OPANAL</a><sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Rio_Group" title="Rio Group">Rio Group</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> In 2008, Mexico contributed over 40 million <a href="/wiki/American_dollar" class="mw-redirect" title="American dollar">dollars</a> to the United Nations regular budget.<sup id="cite_ref-unbudget_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unbudget-200">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> In addition, it was the only Latin American member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> since it joined in 1994 until <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> gained  full membership in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico is considered a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a><sup id="cite_ref-regionalpower_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regionalpower-203">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-regionalpower2_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regionalpower2-204">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> hence its presence in major economic groups such as the <a href="/wiki/G8%2B5" title="G8+5">G8+5</a> and the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G-20</a>. In addition, since the 1990s Mexico has sought a <a href="/wiki/Reform_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Reform of the United Nations Security Council">reform of the United Nations Security Council and its working methods</a><sup id="cite_ref-Foreign_Affairs_2005_p._215_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foreign_Affairs_2005_p._215-205">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> with the support of Canada, Italy, Pakistan and other nine countries, which form a group informally called the <a href="/wiki/Coffee_Club" class="mw-redirect" title="Coffee Club">Coffee Club</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-coffeeclub_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-coffeeclub-206">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Independence of Mexico">War of Independence</a>, the relations of Mexico were focused primarily on the United States, its northern neighbor, <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Mexico" title="Economy of Mexico">largest trading partner</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> and the most <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">powerful actor in hemispheric and world affairs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> Mexico supported the <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolution" title="Cuban Revolution">Cuban government</a> since its establishment in the early 1960s,<sup id="cite_ref-keller_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-keller-209">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Sandinista_National_Liberation_Front" title="Sandinista National Liberation Front">Sandinista revolution</a> in Nicaragua during the late 1970s,<sup id="cite_ref-salaverry_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-salaverry-210">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> and leftist revolutionary groups in <a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador">El Salvador</a> during the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-elsalvador_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-elsalvador-211">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Felipe_Calder%C3%B3n" title="Felipe Calderón">Felipe Calderón</a>'s administration (2006-2012) put a greater emphasis on relations with Latin America and the Caribbean.<sup id="cite_ref-Calderon_FP_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Calderon_FP-212">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Pe%C3%B1a_Nieto" title="Enrique Peña Nieto">Enrique Peña Nieto</a> (2012-2018) emphasized economic issues and foreign investment, particularly the now-defunct <a href="/wiki/Trans-Pacific_Partnership" title="Trans-Pacific Partnership">Trans-Pacific Partnership</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador" title="Andrés Manuel López Obrador">Andrés Manuel López Obrador</a> has taken a cautious approach, unwilling to challenge U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> on either trade or migration, while maintaining neutrality on <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_protests_(2014%E2%80%93present)" title="Venezuelan protests (2014–present)">Venezuela</a> and welcoming Chinese money.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Armed_Forces" title="Mexican Armed Forces">Mexican Armed Forces</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg/170px-Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="238" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg/255px-Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg/340px-Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="2100" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Navy" title="Mexican Navy">Mexican Navy</a> <a href="/wiki/Eurocopter" class="mw-redirect" title="Eurocopter">Eurocopter</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Mexican Armed Forces have two branches: the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Army" title="Mexican Army">Mexican Army</a> (which includes the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Air_Force" title="Mexican Air Force">Mexican Air Force</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Navy" title="Mexican Navy">Mexican Navy</a>. The Mexican Armed Forces maintain significant infrastructure, including facilities for design, research, and testing of weapons, vehicles, aircraft, naval vessels, defense systems and electronics;<sup id="cite_ref-impreso.milenio.com_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-impreso.milenio.com-215">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mexican_Naval_missile_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mexican_Naval_missile-216">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> military industry manufacturing centers for building such systems, and advanced naval dockyards that build heavy military vessels and advanced missile technologies.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Marina_Michoac%C3%A1n.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Marina_Michoac%C3%A1n.jpg/220px-Marina_Michoac%C3%A1n.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e4/Marina_Michoac%C3%A1n.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="320" data-file-height="212" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Marina_Michoac%C3%A1n.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mexican built <a href="/wiki/Sierra-class_corvette" title="Sierra-class corvette">Sierra-class corvettes</a></div></div></div>
<p>In recent years, Mexico has improved its training techniques, military command and information structures and has taken steps to becoming more self-reliant in supplying its military by designing as well as manufacturing its own arms,<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> missiles,<sup id="cite_ref-Mexican_Naval_missile_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mexican_Naval_missile-216">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> aircraft,<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> vehicles, heavy weaponry, electronics,<sup id="cite_ref-impreso.milenio.com_215-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-impreso.milenio.com-215">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> defense systems,<sup id="cite_ref-impreso.milenio.com_215-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-impreso.milenio.com-215">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> armor, heavy military industrial equipment and heavy naval vessels.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup> Since the 1990s, when the military escalated its role in the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Drug_War" title="Mexican Drug War">war on drugs</a>, increasing importance has been placed on acquiring airborne surveillance platforms, aircraft, <a href="/wiki/Helicopters" class="mw-redirect" title="Helicopters">helicopters</a>, digital war-fighting technologies,<sup id="cite_ref-impreso.milenio.com_215-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-impreso.milenio.com-215">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> urban warfare equipment and rapid troop transport.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico has the capabilities to manufacture nuclear weapons, but abandoned this possibility with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tlatelolco" title="Treaty of Tlatelolco">Treaty of Tlatelolco</a> in 1968 and pledged to only use its nuclear technology for peaceful purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> In 1970, Mexico's national institute for nuclear research successfully refined weapons grade uranium<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (March 2011)">failed verification</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> which is used in the manufacture of nuclear weapons but in April 2010, Mexico agreed to turn over its weapons grade uranium to the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, Mexico has remained neutral in international conflicts,<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mexico_in_World_War_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexico in World War II">with the exception of World War II</a>. However, in recent years some political parties have proposed an amendment of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">Constitution</a> to allow the Mexican Army, Air Force or Navy to collaborate with the United Nations in <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping missions</a>, or to provide military help to countries that officially ask for it.<sup id="cite_ref-neutral_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-neutral-227">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup> Mexico signed the UN treaty on the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Mexico" title="Administrative divisions of Mexico">Administrative divisions of Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/States_of_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="States of Mexico">States of Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Mexico" title="Municipalities of Mexico">Municipalities of Mexico</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_state_legislatures" title="List of Mexican state legislatures">List of Mexican state legislatures</a></div>
<p>The United Mexican States are a federation of 31 free and sovereign states, which form a union that exercises a degree of jurisdiction over <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-thought_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thought-229">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Each state has its own constitution, <a href="/wiki/Congress" title="Congress">congress</a>, and a judiciary, and its citizens elect by <a href="/wiki/Direct_vote" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct vote">direct voting</a> a <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_state_governors" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Mexican state governors">governor</a> for a six-year term, and representatives to their respective unicameral state congresses for three-year terms.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico City is a special political division that belongs to the federation as a whole and not to a particular state.<sup id="cite_ref-thought_229-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thought-229">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> Formerly known as the Federal District, its autonomy was previously limited relative to that of the states.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> It dropped this designation in 2016 and is in the process of achieving greater political autonomy by becoming a federal entity with <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Assembly_of_Mexico_City" title="Constitutional Assembly of Mexico City">its own constitution</a> and congress.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The states are divided into <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Mexico" title="Municipalities of Mexico">municipalities</a>, the smallest administrative political entity in the country, governed by a <a href="/wiki/Mayor" title="Mayor">mayor or municipal president</a> (<i lang="es" title="Spanish language text">presidente municipal</i>), elected by its residents by plurality.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><div role="img" class="noresize" style="width: 600px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><a href="/wiki/File:Division_politica_mexico.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Division_politica_mexico.svg/600px-Division_politica_mexico.svg.png" decoding="async" width="600" height="404" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Division_politica_mexico.svg/900px-Division_politica_mexico.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Division_politica_mexico.svg/1200px-Division_politica_mexico.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="460" data-file-height="310" /></a>

<td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flag_of_Sonora.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sonora.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flag_of_Sonora.svg/35px-Flag_of_Sonora.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flag_of_Sonora.svg/46px-Flag_of_Sonora.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="350" data-file-height="200" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Sonora" title="Sonora">Sonora (SON)</a>
</td>

</td></tr>

<td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Flag_of_Michoacan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Michoacan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Flag_of_Michoacan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Michoacan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Flag_of_Michoacan.svg/46px-Flag_of_Michoacan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="350" data-file-height="200" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Michoac%C3%A1n" title="Michoacán">Michoacán (MICH)</a>

<td><a href="/wiki/Zacatecas_City" title="Zacatecas City">Zacatecas</a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Mexico" title="Economy of Mexico">Economy of Mexico</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Mexico" title="Economic history of Mexico">Economic history of Mexico</a></div>
<table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px">
<tbody><tr>
<th style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;" colspan="2">Share of world GDP (PPP)<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th style="background:#cfb;">Year
</th>
<th style="background:#cfb;">Share
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">1980</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">3.06%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">1990</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">2.68%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>2000
</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">2.53%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>2010
</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">2.02%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;">2017</td>
<td style="text-align:right;">1.94%
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg/330px-Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg" decoding="async" width="330" height="257" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg/495px-Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg/660px-Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1107" data-file-height="862" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexico_Product_Export_Treemap.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Mexico's exports. The country has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_economic_complexity" title="List of countries by economic complexity">most complex economy</a> in Latin America.</div></div></div>
<p>As of April 2018, Mexico has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">15th largest</a> nominal GDP (US$1.15 trillion)<sup id="cite_ref-invest_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-invest-235">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">11th largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (US$2.45 trillion). GDP annual average growth was 2.9% in 2016 and 2% in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-invest_235-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-invest-235">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> Agriculture has comprised 4% of the economy over the last two decades, while industry contributes 33% (mostly automotive, oil, and electronics) and services (notably financial services and tourism) contribute 63%.<sup id="cite_ref-invest_235-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-invest-235">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> Mexico's GDP in PPP per capita was US$18,714.05. The World Bank reported in 2009 that the country's <a href="/wiki/Gross_National_Income" class="mw-redirect" title="Gross National Income">Gross National Income</a> in market exchange rates was the second highest in Latin America, after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> at US$1,830.392&#160;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-GNI_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GNI-236">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> which led to the highest <a href="/wiki/Gross_National_Income" class="mw-redirect" title="Gross National Income">income per capita</a> in the region at $15,311.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GNIPC_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GNIPC-238">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> Mexico is now firmly established as an upper middle-income country. After the slowdown of 2001 the country has recovered and has grown 4.2, 3.0 and 4.8 percent in 2004, 2005 and 2006,<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> even though it is considered to be well below Mexico's potential growth.<sup id="cite_ref-Hufbauer_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hufbauer-240">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> predicts growth rates of 2.3% and 2.7% for 2018 and 2019, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-invest_235-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-invest-235">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the report <i>Under pressure: the reduction of the middle class</i>, the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)</a> reports that on average 45% of the population in Mexico is middle class<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> while according to Mexico's <a href="/wiki/National_Council_for_the_Evaluation_of_Social_Development_Policy_(CONEVAL)" title="National Council for the Evaluation of Social Development Policy (CONEVAL)">National Council for the Evaluation of Social Development Policy</a> (CONEVAL) from 2006 to 2010 the portion of the population who lives in poverty rose from 18%-19%<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup> to 46% (52 million people).<sup id="cite_ref-CONEVAL_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CONEVAL-243">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup> However, rather than Mexico's economy crashing, international economists attribute the huge increase in the percentage of population living below the country's poverty line to the CONEVAL using new standards to define it, as now besides people who lives below the economic welfare line, people who lacks at least one "social need" such as complete education, access to healthcare, access to regular food, housing services and goods, social security etc. were considered to be living in poverty (several countries do collect information regarding the persistence of said vulnerabilities on their population, but Mexico is the only one that classifies people lacking one or more of those needs as living below its national poverty line). Said economists do point out that the percentage of people living in poverty according to Mexico's national poverty line is around 40 times higher than the one reported by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank's</a> international poverty line (with said difference being the biggest in the world) and ponder if it wouldn't be better for countries in the situation of Mexico to adopt internationalized standards to measure poverty so the numbers obtained could be used to make accurate international comparisons.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a>'s own poverty line (defined as the percentage of a country's population who earns 60%<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> or less of the national median income) 20% of Mexico's population lives in a situation of poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Among the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> countries, Mexico has the second highest degree of economic disparity between the extremely poor and extremely rich, after Chile&#160;– although it has been falling over the last decade, being one of few countries in which this is the case.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> The bottom ten percent in the income hierarchy disposes of 1.36% of the country's resources, whereas the upper ten percent dispose of almost 36%. The OECD also notes that Mexico's budgeted expenses for poverty alleviation and social development is only about a third of the OECD average.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDREFORMA_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDREFORMA-248">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> This is also reflected by the fact that infant mortality in Mexico is three times higher than the average among OECD nations whereas its literacy levels are in the median range of OECD nations. Nevertheless, according to <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a>, by 2050 Mexico will have the 5th largest economy in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a 2008 UN report the average income in a typical urbanized area of Mexico was $26,654, while the average income in rural areas just miles away was only $8,403.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> Daily minimum wages are set annually being set at $102.68 <a href="/wiki/Mexican_peso" title="Mexican peso">Mexican pesos</a> (US$5.40) in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The electronics industry of Mexico has grown enormously within the last decade. Mexico has the sixth largest electronics industry in the world after <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. Mexico is the second-largest exporter of electronics to the United States where it exported $71.4 billion worth of electronics in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-prnewswire.com_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prnewswire.com-252">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> The Mexican electronics industry is dominated by the manufacture and OEM design of televisions, displays, computers, mobile phones, circuit boards, semiconductors, electronic appliances, communications equipment and LCD modules. The Mexican electronics industry grew 20% between 2010 and 2011, up from its constant growth rate of 17% between 2003 and 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-prnewswire.com_252-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prnewswire.com-252">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> Currently electronics represent 30% of Mexico's exports.<sup id="cite_ref-prnewswire.com_252-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prnewswire.com-252">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico produces the most automobiles of any North American nation.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> The industry produces technologically complex components and engages in some research and development activities.<sup id="cite_ref-Gereffi_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gereffi-254">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> The "Big Three" (<a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ford" class="mw-redirect" title="Ford">Ford</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chrysler" title="Chrysler">Chrysler</a>) have been operating in Mexico since the 1930s, while <a href="/wiki/Volkswagen" title="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nissan" title="Nissan">Nissan</a> built their plants in the 1960s.<sup id="cite_ref-Hufbauer_Auto_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hufbauer_Auto-255">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Puebla,_Puebla" class="mw-redirect" title="Puebla, Puebla">Puebla</a> alone, 70 industrial part-makers cluster around Volkswagen.<sup id="cite_ref-Gereffi_254-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gereffi-254">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> In the 2010s expansion of the sector was surging. In 2014 alone, more than $10 billion in investment was committed. In September 2016 Kia motors opened a $1 billion factory in <a href="/wiki/Nuevo_Le%C3%B3n" title="Nuevo León">Nuevo León</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> with Audi also opening an assembling plant in Puebla the same year.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nissan" title="Nissan">Nissan</a> currently have plants in constructuion.<sup id="cite_ref-KiaMexico_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KiaMexico-258">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The domestic car industry is represented by <a href="/wiki/DINA_S.A." title="DINA S.A.">DINA S.A.</a>, which has built buses and trucks since 1962,<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> and the new <a href="/wiki/Mastretta" title="Mastretta">Mastretta</a> company that builds the high-performance <a href="/wiki/Mastretta_MXT" title="Mastretta MXT">Mastretta MXT</a> sports car.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> In 2006, trade with the United States and Canada accounted for almost 50% of Mexico's exports and 45% of its imports.<sup id="cite_ref-cia.gov_13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> During the first three quarters of 2010, the United States had a $46.0 billion <a href="/wiki/Trade_deficit" class="mw-redirect" title="Trade deficit">trade deficit</a> with Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup> In August 2010 Mexico surpassed France to become the 9th largest holder of US debt.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> The commercial and financial dependence on the US is a cause for concern.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The remittances from Mexican citizens working in the United States account for 0.2% of Mexico's GDP<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup> which was equal to US$20 billion per year in 2004 and is the tenth largest source of foreign income after oil, industrial exports, manufactured goods, electronics, heavy industry, automobiles, construction, food, banking and financial services.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> According to Mexico's central bank, remittances in 2008 amounted to $25bn.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>By 2050, Mexico could potentially become the world's fifth or seventh largest economy.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communications">Communications</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Mexico" title="Telecommunications in Mexico">Telecommunications in Mexico</a></div>
<p>The telecommunications industry is mostly dominated by <a href="/wiki/Telmex" title="Telmex">Telmex</a> (<i>Teléfonos de México</i>), privatized in 1990. By 2006, Telmex had expanded its operations to Colombia, Peru, Chile, Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay, and the United States. Other players in the domestic industry are <a href="/wiki/Axtel" title="Axtel">Axtel</a>, Maxcom, Alestra, Marcatel, AT&amp;T Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-budde_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-budde-269">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup> Because of Mexican <a href="/wiki/Orography" title="Orography">orography</a>, providing a landline telephone service at remote mountainous areas is expensive, and the penetration of line-phones per capita is low compared to other Latin American countries, at 40 percent; however, 82% of Mexicans over the age of 14 own a mobile phone. Mobile telephony has the advantage of reaching all areas at a lower cost, and the total number of mobile lines is almost two times that of landlines, with an estimation of 63 million lines.<sup id="cite_ref-ciacom_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciacom-270">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> The telecommunication industry is regulated by the government through <a href="/wiki/Cofetel" class="mw-redirect" title="Cofetel">Cofetel</a> (<i>Comisión Federal de Telecomunicaciones</i>).
</p><p>The Mexican satellite system is domestic and operates 120 earth stations. There is also extensive microwave radio relay network and considerable use of fiber-optic and coaxial cable.<sup id="cite_ref-ciacom_270-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciacom-270">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> Mexican satellites are operated by <i>Satélites Mexicanos</i> (<a href="/wiki/Satmex" title="Satmex">Satmex</a>), a private company, leader in Latin America and servicing both North and South America.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> It offers broadcast, telephone and telecommunication services to 37 countries in the Americas, from Canada to <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>. Through business partnerships Satmex provides high-speed connectivity to ISPs and Digital Broadcast Services.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup> Satmex maintains its own satellite fleet with most of the fleet being designed and built in Mexico.
</p><p>Major players in the broadcasting industry are <a href="/wiki/Televisa" title="Televisa">Televisa</a>, the largest Mexican media company in the Spanish-speaking world,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-273">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/TV_Azteca" title="TV Azteca">TV Azteca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Imagen_Televisi%C3%B3n" title="Imagen Televisión">Imagen Televisión</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Mexico" title="Electricity sector in Mexico">Electricity sector in Mexico</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I,_Fase_II.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg/200px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg/300px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg/400px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_Central_E%C3%B3lica_Sureste_I%2C_Fase_II.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1654" data-file-height="1104" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The Central Eólica Sureste I, Fase II in Oaxaca. The Isthmus of Tehuantepec is the region of Mexico with the highest capacity for wind energy. (see <i><a href="/wiki/Tehuantepecer" title="Tehuantepecer">Tehuantepecer</a></i>, a strong wind that affects the region)</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_la_Central_Geotermoel%C3%A9ctrica_Azufres_III,_Fase_1._(21526244958).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_la_Central_Geotermoel%C3%A9ctrica_Azufres_III%2C_Fase_1._%2821526244958%29.jpg/200px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_la_Central_Geotermoel%C3%A9ctrica_Azufres_III%2C_Fase_1._%2821526244958%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_la_Central_Geotermoel%C3%A9ctrica_Azufres_III%2C_Fase_1._%2821526244958%29.jpg/300px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_la_Central_Geotermoel%C3%A9ctrica_Azufres_III%2C_Fase_1._%2821526244958%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_la_Central_Geotermoel%C3%A9ctrica_Azufres_III%2C_Fase_1._%2821526244958%29.jpg/400px-Inauguraci%C3%B3n_de_la_Central_Geotermoel%C3%A9ctrica_Azufres_III%2C_Fase_1._%2821526244958%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5520" data-file-height="3680" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The Central Geotermoeléctrica Azufres III in Michoacán. 100% of the electricity produced in Michoacán comes from renewable sources.<sup id="cite_ref-Geothermal_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geothermal-274">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> 90% comes from <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_plants" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydroelectric plants">hydroelectric plants</a>, and 10% from the Azufres <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_energy" title="Geothermal energy">Geothermal</a> Field.<sup id="cite_ref-Geothermal_274-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geothermal-274">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Energy production in Mexico is managed by the state-owned companies <a href="/wiki/Comisi%C3%B3n_Federal_de_Electricidad" title="Comisión Federal de Electricidad">Federal Commission of Electricity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pemex" title="Pemex">Pemex</a>.
</p><p>Pemex, the public company in charge of exploration, extraction, transportation and marketing of crude oil and natural gas, as well as the refining and distribution of petroleum products and petrochemicals, is one of the largest companies in the world by revenue, making US$86 billion in sales a year.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fortune_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortune-276">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> Mexico is the sixth-largest oil producer in the world, with 3.7 million barrels per day.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup> In 1980 oil exports accounted for 61.6% of total exports; by 2000 it was only 7.3%.<sup id="cite_ref-Gereffi_254-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gereffi-254">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The largest hydro plant in Mexico is the 2,400 MW <a href="/wiki/Chicoas%C3%A9n_Dam" title="Chicoasén Dam">Manuel Moreno Torres Dam</a> in Chicoasén, <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">Chiapas</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Grijalva_River" title="Grijalva River">Grijalva River</a>. This is the world's fourth most productive hydroelectric plant.<sup id="cite_ref-EIA_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EIA-279">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico is the country with the world's third largest solar potential.<sup id="cite_ref-S&amp;G_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-S&amp;G-280">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> The country's gross solar potential is estimated at 5kWh/m2 daily, which corresponds to 50 times national electricity generation.<sup id="cite_ref-ER_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ER-281">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> Currently, there is over 1 million square meters of <a href="/wiki/Solar_thermal" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar thermal">solar thermal</a> panels<sup id="cite_ref-SENER_2009b_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SENER_2009b-282">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> installed in Mexico, while in 2005, there were 115,000 square meters of <a href="/wiki/Solar_PV" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar PV">solar PV</a> (photo-voltaic). It is expected that in 2012 there will be 1,8 million square meters of installed solar thermal panels.<sup id="cite_ref-SENER_2009b_282-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SENER_2009b-282">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The project named <a href="/wiki/SEGH-CFE_1" title="SEGH-CFE 1">SEGH-CFE 1</a>, located in Puerto Libertad, Sonora, Northwest of Mexico, will have capacity of 46.8 MW from an array of 187,200 solar panels when complete in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-Sonora_Energy_Group_Hermosillo_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sonora_Energy_Group_Hermosillo-283">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> All of the electricity will be sold directly to the CFE and absorbed into the utility's transmission system for distribution throughout their existing network. At an installed capacity of 46.8 MWp, when complete in 2013, the project will be the first utility scale project of its kind in Mexico and the largest solar project of any kind in Latin America.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_Mexico" title="History of science and technology in Mexico">History of science and technology in Mexico</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a> was officially established in 1910,<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup> and the university became one of the most important institutes of higher learning in Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-page285_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-page285-285">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> UNAM provides world class education in science, medicine, and engineering.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup> Many scientific institutes and new institutes of higher learning, such as <a href="/wiki/National_Polytechnic_Institute" class="mw-redirect" title="National Polytechnic Institute">National Polytechnic Institute</a> (founded in 1936),<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup> were established during the first half of the 20th century. Most of the new research institutes were created within UNAM. Twelve institutes were integrated into UNAM from 1929 to 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-page18_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-page18-288">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup> In 1959, the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Mexican Academy of Sciences">Mexican Academy of Sciences</a> was created to coordinate scientific efforts between academics.
</p><p>In 1995, the Mexican chemist <a href="/wiki/Mario_J._Molina" title="Mario J. Molina">Mario J. Molina</a> shared the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> with <a href="/wiki/Paul_J._Crutzen" title="Paul J. Crutzen">Paul J. Crutzen</a> and <a href="/wiki/F._Sherwood_Rowland" title="F. Sherwood Rowland">F. Sherwood Rowland</a> for their work in atmospheric chemistry, particularly concerning the formation and decomposition of ozone.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup> Molina, an alumnus of UNAM, became the first Mexican citizen to win the Nobel Prize in science.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, the largest scientific project being developed in Mexico was the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Large_Millimeter_Telescope" title="Large Millimeter Telescope">Large Millimeter Telescope</a> (Gran Telescopio Milimétrico, GMT), the world's largest and most sensitive single-aperture telescope in its frequency range.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup> It was designed to observe regions of space obscured by stellar dust.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Mexico" title="Tourism in Mexico">Tourism in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Calle_del_centro_de_morelia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Calle_del_centro_de_morelia.jpg/220px-Calle_del_centro_de_morelia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Calle_del_centro_de_morelia.jpg/330px-Calle_del_centro_de_morelia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Calle_del_centro_de_morelia.jpg/440px-Calle_del_centro_de_morelia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="685" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Calle_del_centro_de_morelia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Street in the historic center of <a href="/wiki/Morelia" title="Morelia">Morelia</a>. Mexico has historical architecture in most of its towns being the country with the highest number of Colonial buildings and structures in all of the Americas and also placing a vast number of Pre-colonial landmarks.</div></div></div>
<p>Mexico has traditionally been among the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">most visited countries in the world</a> according to the World Tourism Organization and it is the most visited country in the Americas after the United States. The most notable attractions are the <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican" class="mw-redirect" title="Mesoamerican">Mesoamerican</a> ruins, cultural festivals, colonial cities, nature reserves and the beach resorts. The nation's wide range of climates, from temperate to tropical, and unique culture – a fusion of the European and the Mesoamerican – make Mexico an attractive destination. The peak tourism seasons in the country are during December and the mid-Summer, with brief surges during the week before <a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">Easter</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spring_break" title="Spring break">Spring break</a>, when many of the beach resort sites become popular destinations for college students from the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:20_de_noviembre_de_zapopan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="November 20th Way in Zapopan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/20_de_noviembre_de_zapopan.jpg/220px-20_de_noviembre_de_zapopan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/20_de_noviembre_de_zapopan.jpg/330px-20_de_noviembre_de_zapopan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/20_de_noviembre_de_zapopan.jpg/440px-20_de_noviembre_de_zapopan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4160" data-file-height="3120" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:20_de_noviembre_de_zapopan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>November 20th Way in <a href="/wiki/Zapopan" title="Zapopan">Zapopan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jalisco" title="Jalisco">Jalisco</a></div></div></div> 
<p>As of 2017, Mexico was the 6th most visited country in the world and  had the 15th highest income from tourism in the world which is also the highest in Latin America.<sup id="cite_ref-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2018_Edition_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2018_Edition-292">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup> The vast majority of tourists come to Mexico from the United States and Canada followed by Europe and Asia. A smaller number also come from other Latin American countries.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup> In the 2017 <a href="/wiki/Travel_and_Tourism_Competitiveness_Report" title="Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report">Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report</a>, Mexico was ranked 22nd in the world, which was 3rd in the Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The coastlines of Mexico harbor many stretches of beaches that are frequented by sunbathers and other visitors. <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico#Article_27" title="Constitution of Mexico">According to national law</a>, the entirety of the coastlines are under federal ownership, that is, all beaches in the country are <a href="/wiki/Public_property" title="Public property">public</a>. On the Yucatán peninsula, one of the most popular beach destinations is the resort town of <a href="/wiki/Canc%C3%BAn" title="Cancún">Cancún</a>, especially among <a href="/wiki/University" title="University">university</a> <a href="/wiki/Student" title="Student">students</a> during <a href="/wiki/Spring_break" title="Spring break">spring break</a>. Just offshore is the beach island of <a href="/wiki/Isla_Mujeres" title="Isla Mujeres">Isla Mujeres</a>, and to the east is the <a href="/wiki/Isla_Holbox" title="Isla Holbox">Isla Holbox</a>. To the south of Cancun is the coastal strip called <a href="/wiki/Riviera_Maya" title="Riviera Maya">Riviera Maya</a> which includes the beach town of <a href="/wiki/Playa_del_Carmen" title="Playa del Carmen">Playa del Carmen</a> and the ecological parks of <a href="/wiki/Xcaret" title="Xcaret">Xcaret</a> and Xel-Há. A day trip to the south of Cancún is the historic port of <a href="/wiki/Tulum" title="Tulum">Tulum</a>. In addition to its beaches, the town of Tulum is notable for its cliff-side <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Mayan</a> ruins.
</p><p>On the <a href="/wiki/Pacific" class="mw-redirect" title="Pacific">Pacific</a> coast is the notable tourist destination of <a href="/wiki/Acapulco" title="Acapulco">Acapulco</a>. Once the destination for the rich and famous, the beaches have become crowded and the shores are now home to many multi-story hotels and vendors. Acapulco is home to renowned cliff divers: trained divers who leap from the side of a vertical cliff into the surf below.
</p><p>At the southern tip of the <a href="/wiki/Baja_California_peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Baja California peninsula">Baja California peninsula</a> is the resort town of <a href="/wiki/Cabo_San_Lucas" title="Cabo San Lucas">Cabo San Lucas</a>, a town noted for its beaches and <a href="/wiki/Marlin" title="Marlin">marlin</a> <a href="/wiki/Fishing" title="Fishing">fishing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup> Further north along the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Cort%C3%A9s" class="mw-redirect" title="Sea of Cortés">Sea of Cortés</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%ADa_Concepci%C3%B3n,_Baja_California_Sur" title="Bahía Concepción, Baja California Sur">Bahía de La Concepción</a>, another beach town known for its sports fishing. Closer to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> border is the weekend draw of <a href="/wiki/San_Felipe,_Baja_California" title="San Felipe, Baja California">San Felipe, Baja California</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Mexico" title="Transportation in Mexico">Transportation in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Puente_Baluarte,_Mexico6.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico6.jpg/220px-Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico6.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="330" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico6.jpg/330px-Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico6.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico6.jpg/440px-Puente_Baluarte%2C_Mexico6.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3744" data-file-height="5616" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Puente_Baluarte,_Mexico6.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Baluarte_Bridge" title="Baluarte Bridge">Baluarte Bridge</a> is the highest cable-stayed bridge in the world, the fifth-highest bridge overall and the highest bridge in the Americas.</div></div></div>
<p>The roadway network in Mexico is extensive and all areas in the country are covered by it.<sup id="cite_ref-nations_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nations-296">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup> The roadway network in Mexico has an extent of 366,095&#160;km (227,481&#160;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-sctroad_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sctroad-297">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> of which 116,802&#160;km (72,577&#160;mi) are paved,<sup id="cite_ref-sctroad-2_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sctroad-2-298">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup> making it the largest paved-roadway network in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup> Of these, 10,474&#160;km (6,508&#160;mi) are multi-lane <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">expressways</a>: 9,544&#160;km (5,930&#160;mi) are four-lane highways and the rest have 6 or more lanes.<sup id="cite_ref-sctroad-2_298-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sctroad-2-298">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico was one of the first Latin American countries to promote railway development,<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_175-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-175">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> and the network covers 30,952&#160;km (19,233&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-encnations_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encnations-300">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_Communications_and_Transportation_(Mexico)" title="Secretariat of Communications and Transportation (Mexico)">Secretary of Communications and Transport</a> of Mexico proposed a high-speed rail link that will transport its passengers from <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a> to <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jalisco" title="Jalisco">Jalisco</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-azcentral.com_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-azcentral.com-301">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup> The train, which will travel at 300 kilometres per hour (190 miles per hour),<sup id="cite_ref-systra.com_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-systra.com-303">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> will allow passengers to travel from Mexico City to Guadalajara in just 2&#160;hours.<sup id="cite_ref-systra.com_303-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-systra.com-303">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> The whole project was projected to cost 240&#160;billion <a href="/wiki/MXN" class="mw-redirect" title="MXN">pesos</a>, or about 25&#160;billion US$<sup id="cite_ref-azcentral.com_301-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-azcentral.com-301">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup> and is being paid for jointly by the Mexican government and the local private sector including the wealthiest man in the world, Mexico's billionaire business tycoon <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Slim" title="Carlos Slim">Carlos Slim</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup> The government of the state of <a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Yucatán">Yucatán</a> is also funding the construction of a high speed line connecting the cities of <a href="/wiki/Cozumel" title="Cozumel">Cozumel</a> to <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida,_Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Mérida, Yucatán">Mérida</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chichen_Itza" title="Chichen Itza">Chichen Itza</a> and Cancún.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico has 233 airports with paved runways; of these, 35 carry 97% of the passenger traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-encnations_300-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encnations-300">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_International_Airport" title="Mexico City International Airport">Mexico City International Airport</a> remains the busiest in Latin America and the 36th busiest in the world<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup> transporting 45 million passengers a year.<sup id="cite_ref-aicmstats_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aicmstats-307">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Mexico" title="Water supply and sanitation in Mexico">Water supply and sanitation in Mexico</a></div>
<p>Among the achievements is a significant increase in access to piped water supply in urban areas (88% to 93%) as well as in rural areas (50% to 74%) between 1990 and 2010. Additionally, a strong nationwide increase in access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">improved sanitation</a> (64% to 85%) was observed in the same period. Other achievements include the existence of a functioning national system to finance water and sanitation infrastructure with a National Water Commission as its apex institution; and the existence of a few well-performing utilities such as Aguas y Drenaje de Monterrey.
</p><p>The challenges include water scarcity in the northern and central parts of the country; inadequate water service quality (drinking water quality; 11% of Mexicans receiving water only intermittently as of 2014);<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup> poor technical and commercial efficiency of most utilities (with an average level of <a href="/wiki/Non-revenue_water" title="Non-revenue water">non-revenue water</a> of 43.2% in 2010);<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup> an insufficient share of wastewater receiving treatment (36% in 2006); and still inadequate access in rural areas. In addition to on-going investments to expand access, the government has embarked on a large investment program to improve wastewater treatment.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Mexico" title="Demographics of Mexico">Demographics of Mexico</a></div>
<table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 0.5em;"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="3" style="padding:0.25em;font-size:110%">Historical population</th></tr><tr style="font-size:95%"><th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;width:3em">Year</th><th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px 2px;text-align:right"><abbr title="Population">Pop.</abbr></th><th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;text-align:right"><abbr title="Percent change">±%</abbr></th></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1910 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">15,160,369</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">—&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1921 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">14,334,780</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">−5.4%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1940 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">19,653,552</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+37.1%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1960 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">34,923,129</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+77.7%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">1980 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">66,846,833</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+91.4%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2000 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">97,483,412</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+45.8%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2015 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">121,005,816</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+24.1%</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">Source: <a href="/wiki/INEGI" class="mw-redirect" title="INEGI">INEGI</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Throughout the 19th century, the population of Mexico had barely doubled. This trend continued during the first two decades of the 20th century, and even in the 1920 census there was a loss of about 2 million inhabitants. The phenomenon can be explained because during the decade from 1910 to 1920 the Mexican Revolution took place.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexicopop.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Mexicopop.svg/220px-Mexicopop.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Mexicopop.svg/330px-Mexicopop.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Mexicopop.svg/440px-Mexicopop.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mexicopop.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population pyramid 2017</div></div></div>
<p>The growth rate increased dramatically between the 1930s and the 1980s, when the country registered growth rates of over 3% (1950–1980). The Mexican population doubled in twenty years, and at that rate it was expected that by the year 2000 there would be 120 million Mexicans. Life expectancy went from 36 years (in 1895) to 72 years (in the year 2000).
</p><p>According to estimations made by Mexico's <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_y_Geograf%C3%ADa" class="mw-redirect" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía">National Geography and Statistics Institute</a>, as of 2017 Mexico has 123.5 million inhabitants<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup> making it the most populous Spanish-speaking country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Spanishhistory_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spanishhistory-311">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> Between 2005 and 2010, the Mexican population grew at an average of 1.70% per year, up from 1.16% per year between 2000 and 2005.
</p><p>Even though Mexico is a very ethnically diverse country, research about ethnicity has largely been a forgotten field, in consequence of the post-revolutionary efforts of Mexico's government to unify all non-indigenous Mexicans under a single ethnic identity (that of the "Mestizo"). As a result, since 1930 the only explicit ethnic classification that has been included in Mexican censuses has been that of "Indigenous peoples".<sup id="cite_ref-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES-312">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup> Even then, across the years the government has used different criteria to count Indigenous peoples, with each of them returning considerably different numbers. It is not until very recently that the Mexican government begun conducting surveys that considered the <a href="/wiki/Afro-Mexican" class="mw-redirect" title="Afro-Mexican">Afro-Mexican</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mexicans_of_European_descent" title="Mexicans of European descent">Euro-Mexican</a> population that lives in the country.
</p><p>As of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, it is estimated that 1.2 million foreigners have settled in the country,<sup id="cite_ref-UN2017_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN2017-313">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup> up from nearly 1 million in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup> The vast majority of migrants come from the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> (900,000), making Mexico the top destination for <a href="/wiki/American_immigration_to_Mexico" title="American immigration to Mexico">U.S. citizens abroad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup> The second largest group comes from neighboring <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> (54,500), followed by <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> (27,600).<sup id="cite_ref-UN2017_313-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN2017-313">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup> Other major sources of migration are fellow Latin American countries, which include <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> (20,600), <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> (19,200) and <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a> (18,100).<sup id="cite_ref-UN2017_313-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN2017-313">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup> Historically, the <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_Mexicans" title="Lebanese Mexicans">Lebanese diaspora</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mennonites_in_Mexico" title="Mennonites in Mexico">German-born Mennonite migration</a> have left a notorious impact in the country's culture, particularly in its cuisine and traditional music.<sup id="cite_ref-Garcia_2005_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Garcia_2005-316">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup> At the turn of the 21st century, several trends have increased the number of foreigners residing in the country such as the <a href="/wiki/2008%E2%80%932014_Spanish_financial_crisis" title="2008–2014 Spanish financial crisis">2008–2014 Spanish financial crisis</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup> increasing gang-related violence in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Triangle_of_Central_America" title="Northern Triangle of Central America">Northern Triangle of Central America</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Crisis_in_Venezuela" title="Crisis in Venezuela">ongoing political and economic crisis in Venezuela</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Mexico" title="Automotive industry in Mexico">automotive industry boom</a> led by Japanese and South Korean investment.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnicity_and_race">Ethnicity and race</span></h3>
