<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ignacio_Mar%C3%ADa_Barreda_-_Las_castas_mexicanas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Ignacio_Mar%C3%ADa_Barreda_-_Las_castas_mexicanas.jpg/220px-Ignacio_Mar%C3%ADa_Barreda_-_Las_castas_mexicanas.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="360" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Ignacio_Mar%C3%ADa_Barreda_-_Las_castas_mexicanas.jpg/330px-Ignacio_Mar%C3%ADa_Barreda_-_Las_castas_mexicanas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Ignacio_Mar%C3%ADa_Barreda_-_Las_castas_mexicanas.jpg/440px-Ignacio_Mar%C3%ADa_Barreda_-_Las_castas_mexicanas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="707" data-file-height="1156" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ignacio_Mar%C3%ADa_Barreda_-_Las_castas_mexicanas.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Depiction of the <a href="/wiki/Casta" title="Casta">casta</a> system in Mexico. Painting of 1777.</div></div></div>
<p>Mexico is ethnically diverse; with people of several ethnicities being united under a single national identity.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated115_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated115-324">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup> The core part of Mexican national identity is formed on the basis of a synthesis of cultures, primarily European culture and indigenous cultures, in a process known as <a href="/wiki/Mestizaje" class="mw-redirect" title="Mestizaje">mestizaje</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated115_324-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated115-324">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-census_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-325">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup> Mexican politicians and reformers such as <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Vasconcelos" title="José Vasconcelos">José Vasconcelos</a> (promoter of the <i><a href="/wiki/La_Raza_C%C3%B3smica" class="mw-redirect" title="La Raza Cósmica">cosmic race</a></i>) and <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Gamio" title="Manuel Gamio">Manuel Gamio</a> (promoter of <i><a href="/wiki/Indigenismo" title="Indigenismo">indigenismo</a></i>) were instrumental in building a Mexican national identity on the concept of mestizaje.<sup id="cite_ref-Knight,_Alan_1990._pp._78_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Knight,_Alan_1990._pp._78-326">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The large majority of Mexicans have historically been classified as "<a href="/wiki/Mestizos_in_Mexico" title="Mestizos in Mexico">Mestizos</a>". In modern Mexican usage, the term <i>mestizo</i> is primarily a cultural identity rather than the racial identity it was during the colonial era, resulting in individuals with varying phenotypes being classified under the same identity, regardless of whether they are of mixed ancestry or not.<sup id="cite_ref-redalyc_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-redalyc-327">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> In the Yucatán Peninsula the word <i>Mestizo</i> has a different meaning, being used to refer to the <a href="/wiki/Yucatec_Maya_language" title="Yucatec Maya language">Maya</a>-speaking populations living in traditional communities, because during the <a href="/wiki/Caste_War_of_Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Caste War of Yucatán">Caste War</a> of the late 19th century those Maya who did not join the rebellion were classified as mestizos.<sup id="cite_ref-Bartolomé_1996:2_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bartolomé_1996:2-328">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup> In Chiapas the word <i>Ladino</i> is used instead of <i>mestizo</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup> Due the different definitions and socio-cultural connotations the term has carried through history it was deemed too imprecise to be used for ethnic classification, which led to it being abandoned by the government and the Mexican society,<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_175-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-175">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup> with its use being limited to intellectual circles. According to the Mexican census of 1921 and publications who retake its results such as  <a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a>, the majority of Mexicans (from 50% to 67% of the country's population) identify as Mestizo,<sup id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-331">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup> although modern research has observed that when asked directly about their ethno-racial identification, many Mexicans do not identify as Mestizos.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The total percentage of Mexico's population who are <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_Mexico" title="Indigenous peoples of Mexico">indigenous</a> varies considerably depending of the criteria used by the government on its censuses: it is 5.4% if the ability to speak an indigenous language is used as the criteria to define a person as indigenous,<sup id="cite_ref-inegiindigenous_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-inegiindigenous-333">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup> if racial self-identification is used it is 14.9%<sup id="cite_ref-CDI1_334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CDI1-334">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">&#91;a&#93;</a></sup> and if people who consider themselves part indigenous are also included it amounts to 23%.<sup id="cite_ref-beta.inegi.org.mx_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beta.inegi.org.mx-338">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup> Nonetheless, all the censuses conclude that the majority of Mexico's indigenous population is concentrated in rural areas of the southern and south-eastern Mexican states such as<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup> Yucatán at 59%, Quintana Roo 39% and Campeche 27%, who are chiefly <a href="/wiki/Maya_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Maya people">Maya</a>; Oaxaca with 48% of the population, the most numerous groups being the <a href="/wiki/Mixtec" title="Mixtec">Mixtec</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Zapotec people">Zapotec peoples</a>; Chiapas at 28%, the majority being <a href="/wiki/Tzeltal_people" title="Tzeltal people">Tzeltal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tzotzil_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Tzotzil people">Tzotzil</a> Maya; Hidalgo 24%, the majority being <a href="/wiki/Otomi_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Otomi people">Otomi</a>; Puebla 19%, and Guerrero 17%, mostly <a href="/wiki/Nahua_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Nahua people">Nahua peoples</a> and the states of San Luis Potosí and Veracruz are both home to a population that is 15% indigenous, mostly from the <a href="/wiki/Totonac" title="Totonac">Totonac</a>, Nahua and <a href="/wiki/Huastec_people" title="Huastec people">Teenek (Huastec)</a> groups.<sup id="cite_ref-inegi.org.mx_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-inegi.org.mx-340">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup> The absolute numbers of the indigenous population are growing, but at a slower rate than the rest of the population so that the percentage of indigenous peoples in regards to total population is nonetheless falling.<sup id="cite_ref-CDI_341-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CDI-341">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> All of the indices of social development for the indigenous population are considerably lower than the national average even though the indigenous population participates in the workforce longer than the national average with 55% of the indigenous population receiving less than a minimum salary, compared to 20% for the national average. Many practice subsistence agriculture and regulate some internal issues under <a href="/wiki/Customary_law" title="Customary law">customary law</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-inegi.org.mx_340-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-inegi.org.mx-340">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Similarly to Mestizo and indigenous peoples, estimates of the percentage of <a href="/wiki/Mexicans_of_European_descent" title="Mexicans of European descent">European-descended Mexicans</a> within the Mexican population vary considerably: according to the Encyclopædia Britannica which uses as reference the 1921 census their numbers range from around 10%–20%.<sup id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica_331-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-331">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup> (the results of the 1921 census, however, have been contested by various historians and deemed inaccurate).<sup id="cite_ref-MexicoRacista1_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MexicoRacista1-342">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup> Recent nationwide field surveys that account for different phenotypical traits (hair color, skin color etc.) on the other hand, report rather higher percentages, with it being between 18%<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup>-23%<sup id="cite_ref-scielo.org.mx_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scielo.org.mx-344">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup> if the criteria is the presence of <a href="/wiki/Blond" title="Blond">blond hair</a>, and of 47% if the criteria is skin color, with the later surveys having been conducted by Mexico's government with the aim to address ethnic and racial discrimination in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017-345">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-conapred.org.mx_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-conapred.org.mx-346">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DISC-RACIAL_2011_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DISC-RACIAL_2011-347">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ENADIS2017_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENADIS2017-348">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MMSI2_349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MMSI2-349">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup><br /> While during the colonial era, most of the European migration into Mexico was <a href="/wiki/Spaniards_in_Mexico" title="Spaniards in Mexico">Spanish</a>, in the 19th and 20th centuries a substantial number of non-Spanish Europeans immigrated to the country. According to 20th- and 21st-century academics, large scale intermixing between European immigrants and native Indigenous peoples would produce a Mestizo group which would become the overwhelming majority of Mexico's population by the time of the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-fnavarrete_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fnavarrete-350">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup> However, according to church registers from the colonial times, the majority of European men married European women.<sup id="cite_ref-MexicoRacista1_342-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MexicoRacista1-342">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup> Said registers also put in question other narratives held by contemporary academics, such as European migrants who arrived in Mexico being almost exclusively men,<sup id="cite_ref-scielo.org.mx2_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scielo.org.mx2-351">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup> or that "pure Spanish" people were all part of a small powerful elite, as Spaniards were often the most numerous ethnic group in the colonial cities<sup id="cite_ref-EnsayospoblaciónMéxico_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EnsayospoblaciónMéxico-352">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup> and there were menial workers and people in poverty who were of complete Spanish origin.<sup id="cite_ref-scielo.org.mx2_351-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scielo.org.mx2-351">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup> Nowadays Mexico's northern and western regions have the highest European populations, with the majority of the people not having native admixture or being of predominantly European ancestry.<sup id="cite_ref-UnitedStatesandMexico_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UnitedStatesandMexico-353">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg/220px-Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg/330px-Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg/440px-Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3227" data-file-height="4303" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Capilla_de_San_Francisco_Puebla.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Puebla_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Puebla City">Puebla de Zaragoza</a> is the most populated city of <a href="/wiki/Puebla" title="Puebla">Puebla</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Afro-Mexican population (1,381,853 individuals as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>)<sup id="cite_ref-Encuesta_Intercensal_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encuesta_Intercensal-354">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup> is an ethnic group made up of descendants of Colonial-era slaves and recent immigrants of sub-Saharan African descent. Mexico had an active slave trade during the colonial period, and some 200,000 Africans were taken there, primarily in the 17th century. The creation of a national Mexican identity, especially after the Mexican Revolution, emphasized Mexico's indigenous and European past; it passively eliminated the African ancestors and contributions. Most of the African-descended population was absorbed into the surrounding Mestizo (mixed European/indigenous) and indigenous populations through unions among the groups. Evidence of this long history of intermarriage with Mestizo and indigenous Mexicans is also expressed in the fact that in the 2015 inter-census, 64.9% (896,829) of Afro-Mexicans also identified as indigenous. It was also reported that 9.3% of Afro-Mexicans speak an indigenous language.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup> The states with the highest self-report of Afro-Mexicans were Guerrero (6.5% of the population), Oaxaca (4.95%) and Veracruz (3.28%).<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup> Afro-Mexican culture is strongest in the communities of the <a href="/wiki/Costa_Chica_of_Oaxaca" class="mw-redirect" title="Costa Chica of Oaxaca">Costa Chica of Oaxaca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Costa_Chica_of_Guerrero" title="Costa Chica of Guerrero">Costa Chica of Guerrero</a>.
</p><p>During the early 20th century, a substantial number of <a href="/wiki/Arab_Mexicans" title="Arab Mexicans">Arabs</a> (mostly <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Christians</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup> began arriving from the crumbling <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. The largest group were the Lebanese and an estimated 400,000 Mexicans have some <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_Mexicans" title="Lebanese Mexicans">Lebanese ancestry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup> Smaller ethnic groups in Mexico include <a href="/wiki/Asian_Mexicans" title="Asian Mexicans">South and East Asians</a>, present since the colonial era. During the colonial era Asians were termed <i>Chino</i> (regardless of ethnicity), and arrived as merchants, artisans and slaves.<sup id="cite_ref-Seijas_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seijas-359">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup> A study by Juan Esteban Rodríguez, a graduate student at the National Laboratory of Genomics for Biodiversity, indicated that up to one third of people sampled from <a href="/wiki/Guerrero" title="Guerrero">Guerrero</a> state had significantly more Asian ancestry than most Mexicans, primarily <a href="/wiki/Filipino_immigration_to_Mexico" title="Filipino immigration to Mexico">Filipino</a> or <a href="/wiki/Native_Indonesians" title="Native Indonesians">Indonesian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup> Modern Asian immigration began in the late 19th century, and at one point in the early 20th century the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_immigration_to_Mexico" title="Chinese immigration to Mexico">Chinese</a> were the second largest immigrant group.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Official_censuses">Official censuses</span></h4>
<p>The first census in Mexico (then known as <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain" class="mw-redirect" title="Viceroyalty of New Spain">New Spain</a>) that included an ethnic classification was the 1793 census. Also known as the Revillagigedo census. Most of its original datasets have reportedly been lost, thus most of what is known about it nowadays comes from essays and field investigations made by academics who had access to the census data and used it as reference for their works such as Prussian geographer <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">Alexander von Humboldt</a>. According to said works Europeans ranged from 18% to 22% of New Spain's population, Mestizos from 21% to 25%, Indians from 51% to 61% and Africans were between 6,000 and 10,000. The total population ranged from 3,799,561 to 6,122,354. It is concluded that the population growth trends of whites and mestizos were even, while the percentage of the indigenous population decreased at a rate of 13%–17% per century mostly due the later having higher mortality rates for living in remote locations and being in constant war with the colonists.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup> Anthropologist <a href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gonzalo_Aguirre_Beltr%C3%A1n" class="extiw" title="es:Gonzalo Aguirre Beltrán">Gonzalo Aguirre Beltrán</a> goes beyond said numbers and splits the Mestizo group into "Euromestizos", "Indomestizos" and "Afromestizos" calculating their numbers at more than one million, 700,000 and 600,000 respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-Aguirre_Beltrán_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Aguirre_Beltrán-364">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup> Independent-era Mexico eliminated the legal basis of the <a href="/wiki/Castas" class="mw-redirect" title="Castas">Colonial caste system</a> which led to exclusion of racial classification in the censuses to come.
</p><p>According to Mexico's second census ever that considered race, made right after the Mexican revolution in 1921,<sup id="cite_ref-somosprimos.com_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-somosprimos.com-365">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup> 59% of Mexico's population was Mestizo, 29% was Indigenous and only 9% was European, with Mestizos being the most numerous ethno-racial group in almost all the states.<sup id="cite_ref-somosprimos.com_365-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-somosprimos.com-365">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup> For a long time this census' results were taken as fact, with extraofficial international publications such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">The World Factbook</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a> using them as a reference to estimate Mexico's racial composition up to this day.<sup id="cite_ref-Factbook_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-366">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica_331-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica-331">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup> In recent time nonetheless, Mexican academics have subjected the census' results to scrutiny, claiming that such a drastic alteration in demographic trends in regards to the 1793 census is not possible and cite, among other statistics the relatively low frequency of marriages between people of different continental ancestries in colonial and early independent Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MexicoRacista1_342-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MexicoRacista1-342">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup> Said authors claim that the Mexican society went through a "more cultural than biological mestizaje process" sponsored by the state in its efforts to unify the Mexican population which resulted in the inflation of the percentage of the Mestizo Mexican group at the expense of the identity of the other races that exist in Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent times the Mexican government has decided to conduct new ethnic surveys and censuses, also widening the criteria to classify the ethnicities who were already considered such as the Indigenous Mexican one, which was previously reserved to people who lived in indigenous communities or spoke an indigenous language. According to these recent surveys, Indigenous peoples amount to 23% of Mexico's population (including people who declared to be partially indigenous),<sup id="cite_ref-beta.inegi.org.mx_338-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beta.inegi.org.mx-338">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup> Afro-Mexicans are 2% of Mexico's population (including people who declared to be partially African)<sup id="cite_ref-beta.inegi.org.mx_338-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beta.inegi.org.mx-338">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup> and White or European Mexicans amount to 47% of Mexico's population (based on appearance rather than on self-declared of ancestry).<sup id="cite_ref-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017_345-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marzo_DiaIntElimDiscRacial_INACCSS_2017-345">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-conapred.org.mx_346-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-conapred.org.mx-346">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DISC-RACIAL_2011_347-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DISC-RACIAL_2011-347">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MMSI1_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MMSI1-369">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup> Less numerous groups in Mexico such as Asians and Middle Easterners are also accounted for. Out of all the ethnic groups that have recently been surveyed, that of Mestizos is notably absent, which may be consequence of the ethnic label's fluid and subjective definition, which complicates a precise calculation as well the tendency that Mexicans have to identify people with "static" ethnic labels rather than "fluid" ones.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Emigration">Emigration</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Emigration_from_Mexico" title="Emigration from Mexico">Emigration from Mexico</a></div>
<p>In the early 1960s, around 600,000 Mexicans lived abroad, which increased sevenfold by the 1990s to 4.4 million.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-371">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> At the turn of the 21st century, this figure more than doubled to 9.5 million.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_371-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-371">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> As of 2017, it is estimated that 12.9 million Mexicans live abroad, primarily in the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, which concentrates nearly 98% of the expatriate population.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_371-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-371">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> The majority of Mexicans have settled in states such as <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a>, particularly around the metropolitan areas of <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_metropolitan_area" title="Los Angeles metropolitan area">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicago_metropolitan_area" title="Chicago metropolitan area">Chicago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greater_Houston" title="Greater Houston">Houston</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dallas%E2%80%93Fort_Worth_metroplex" title="Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex">Dallas-Fort Worth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> As a result of these major migration flows in recent decades, around 36 million U.S. residents, or 11.2% of the country's population, identified as being of full or partial Mexican ancestry.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> The remaining 2% of expatriates have settled in <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> (86,000), primarily in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Ontario" title="Ontario">Ontario</a> and <a href="/wiki/Quebec" title="Quebec">Quebec</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup> followed by <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> (49,000) and <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> (18,000), both European destinations represent almost two-thirds of the Mexican population living in the continent.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_371-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-371">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> As for Latin America, it is estimated that 69,000 Mexicans live in the region, <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> (18,000) being the top destination for expatriates, followed by <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> (10,000) and <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a> (5,000).<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Yearbook_371-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Yearbook-371">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Mexico" title="Languages of Mexico">Languages of Mexico</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> is the <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> national language spoken by the vast majority of the population, making Mexico the world's most populous <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone" title="Hispanophone">Hispanophone</a> country.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Spanishhistory_311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spanishhistory-311">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Spanish" title="Mexican Spanish">Mexican Spanish</a> is the set of <a href="/wiki/Variety_(linguistics)" title="Variety (linguistics)">varieties</a> of the language spoken in the country, which differs from one region to another phonetically, syntactically and lexically.<sup id="cite_ref-Concise_Encyclopedia_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Concise_Encyclopedia-376">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> In general, Mexican Spanish does not make any phonetic <a href="/wiki/Phonological_history_of_Spanish_coronal_fricatives#Seseo" title="Phonological history of Spanish coronal fricatives">distinction among the letters <i>s</i> and <i>z</i></a>, as well as <i>c</i> when preceding the vowels <i>e</i> and <i>i</i>, as opposed to <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_Spanish" title="Peninsular Spanish">Peninsular Spanish</a>. The letters <i>b</i> and <i>v</i> have the same pronunciation as well.<sup id="cite_ref-Concise_Encyclopedia_376-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Concise_Encyclopedia-376">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> Furthermore, the usage of <i><a href="/wiki/Voseo" title="Voseo">vos</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_person" title="Grammatical person">second person</a> <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">singular</a> <a href="/wiki/Pronoun" title="Pronoun">pronoun</a>, found in several Latin American varieties, is replaced by <i><a href="/wiki/T-V_distinction#Spanish" class="mw-redirect" title="T-V distinction">tú</a></i>; whereas <i><a href="/wiki/Spanish_personal_pronouns#The_use_of_vosotros" title="Spanish personal pronouns">vosotros</a></i>, the second person plural pronoun, fell out of use and was effectively replaced by <i>ustedes</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Concise_Encyclopedia_376-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Concise_Encyclopedia-376">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> In written form, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Royal_Academy" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish Royal Academy">Spanish Royal Academy</a> serves as the primary guideline for spelling, except for words of Amerindian origin that retain their original phonology such as <i><a href="/wiki/Northern_mockingbird" title="Northern mockingbird">cenzontle</a></i> instead of <i>sinzontle</i> and <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Mexico" title="Name of Mexico"><i>México</i> not <i>Méjico</i></a>. Words of foreign origin also maintain their original spelling such as whisky and film, as opposed to <i>güisqui</i> and <i>filme</i> as the Royal Academy suggests.<sup id="cite_ref-Concise_Encyclopedia_376-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Concise_Encyclopedia-376">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> The letter <i>x</i> is distinctly used in Mexican Spanish, which may be pronounced as <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ks]</span> (as in <i>oxígeno</i> or <i>taxi</i>), as <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[ʃ]</span> particularly in Amerindian words (e.g. <i>mixiote</i>, <i>Xola</i> and <i>uxmal</i>) and as the <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative" title="Voiceless velar fricative">voiceless velar fricative</a> <span class="IPA nowrap" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">&#91;<a href="/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative" title="Voiceless velar fricative">x</a>&#93;</span> (such as <i>Texas</i> and <i>Oaxaca</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-Concise_Encyclopedia_376-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Concise_Encyclopedia-376">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The federal government officially recognizes <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Mexico#Indigenous_languages" title="Languages of Mexico">sixty-eight linguistic groups and 364 varieties of indigenous languages</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup> It is estimated that around 8.3 million citizens speak these languages,<sup id="cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-378">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a> being the most widely spoken by more than 1.7 million, followed by <a href="/wiki/Yucatec_Maya_language" title="Yucatec Maya language">Yucatec Maya</a> used daily by nearly 850,000 people, <a href="/wiki/Tzeltal_language" title="Tzeltal language">Tzeltal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tzotzil_language" title="Tzotzil language">Tzotzil</a>, two variants of the <a href="/wiki/Mayan_languages" title="Mayan languages">Mayan languages</a>, are spoken by around half a million people each, primarily in the southern state of <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">Chiapas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_378-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-378">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mixtec_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Mixtec languages">Mixtec</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_languages" title="Zapotec languages">Zapotec</a>, both with estimated 500,000 native speakers each, are two other notorious language groups.<sup id="cite_ref-Indigenous_Languages_378-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indigenous_Languages-378">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup> Since its creation in March 2003, the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Lenguas_Ind%C3%ADgenas" title="Instituto Nacional de Lenguas Indígenas">National Indigenous Languages Institute</a> has been in charge of promoting and protecting the use of the country's indigenous languages, through the <a href="/wiki/Ley_General_de_Derechos_Ling%C3%BC%C3%ADsticos_de_los_Pueblos_Ind%C3%ADgenas" title="Ley General de Derechos Lingüísticos de los Pueblos Indígenas">General Law of Indigenous Peoples' Linguistic Rights</a>, which recognizes them <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> as "national languages" with equal status as that of Spanish.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup> Notwithstanding, in practice, indigenous peoples often face discrimination and are unable to have proper access to public services such as education and healthcare, as well as the justice system, as Spanish is the prominent language.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Aside from indigenous languages, there are several minority languages spoken in Mexico due to international migration such as <a href="/wiki/Low_German" title="Low German">Low German</a> by the 80,000-strong <a href="/wiki/Mennonites_in_Mexico" title="Mennonites in Mexico">Menonite population</a>, primarily settled in the northern states, fuelled by the tolerance of the federal government towards this community by allowing them to set their own educational system compatible with their customs and traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chipilo_Venetian_dialect" title="Chipilo Venetian dialect">Chipilo dialect</a>, a variance of the <a href="/wiki/Venetian_language" title="Venetian language">Venetian language</a>, is spoken in the town of <a href="/wiki/Chipilo" title="Chipilo">Chipilo</a>, located in the central state of <a href="/wiki/Puebla" title="Puebla">Puebla</a>, by around 2,500 people, mainly descendants of Venetians that migrated to the area in the late 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup> Furthermore, <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> is the most commonly taught <a href="/wiki/Foreign_language" title="Foreign language">foreign language</a> in Mexico. It is estimated that nearly 24 million, or around a fifth of the population, study the language through public schools, private institutions or self-access channels.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup> However, a high level of English proficiency is limited to only 5% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup> Moreover, <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> is the second most widely taught foreign language, as every year between 200,000 and 250,000 Mexican students enroll in language courses.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urban_areas">Urban areas</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_of_Mexico" title="Metropolitan areas of Mexico">Metropolitan areas of Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Mexico" title="List of cities in Mexico">List of cities in Mexico</a></div>
<p>Here are the 20 largest urban areas in Mexico.
</p>
<table class="navbox">

<tbody><tr>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Mexico" title="Religion in Mexico">Religion in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">
<table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
<tbody><tr style="background:#ddd"><th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5"><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Mexico" title="Religion in Mexico">Religion in Mexico</a> (2010 census)<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></th></tr>

</tbody></table>
</div>
</div>
<p>The 2010 census by the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Nacional_de_Estad%C3%ADstica_y_Geograf%C3%ADa" class="mw-redirect" title="Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía">Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía</a> (National Institute of Statistics and Geography) gave <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Mexico" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism in Mexico">Roman Catholicism</a> as the main religion, with 83% of the population, while 10% (10,924,103) belong to other Christian denominations, including <a href="/wiki/Evangelicals" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelicals">Evangelicals</a> (5%); <a href="/wiki/Pentecostals" class="mw-redirect" title="Pentecostals">Pentecostals</a> (1.6%); other Protestant or Reformed (0.7%); <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah&#39;s Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a> (1.4%); <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a> (0.6%); and members of <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a> (0.3%).<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> 172,891 (or less than 0.2% of the total) belonged to other, non-Christian religions; 4.7% declared having <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Mexico" title="Irreligion in Mexico">no religion</a>; 2.7% were unspecified.<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_(JC)_01.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG/220px-Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG/330px-Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG/440px-Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_%28JC%29_01.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3672" data-file-height="4896" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Nueva_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Guadalupe_(JC)_01.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Our Lady of Guadalupe">Our Lady of Guadalupe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patron_saint" title="Patron saint">patron saint</a> of Mexico, an ancient Marian title of <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">Amerindian</a> race. This painting of her at the <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe">Basilica of Guadalupe</a> is among her most notable depictions; scientists still debate if it should be dated 1531, the year of the first apparition,<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup> or the 1550s.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The 92,924,489<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> Catholics of Mexico constitute in absolute terms the second largest Catholic community in the world, after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>'s.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup> 47% percent of them attend church services weekly.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup> The feast day of <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Our Lady of Guadalupe">Our Lady of Guadalupe</a>, the patron saint of Mexico, is celebrated on December 12 and is regarded by many Mexicans as the most important religious holiday of their country.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup> In spite of this, the Mexican State is officially lay secularist since the separation between religious institutions and the political administration of the nation was enshrined in the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Constitution_of_the_United_Mexican_States_of_1857" title="Federal Constitution of the United Mexican States of 1857">1857</a>, and was ratified in the current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">Constitution of 1917</a>. <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Morelos" title="José María Morelos">José María Morelos</a> noted in his writings that there should be no tolerance for any other religion and the <a href="/wiki/1824_Constitution_of_Mexico" title="1824 Constitution of Mexico">Constitution of 1824</a> declared that the official religion of the Republic would be Catholic, and from the second half of the 20th century, began a process of introducing creeds different from the Catholic.
</p><p>The 1920s was marked by a religious conflict known as the <a href="/wiki/Cristero_War" title="Cristero War">Cristero War</a>, in which many peasants encouraged by the clergy clashed with the federal government that had decided to enforce the constitutional laws of 1917. Among the measures contemplated by the Magna Carta were the suppression of the <a href="/wiki/Monasticism" title="Monasticism">monastic orders</a> and the cancellation of all religious worship. The war ended with an agreement between the parties in conflict (<a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a> and State), by means of which the respective fields of action were defined. Until the middle of the 1990s, the Mexican constitution did not recognize the existence of any religious group. In 1993, a law was enacted whereby the State granted them legal status as "religious associations". This fact allowed the reestablishment of diplomatic relations with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>, to which the Mexican State did not recognize as a political entity.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Zapopan_(Zapopan,_Jalisco)_-_exterior_and_plaza.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Basilica of Our Lady of Zapopan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Zapopan_%28Zapopan%2C_Jalisco%29_-_exterior_and_plaza.jpg/220px-Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Zapopan_%28Zapopan%2C_Jalisco%29_-_exterior_and_plaza.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Zapopan_%28Zapopan%2C_Jalisco%29_-_exterior_and_plaza.jpg/330px-Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Zapopan_%28Zapopan%2C_Jalisco%29_-_exterior_and_plaza.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Zapopan_%28Zapopan%2C_Jalisco%29_-_exterior_and_plaza.jpg/440px-Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Zapopan_%28Zapopan%2C_Jalisco%29_-_exterior_and_plaza.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="3005" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bas%C3%ADlica_de_Nuestra_Se%C3%B1ora_de_Zapopan_(Zapopan,_Jalisco)_-_exterior_and_plaza.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_Our_Lady_of_Zapopan" title="Basilica of Our Lady of Zapopan">Basilica of Our Lady of Zapopan</a> in Zapopan, Jalisco</div></div></div>
<p>According to the figures of <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Statistics_and_Geography_(Mexico)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Institute of Statistics and Geography (Mexico)">INEGI</a>, most Mexicans declare themselves <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christian</a> and most <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholics</a> (almost 93 million adherents according to the census of 2010).<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
The second Christian group is the <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah&#39;s Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>, which totals more than 1&#160;million adherents, making the Mexican congregation of this Christian branch the second worldwide.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Thirdly find <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a>, whose members are known as <a href="/wiki/Latter_Day_Saint_movement" title="Latter Day Saint movement">Mormons</a>, 2010 census reported 314,932 members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints,<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> though the church in 2009 claimed to have over one million registered members;<sup id="cite_ref-lds-Mexico_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lds-Mexico-394">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> followed by <a href="/wiki/La_Luz_del_Mundo" title="La Luz del Mundo">Church of the La Luz del Mundo</a>, which has its center in "<a href="/w/index.php?title=La_Hermosa_Provincia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="La Hermosa Provincia (page does not exist)">La Hermosa Provincia</a>", a colony of <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>. The denominations <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">Pentecostal</a> also have an important presence, especially in the cities of the border and in the indigenous communities. In fact, Pentecostal churches together have more than 1.3 million adherents, which in net numbers place them as the second Christian creed in Mexico. The situation changes when the different Pentecostal denominations are considered as separate entities. Other groups are growing, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iglesia_apost%C3%B3lica_de_la_Fe_en_Cristo_Jes%C3%BAs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iglesia apostólica de la Fe en Cristo Jesús (page does not exist)">Iglesia apostólica de la Fe en Cristo Jesús</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mennonites_in_Mexico" title="Mennonites in Mexico">Mennonites</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventist Church</a>. Migratory phenomena have led to the proliferation of different aspects of Christianity, including branches <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>.
</p><p>According to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jacobo_Grinberg-Zylberbaum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jacobo Grinberg-Zylberbaum (page does not exist)">Jacobo Grinberg-Zylberbaum</a> (in texts edited by the <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a>), it is remarkable the survival of magic-religious rituals of the old <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples" title="Indigenous peoples">indigenous</a> groups, not only in the current indigenous people but in the <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">mestizos</a> and <a href="/wiki/White_people" title="White people">whites</a> that make up the Mexican rural and urban society. There is often a <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretism</a> between <a href="/wiki/Shamanism" title="Shamanism">shamanism</a> and the Catholic tradition. Another religion of popular syncretism in Mexico (especially in recent years) is the <a href="/wiki/Santer%C3%ADa" title="Santería">Santería</a>. This is mainly due to the large number of Cubans who settled in the territory after the <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolution" title="Cuban Revolution">Cuban Revolution</a> (mainly in states such as <a href="/wiki/Veracruz" title="Veracruz">Veracruz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yucat%C3%A1n" title="Yucatán">Yucatán</a>). Although Mexico was also a recipient of black slaves from <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> in the 16th century, the apogee of these cults is relatively new.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In certain regions, the profession of a creed other than the Catholic is seen as a threat to community unity. It is argued that the Catholic religion is part of the ethnic identity, and that the Protestants are not willing to participate in the traditional customs and practices (the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tequio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tequio (page does not exist)">tequio</a> or community work, participation in the festivities and similar issues). The refusal of the Protestants is because their religious beliefs do not allow them to participate in the cult of images. In extreme cases, tension between Catholics and Protestants has led to the expulsion or even murder of Protestants in several villages. The best known cases are those of <a href="/wiki/San_Juan_Chamula" class="mw-redirect" title="San Juan Chamula">San Juan Chamula</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup> in Chiapas, and San Nicolás, in <a href="/wiki/Ixmiquilpan" title="Ixmiquilpan">Ixmiquilpan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hidalgo_(state)" title="Hidalgo (state)">Hidalgo</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Kid_-_Diego_Rivera.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/The_Kid_-_Diego_Rivera.jpg/220px-The_Kid_-_Diego_Rivera.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/The_Kid_-_Diego_Rivera.jpg/330px-The_Kid_-_Diego_Rivera.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/86/The_Kid_-_Diego_Rivera.jpg 2x" data-file-width="420" data-file-height="560" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Kid_-_Diego_Rivera.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Detail of the 1947 Rivera mural,  <i><a href="/wiki/Dream_of_a_Sunday_Afternoon_in_the_Alameda_Central" class="mw-redirect" title="Dream of a Sunday Afternoon in the Alameda Central">Dream of a Sunday Afternoon in the Alameda Central</a></i>. The mural includes a depiction of <a href="/wiki/La_Calavera_Catrina" title="La Calavera Catrina">La Catrina</a>, a popular satirical character that has become associated with <a href="/wiki/D%C3%ADa_de_Muertos" class="mw-redirect" title="Día de Muertos">Día de Muertos</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>A similar argument was presented by a committee of anthropologists to request the government of the Republic to expel the <a href="/wiki/SIL_International" title="SIL International">Summer Linguistic Institute</a> (SIL), in the year 1979, which was accused of promoting the division of indigenous peoples by translating the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a> into vernacular languages and evangelizing in a Protestant creed that threatened the integrity of popular cultures. The Mexican government paid attention to the call of the anthropologists and canceled the agreement that had held with the SIL. Conflicts have also occurred in other areas of social life. For example, given that Jehovah's Witnesses are prohibited from surrendering honors to national symbols (something that is done every Monday in Mexican public schools), children who have been educated in that religion were expelled from public schools. This type of problem can only be solved with the intervention of the National Commission of <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Human Rights">Human Rights</a>, and not always with favorable results for children.
</p><p>The impact of the Catholic religion in Mexico has also caused a fusion of elements. Beyond churches and religious denominations, a phenomenon persists in Mexico that some anthropologists and sociologists call "popular religion", that is, religion as the practice and understanding of the people. In Mexico, the main component is the Catholic religion, to which elements of other beliefs have been added, already of pre-Hispanic, African or Asian origin. In general, popular religiosity is viewed with bad eyes by institutionally structured religions. One of the most exemplary cases of popular religiosity is the cult of <a href="/wiki/Santa_Muerte" title="Santa Muerte">Holy Dead</a> (Santa Muerte). The Catholic hierarchy insists on describing it as a satanic cult. However, most of the people who profess this cult declare themselves to be Catholic believers, and consider that there is no contradiction between the tributes they offer to the <a href="/wiki/Christ_Child" title="Christ Child">Christ Child</a> and the adoration of God. Other examples are the representations of the <a href="/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross" title="Stations of the Cross">Passion of Christ</a> and the celebration of <a href="/wiki/Day_of_the_Dead" title="Day of the Dead">Day of the Dead</a>, which take place within the framework of the Catholic Christian imaginary, but under a very particular reinterpretation of its protagonists.
</p><p>The presence of <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Mexico" title="History of the Jews in Mexico">Jews in Mexico</a> dates back to 1521, when Hernán Cortés conquered the Aztecs, accompanied by several <a href="/wiki/Converso" title="Converso">Conversos</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup>  According to the 2010 census, there are 67,476 Jews in Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Mexico" title="Islam in Mexico">Islam in Mexico</a> is practiced mostly by <a href="/wiki/Arab_Mexican" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab Mexican">Arab Mexicans</a>. In the 2010 census 18,185 Mexicans reported belonging to an <a href="/wiki/Eastern_religion" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern religion">Eastern religion</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-2010-census_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010-census-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> a category which includes a tiny <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Mexico" title="Buddhism in Mexico">Buddhist</a> population.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Women">Women</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Mexico" title="Women in Mexico">Women in Mexico</a></div>
<p>Until the twentieth century, Mexico was an overwhelmingly rural country, with rural women's status defined within the context of the family and local community.  With urbanization beginning in the sixteenth century, following the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Aztec_empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish conquest of the Aztec empire">Spanish conquest of the Aztec empire</a>, cities have provided economic and social opportunities not possible within rural villages.
</p><p>As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Mexico has the 16th highest rate of homicides committed against women in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-femicide_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-femicide-400">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup> A study in 1997 showed that the prevalence of <a href="/wiki/Domestic_violence" title="Domestic violence">domestic violence</a> against women in Mexican marital relationships varies at between 30 and 60 percent of relationships.<sup id="cite_ref-usaid_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usaid-401">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup> The remains of the victims were frequently mutilated.<sup id="cite_ref-hp_8Jan2015_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hp_8Jan2015-402">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup> According to a 1997 study, domestic abuse in Mexican culture "is embedded in gender and marital relations fostered in Mexican women's dependence on their spouses for subsistence and for self-esteem, sustained by ideologies of romantic love, by family structure and residential arrangements".<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">&#91;402&#93;</a></sup> The perpetrators are often the boyfriend, father-in-law, ex-husbands or husbands but only 1.6% of the murder cases led to an arrest and sentencing.<sup id="cite_ref-hp_8Jan2015_402-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hp_8Jan2015-402">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1" title="Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.<br /><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Mexico%22">"Mexico"</a>&#160;–&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Mexico%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Mexico%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Mexico%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Mexico%22">scholar</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Mexico%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2017</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Mexico" title="Culture of Mexico">Culture of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TiledBldgs5OrientePuebla.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/TiledBldgs5OrientePuebla.JPG/220px-TiledBldgs5OrientePuebla.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/TiledBldgs5OrientePuebla.JPG/330px-TiledBldgs5OrientePuebla.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/TiledBldgs5OrientePuebla.JPG/440px-TiledBldgs5OrientePuebla.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:TiledBldgs5OrientePuebla.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Talavera_pottery" title="Talavera pottery">Talavera pottery</a></div></div></div>
<p>Mexican culture reflects the complexity of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Mexico" title="History of Mexico">country's history</a> through the blending of indigenous cultures and the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Spain" title="Culture of Spain">culture of Spain</a>, imparted during Spain's 300-year occupation of Mexico. Exogenous cultural elements have been incorporated into Mexican culture as time has passed.
</p><p>The Porfirian era (<i>el <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">Porfiriato</a></i>), in the last quarter of the 19th century and the first decade of the 20th century, was marked by economic progress and peace. After four decades of civil unrest and war, Mexico saw the development of philosophy and the arts, promoted by President Díaz himself. Since that time, as accentuated during the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a>, cultural identity has had its foundation in the <i>mestizaje</i>, of which the indigenous (i.e. Amerindian) element is the core. In light of the various ethnicities that formed the Mexican people, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Vasconcelos" title="José Vasconcelos">José Vasconcelos</a> in his publication <i>La Raza Cósmica</i> (The Cosmic Race) (1925) defined Mexico to be the melting pot of all races (thus extending the definition of the <i>mestizo</i>) not only biologically but culturally as well.<sup id="cite_ref-vasconcelos160_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vasconcelos160-404">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Painting">Painting</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_art" title="Mexican art">Mexican art</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Kodeks_nuttall3.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Kodeks_nuttall3.jpeg/200px-Kodeks_nuttall3.jpeg" decoding="async" width="200" height="145" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Kodeks_nuttall3.jpeg/300px-Kodeks_nuttall3.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Kodeks_nuttall3.jpeg/400px-Kodeks_nuttall3.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="574" data-file-height="415" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Many <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_codices" class="mw-redirect" title="Mesoamerican codices">codices</a> made both during Pre-hispanic Mexico and in the Spanish colony are preserved.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Lactaci%C3%B3n_de_Santo_Domingo.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Lactaci%C3%B3n_de_Santo_Domingo.JPG/200px-Lactaci%C3%B3n_de_Santo_Domingo.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="146" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Lactaci%C3%B3n_de_Santo_Domingo.JPG/300px-Lactaci%C3%B3n_de_Santo_Domingo.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Lactaci%C3%B3n_de_Santo_Domingo.JPG/400px-Lactaci%C3%B3n_de_Santo_Domingo.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="875" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The art of the Colonial Mexico (center of New Spain) developed a large number of painters born in Mexico. Now these works are preserved in museums in many cities of Mexico.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg/200px-Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="178" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg/300px-Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg/400px-Murales_Rivera_-_Ausbeutung_durch_die_Spanier_1_perspective.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2684" data-file-height="2384" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Mexican_Muralism" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican Muralism">Mexican Muralism</a>. A cultural expression starting in the 1920s created by a group of Mexican painters after the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a>, reinforced by the Great Depression and the First World War.<sup id="cite_ref-aguilar_405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aguilar-405">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">Painting</a> is one of the oldest arts in Mexico. Cave painting in Mexican territory is about 7500 years old and has been found in the caves of the <a href="/wiki/Baja_California_Peninsula" title="Baja California Peninsula">Baja California Peninsula</a>. Pre-Hispanic Mexico is present in buildings and caves, in <a href="/wiki/Aztec_codices" title="Aztec codices">Aztec codices</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Ceramics" class="mw-redirect" title="Ceramics">ceramics</a>, in garments, etc. .; examples of this are the <a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Maya</a> mural paintings of <a href="/wiki/Bonampak" title="Bonampak">Bonampak</a>, or those of <a href="/wiki/Teotihuac%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Teotihuacán">Teotihuacán</a>, those of <a href="/wiki/Cacaxtla" title="Cacaxtla">Cacaxtla</a> and those of <a href="/wiki/Monte_Alb%C3%A1n" title="Monte Albán">Monte Albán</a>.
</p><p>Mural painting had an important flowering during the 16th century; the same in religious constructions as in houses of lineage; such is the case of the convents of <a href="/wiki/Acolman" title="Acolman">Acolman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Actopan,_Hidalgo" title="Actopan, Hidalgo">Actopan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Huejotzingo" title="Huejotzingo">Huejotzingo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tecamachalco,_Puebla" title="Tecamachalco, Puebla">Tecamachalco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zinacantepec" class="mw-redirect" title="Zinacantepec">Zinacantepec</a>. It is said that they were mainly indigenous painters led by friars who made them. These were also manifested in illustrated manuscripts such as the <a href="/wiki/Matr%C3%ADcula_de_Tributos" title="Matrícula de Tributos">Matrícula de Tributos</a>.
</p><p>For a time it was believed that the first European painter living in <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a> was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rodrigo_de_Cifuentes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rodrigo de Cifuentes (page does not exist)">Rodrigo de Cifuentes</a>, an apocryphal artist who even came to be attributed works such as <i>The Baptism of the <a href="/wiki/Cacique" title="Cacique">Caciques</a> de Tlaxcala</i>, painting of the main altarpiece of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Convento_de_San_Francisco,_Tlaxcala&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Convento de San Francisco, Tlaxcala (page does not exist)">Convent of San Francisco</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tlaxcala" title="Tlaxcala">Tlaxcala</a>. Among the native painters was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marcos_Aquino&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marcos Aquino (page does not exist)">Marcos Aquino</a>. The religiosity of the Novohispanos ("New-Spanish") made that the painting was important for the evangelization of the society, the friars realized the graphic skills of the natives, who enriched the baroque and <a href="/wiki/Mannerist" class="mw-redirect" title="Mannerist">mannerist</a> style. The arrival of several European painters and some students from New Spain, such as <a href="/wiki/Juan_Correa" title="Juan Correa">Juan Correa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crist%C3%B3bal_de_Villalpando" title="Cristóbal de Villalpando">Cristóbal de Villalpando</a> or <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Cabrera_(painter)" title="Miguel Cabrera (painter)">Miguel Cabrera</a>, who made the walls and altarpieces the main source of the ideological and political expression of artists.
</p><p>The painting of the 19th century had a very marked romantic influence; landscapes and portraits were the greatest expressions of this era. <a href="/wiki/Hermenegildo_Bustos" title="Hermenegildo Bustos">Hermenegildo Bustos</a> is one of the most appreciated painters of the <a href="/wiki/Historiography" title="Historiography">historiography</a> of Mexican art. Other painters in these years were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Santiago_Rebull&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Santiago Rebull (page does not exist)">Santiago Rebull</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Salom%C3%A9_Pina" title="José Salomé Pina">José Salomé Pina</a>, <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Parra" title="Félix Parra">Félix Parra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Landesio" title="Eugenio Landesio">Eugenio Landesio</a> and his famous disciple, the landscaper <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Velasco_G%C3%B3mez" title="José María Velasco Gómez">José María Velasco Gómez</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Julio_Ruelas" title="Julio Ruelas">Julio Ruelas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mexican_art" title="Mexican art">Mexican painting</a> of the 20th century has achieved world renown with figures such as <a href="/wiki/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros" title="David Alfaro Siqueiros">David Alfaro Siqueiros</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Clemente_Orozco" title="José Clemente Orozco">José Clemente Orozco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joaqu%C3%ADn_Clausell" title="Joaquín Clausell">Joaquín Clausell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frida_Kahlo" title="Frida Kahlo">Frida Kahlo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Diego_Rivera" title="Diego Rivera">Diego Rivera</a>, a generation of idealists who marked the image of modern Mexico in the face of strong social and economic criticism. The Oaxacan School quickly gained fame and prestige, diffusion of ancestral and modern culture. Freedom of design is observed in relation to the color and texture of the canvases and murals as a period of transition between the 20th century and the 21st century.
</p><p>Some of the most outstanding painters in the 21st century (current painters): <a href="/w/index.php?title=Patricia_Calvo_Guzm%C3%A1n&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Patricia Calvo Guzmán (page does not exist)">Patricia Calvo Guzmán</a> studied painting in Beijing. Her work, of marked oriental influence, recalls the cut paper figures of Mexico and China, mixing them with a rich chromatic range; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eliseo_Garza_Aguilar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eliseo Garza Aguilar (page does not exist)">Eliseo Garza Aguilar</a>, painter and <a href="/wiki/Performer" class="mw-redirect" title="Performer">performer</a> considered among the leading exponents of the provocative and reflective art of the Third Millennium. In search of a critical response from the spectators, he combines his pictorial work in the <a href="/wiki/Performance" title="Performance">performances</a> with theatrical histrionics. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pilar_Goutas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pilar Goutas (page does not exist)">Pilar Goutas</a> is a painter who uses oil on amate support, with strong influence from <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Pollock" title="Jackson Pollock">Jackson Pollock</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_calligraphy" title="Chinese calligraphy">Chinese calligraphy</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rafael_Torres_Correa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rafael Torres Correa (page does not exist)">Rafael Torres Correa</a> settled in Mexico in 2001 and joined the contemporary art workshop "La Polilla" in <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>, producing various plastic and scenographic projects.
</p><p>Throughout history several prominent painters of different nationalities have expressed in their works the face of Mexico. Among the most outstanding we can mention are <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Thomas_Egerton" title="Daniel Thomas Egerton">Daniel Thomas Egerton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carl_Nebel" title="Carl Nebel">Carl Nebel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Moran" title="Thomas Moran">Thomas Moran</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89douard_Manet" title="Édouard Manet">Édouard Manet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leonora_Carrington" title="Leonora Carrington">Leonora Carrington</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sculpture">Sculpture</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sculpture_in_Mexico" title="Sculpture in Mexico">Sculpture in Mexico</a></div>
<p>Sculpture in Mexico is strongly manifested in Mesoamerican pre-Columbian cultures (<a href="/wiki/Maya_civilization" title="Maya civilization">Mayans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olmec" class="mw-redirect" title="Olmec">Olmecs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toltec" title="Toltec">Toltecs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mixtec" title="Mixtec">Mixtecs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aztec" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec">Aztecs</a>), etc., being this generally religious.
</p><p>From the Spanish conquest, civil and religious sculpture is worked by indigenous artists, with guidance from teachers of the peninsula, so some pre-Hispanic features are shown. Since the 17th century, white and <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">mestizo</a> sculptors have created works with a marked influence of European classicism.
</p><p>Romanticism tended to break the strict norms and models of classicism, as it pursued ideas influenced by realism and nationalism. The religious sculpture was reduced to a sporadic imagery, while the secular sculpture continued in portraits and monumental art of a civic nature. Between 1820 and 1880 the predominant themes were, successively: religious images, biblical scenes, allegories to the symbols of the insurgency movement and scenes and characters of pre-Cortesian history, and portraits of the old aristocracy, of the nascent bourgeoisie and commanders of the pre-revolution. The transcendent was to introduce civil reasons, the first national types and glimpses of a current of self-expression.
</p><p>During the 20th century, great exponents of Mexican sculpture are <a href="/wiki/Juan_Soriano" title="Juan Soriano">Juan Soriano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Luis_Cuevas" title="José Luis Cuevas">José Luis Cuevas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sebasti%C3%A1n_(sculptor)" title="Sebastián (sculptor)">Enrique Carbajal</a> (<i>Sebastián</i>), English <a href="/wiki/Leonora_Carrington" title="Leonora Carrington">Leonora Carrington</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Mexico" title="Architecture of Mexico">Architecture of Mexico</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:SSA41434.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/SSA41434.JPG/200px-SSA41434.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/SSA41434.JPG/300px-SSA41434.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/SSA41434.JPG/400px-SSA41434.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Teotihuac%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Teotihuacán">Teotihuacán</a>, <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">State of Mexico</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Palacio_de_Cort%C3%A9s_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Palacio_de_Cort%C3%A9s_-_panoramio.jpg/200px-Palacio_de_Cort%C3%A9s_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="134" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Palacio_de_Cort%C3%A9s_-_panoramio.jpg/300px-Palacio_de_Cort%C3%A9s_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Palacio_de_Cort%C3%A9s_-_panoramio.jpg/400px-Palacio_de_Cort%C3%A9s_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1162" data-file-height="778" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Cort%C3%A9s,_Cuernavaca" title="Palace of Cortés, Cuernavaca">Palace of Cortés</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuernavaca" title="Cuernavaca">Cuernavaca</a>, is the oldest conserved colonial-era civil building in the continental Americas.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Catedral_zacatecas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Catedral_zacatecas.jpg/200px-Catedral_zacatecas.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="146" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Catedral_zacatecas.jpg/300px-Catedral_zacatecas.jpg 1.5x,
