//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Catedral_zacatecas.jpg/400px-Catedral_zacatecas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1054" data-file-height="770" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Cathedral_Basilica_of_Zacatecas" title="Cathedral Basilica of Zacatecas">Cathedral Basilica of Zacatecas</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The presence of the human being in the Mexican territory has left important archaeological findings of great importance for the explanation of the habitat of primitive man and contemporary man. The Mesoamerican civilizations managed to have great stylistic development and proportion on the human and urban scale, the form was evolving from simplicity to aesthetic complexity; in the north of the country the adobe and stone architecture is manifested, the multifamily housing as we can see in <a href="/wiki/Casas_Grandes" title="Casas Grandes">Casas Grandes</a>; and the troglodyte dwelling in caves of the Sierra Madre Occidental.
</p><p>Urbanism had a great development in pre-Hispanic cultures, where we can see the magnitude of the cities of <a href="/wiki/Teotihuac%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Teotihuacán">Teotihuacán</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tula_(Mesoamerican_site)" title="Tula (Mesoamerican site)">Tollan-Xicocotitlan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">México-Tenochtitlan</a>, within the environmentalist urbanism highlight the Mayan cities to be incorporated into the monumentality of its buildings with the thickness of the jungle and complex networks of roads called <i>sakbés</i>.
</p><p>With the arrival of the Spaniards, architectural theories of the Greco-Roman order with Arab influences were introduced. Due to the process of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evangelization_in_New_Spain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evangelization in New Spain (page does not exist)">evangelization</a>, when the first monastic temples and monasteries were built, their own models were projected, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mendicant_monasteries_in_Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mendicant monasteries in Mexico (page does not exist)">mendicant monasteries</a>, unique in their type in architecture. The interaction between Spaniards and natives gave rise to artistic styles such as the so-called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tequitqui&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tequitqui (page does not exist)">tequitqui</a></i> (from <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a>: worker). Years later the baroque and mannerism were imposed in large cathedrals and civil buildings, while rural areas are built <a href="/wiki/Hacienda" title="Hacienda">haciendas</a> or stately farms with Mozarabic tendencies.
</p><p>In the 19th century the neoclassical movement arose as a response to the objectives of the republican nation, one of its examples are the <a href="/wiki/Hospicio_Caba%C3%B1as" title="Hospicio Cabañas">Hospicio Cabañas</a> where the strict plastic of the classical orders are represented in their architectural elements, new religious buildings also arise, civilian and military that demonstrate the presence of neoclassicism. Romanticists from a past seen through archeology show images of medieval Europe, Islamic and pre-Hispanic Mexico in the form of architectural elements in the construction of international exhibition pavilions looking for an identity typical of the national culture. The <i>art nouveau</i>, and the <i>art deco</i> were styles introduced into the design of the <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palacio de Bellas Artes</a> to mark the identity of the Mexican nation with Greek-Roman and pre-Hispanic symbols.
</p><p>Modern architecture in Mexico has an important development in the plasticity of form and space, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Villagr%C3%A1n_Garc%C3%ADa" title="José Villagrán García">José Villagrán García</a> develops a theory of form that sets the pattern of teaching in many schools of architecture in the country within functionalism. The emergence of the new <a href="/wiki/Mexican_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican architecture">Mexican architecture</a> was born as a formal order of the policies of a nationalist state that sought modernity and the differentiation of other nations. <a href="/wiki/Juan_O%27Gorman" title="Juan O&#39;Gorman">Juan O'Gorman</a> was one of the first environmental architects in Mexico, developing the "organic" theory, trying to integrate the building with the landscape within the same approaches of <a href="/wiki/Frank_Lloyd_Wright" title="Frank Lloyd Wright">Frank Lloyd Wright</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup> In the search for a new architecture that does not resemble the styles of the past, it achieves a joint manifestation with the mural painting and the <a href="/wiki/Landscaping" title="Landscaping">landscaping</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jalisco_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jalisco School (page does not exist)">Jalisco School</a> was a proposal of those socio-political movements that the country demanded. <a href="/wiki/Luis_Barrag%C3%A1n" title="Luis Barragán">Luis Barragán</a> managed to combine the shape of the space with forms of rural vernacular architecture of Mexico and Mediterranean countries (Spain-Morocco), integrating an impressive color that handles light and shade in different tones and opens a look at the international <a href="/wiki/Minimalism" title="Minimalism">minimalism</a>.
</p><p>Mexican architecture is a cultural phenomenon born of the ideology of nationalist governments of the 20th century, which was shaping the identity image by its colorful and variegated ornamental elements inherited from ancestral cultures, classical and monumental forms and, subsequently, the incorporation of modernism and cutting-edge international trends.
</p>
<h3><span id="The_Mexican_.28Lo_mexicano.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Mexican_(Lo_mexicano)">The Mexican (<i>Lo mexicano</i>)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Danzantes_en_la_Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas,_Tlatelolco.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Danzantes_en_la_Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas%2C_Tlatelolco.jpg/220px-Danzantes_en_la_Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas%2C_Tlatelolco.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Danzantes_en_la_Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas%2C_Tlatelolco.jpg/330px-Danzantes_en_la_Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas%2C_Tlatelolco.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Danzantes_en_la_Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas%2C_Tlatelolco.jpg/440px-Danzantes_en_la_Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas%2C_Tlatelolco.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Danzantes_en_la_Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas,_Tlatelolco.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas" title="Plaza de las Tres Culturas">Plaza de las Tres Culturas</a> in Mexico City, which combines architectural styles representing three major cultural periods: pre-Columbian, colonial, and independent Mexico.</div></div></div>
<p>In ethnic and cultural terms, <i>Lo mexicano</i> corresponds only to everything that is referred to the <a href="/wiki/Aztec" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec">Aztec</a> culture; therefore, ethnically Mexicans are those who are also known as <i><a href="/wiki/Nahua_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="Nahua peoples">Nahuas</a></i> and whose language is <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">&#91;407&#93;</a></sup> There is a strong discussion to define The Mexican (<i>Lo mexicano</i>); there are two completely divided aspects: ethnic and cultural, which focuses exclusively on the <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">Mesoamerican</a> people called <i>Mexica people</i>, and the legal-administrative aspect of the territory called <i>Mexico</i>. In legal terms and in accordance with the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">Constitution</a>, a <i>Mexican</i> is a citizen born within the territory of the United Mexican States or whoever has decided adopt the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_citizenship" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican citizenship">Mexican citizenship</a>.
</p><p><i>The Mexican</i> could be what characterizes the being of Mexico and its people; however, it is an ethnic concept that only defines the mestizo identity that had been related for a long time and that is limited with respect to the ethnic diversity of the country. It is an intellectual construction product of the approaches of specialists to the <a href="/wiki/Cultural" class="mw-redirect" title="Cultural">cultural</a> reality of the country. In trying to capture in a single figure the <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multicultural</a> reality of Mexico, the result of the intellectual analysis has produced a series of <a href="/wiki/Stereotype" title="Stereotype">stereotypes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Truism" title="Truism">truisms</a> about what it is to be a Mexican. This discourse about The Mexican has been used in the political field to legitimize power, and at the same time it is imposed on the population of the country as a fact beyond all doubt.
</p><p>The intellectual construction of the <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">mestizo</a> is in dialogue with the triumph of revolutionary nationalism, which was born after the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">Mexican Revolution</a>. In the reflection on the subject (the character of the Mexican, the mexicanity, the definition of a Mexican) have participated, among others: <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Vasconcelos_Calder%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="José Vasconcelos Calderón">José Vasconcelos</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Ramos" title="Samuel Ramos">Samuel Ramos</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Uranga" title="Emilio Uranga">Emilio Uranga</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">&#91;410&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Gaos" title="José Gaos">José Gaos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leopoldo_Zea_Aguilar" title="Leopoldo Zea Aguilar">Leopoldo Zea</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jorge_Portilla&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jorge Portilla (page does not exist)">Jorge Portilla</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Santiago_Ram%C3%ADrez_Sandoval&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Santiago Ramírez Sandoval (page does not exist)">Santiago Ramírez</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Salvador_P%C3%A9rez_Nevares&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Salvador Pérez Nevares (page does not exist)">Salvador Pérez Nevares</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roger_Bartra" title="Roger Bartra">Roger Bartra</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jos%C3%A9_del_Val&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="José del Val (page does not exist)">José del Val</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Warman" title="Arturo Warman">Arturo Warman</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aniceto_Aramoni&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aniceto Aramoni (page does not exist)">Aniceto Aramoni</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rogelio_D%C3%ADaz_Guerrero&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rogelio Díaz Guerrero (page does not exist)">Rogelio Díaz Guerrero</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ezequiel_Adeodato_Ch%C3%A1vez_Lavista&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ezequiel Adeodato Chávez Lavista (page does not exist)">Ezequiel Adeodato Chávez Lavista</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mauro_Rodr%C3%ADguez_Estrada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mauro Rodríguez Estrada (page does not exist)">Mauro Rodríguez Estrada</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carlos_Chilpa_Navarrete&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carlos Chilpa Navarrete (page does not exist)">Carlos Chilpa Navarrete</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup> In this specific topic, occupies a privileged place <a href="/wiki/Octavio_Paz" title="Octavio Paz">Octavio Paz</a>, author of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Labyrinth_of_Solitude" title="The Labyrinth of Solitude">The Labyrinth of Solitude</a></i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_literature" title="Mexican literature">Mexican literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_literature" title="Mesoamerican literature">Mesoamerican literature</a></div>
<p>Mexican literature has its antecedents in the literature of the indigenous settlements of Mesoamerica. Poetry had a rich cultural tradition in prehispanic Mexico, being divided into two broad categories—secular and religious. Aztec poetry was sung, chanted, or spoken, often to the accompanyment of a drum or a harp. While Tenochtitlan was the political capital, <a href="/wiki/Texcoco_(altepetl)" title="Texcoco (altepetl)">Texcoco</a> was the cultural center; the Texcocan language was considered the most melodious and refined. The best well-known prehispanic poet is <a href="/wiki/Nezahualcoyotl_(tlatoani)" title="Nezahualcoyotl (tlatoani)">Nezahualcoyotl</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">&#91;412&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Literature during the 16th century consisted largely of histories of Spanish conquests, and most of the writers at this time were from Spain. <a href="/wiki/Bernal_D%C3%ADaz_del_Castillo" title="Bernal Díaz del Castillo">Bernal Díaz del Castillo's</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Historia_verdadera_de_la_conquista_de_la_Nueva_Espa%C3%B1a" title="Historia verdadera de la conquista de la Nueva España">Historia verdadera de la conquista de la Nueva España</a></i> (True history of the Conquest of New Spain) is still widely read today. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Francisco_de_Terrazas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Francisco de Terrazas (page does not exist)">Francisco de Terrazas</a>, who wrote sonnets, was the first Mexican-born poet to attain renown.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-414">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baroque_Literature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baroque Literature (page does not exist)">Baroque Literature</a> flourished in the 17th century; the most notable writers of this period were <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ruiz_de_Alarc%C3%B3n" title="Juan Ruiz de Alarcón">Juan Ruiz de Alarcón</a> and <a href="/wiki/Juana_In%C3%A9s_de_la_Cruz" title="Juana Inés de la Cruz">Juana Inés de la Cruz</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_414-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-414">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup> The 18th and early 19th centuries gave us <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Joaqu%C3%ADn_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Lizardi" title="José Joaquín Fernández de Lizardi">José Joaquín Fernández de Lizardi</a>, whose <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mangy_Parrot" title="The Mangy Parrot">The Mangy Parrot</a></i> ("El Periquillo Sarniento"), is said to be the first Latin American novel. Several <a href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuit</a> humanists wrote at this time, and they were among the first to call for independence from Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_414-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-414">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Other writers include <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Reyes" title="Alfonso Reyes">Alfonso Reyes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Joaqu%C3%ADn_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Lizardi" title="José Joaquín Fernández de Lizardi">José Joaquín Fernández de Lizardi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_Manuel_Altamirano" title="Ignacio Manuel Altamirano">Ignacio Manuel Altamirano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Fuentes" title="Carlos Fuentes">Carlos Fuentes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Octavio_Paz" title="Octavio Paz">Octavio Paz</a> (Nobel Laureate), <a href="/wiki/Renato_Leduc" title="Renato Leduc">Renato Leduc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Monsiv%C3%A1is" title="Carlos Monsiváis">Carlos Monsiváis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elena_Poniatowska" title="Elena Poniatowska">Elena Poniatowska</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Azuela" title="Mariano Azuela">Mariano Azuela</a> ("Los de abajo") and <a href="/wiki/Juan_Rulfo" title="Juan Rulfo">Juan Rulfo</a> ("Pedro Páramo"). <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Traven" class="mw-redirect" title="Bruno Traven">Bruno Traven</a> wrote<i>Canasta de cuentos mexicano</i> (Mexican tales basket) and <i>El tesoro de la Sierra Madre</i> (Treasure of the Sierra Madre). <a href="/wiki/Luis_Spota" title="Luis Spota">Luis Spota</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaime_Sabines" title="Jaime Sabines">Jaime Sabines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Luis_Guzm%C3%A1n" title="Martín Luis Guzmán">Martín Luis Guzmán</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Valeria_Luiselli" title="Valeria Luiselli">Valeria Luiselli</a> (<i>Faces in the Crowd</i>) are also noteworthy.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">&#91;414&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_art" title="Mexican art">Mexican art</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Artes_Bellas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Artes_Bellas.jpg/220px-Artes_Bellas.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Artes_Bellas.jpg/330px-Artes_Bellas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Artes_Bellas.jpg/440px-Artes_Bellas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Artes_Bellas.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palacio de Bellas Artes</a> is the preeminent fine arts hall in Mexico.</div></div></div>
<p>Post-revolutionary art in Mexico had its expression in the works of renowned artists such as <a href="/wiki/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros" title="David Alfaro Siqueiros">David Alfaro Siqueiros</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federico_Cant%C3%BA_Garza" title="Federico Cantú Garza">Federico Cantú Garza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frida_Kahlo" title="Frida Kahlo">Frida Kahlo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juan_O%27Gorman" title="Juan O&#39;Gorman">Juan O'Gorman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Clemente_Orozco" title="José Clemente Orozco">José Clemente Orozco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diego_Rivera" title="Diego Rivera">Diego Rivera</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rufino_Tamayo" title="Rufino Tamayo">Rufino Tamayo</a>. Diego Rivera, the most well-known figure of Mexican muralism, painted the <a href="/wiki/Man_at_the_Crossroads" title="Man at the Crossroads">Man at the Crossroads</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center" title="Rockefeller Center">Rockefeller Center</a> in New York City, a huge mural that was destroyed the next year because of the inclusion of a portrait of Russian communist leader <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Lenin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">&#91;415&#93;</a></sup> Some of Rivera's murals are displayed at the Mexican <a href="/wiki/National_Palace_(Mexico)" title="National Palace (Mexico)">National Palace</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">Palace of Fine Arts</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_architecture" title="Mesoamerican architecture">Mesoamerican architecture</a> is mostly noted for its pyramids which are the largest such structures outside of Ancient Egypt. <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Colonial_architecture" title="Spanish Colonial architecture">Spanish Colonial architecture</a> is marked by the contrast between the simple, solid construction demanded by the new environment and the Baroque ornamentation exported from Spain. Mexico, as the center of New Spain has some of the most renowned buildings built in this style.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Mexico" title="Cinema of Mexico">Cinema of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg/170px-Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg/255px-Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f8/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="340" data-file-height="453" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Actress <a href="/wiki/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo" title="Dolores del Río">Dolores del Río</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> star in the 1920s and 1930s and prominent figure of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Mexican_cinema" title="Golden Age of Mexican cinema">Golden Age of Mexican cinema</a> in the 1940s and 1950s</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Mexico" title="Cinema of Mexico">Mexican films</a> from the <i><a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Mexican_cinema" title="Golden Age of Mexican cinema">Golden Age</a></i> in the 1940s and 1950s are the greatest examples of Latin American cinema, with a huge industry comparable to the Hollywood of those years. Mexican films were exported and exhibited in all of Latin America and Europe. <i><a href="/wiki/Maria_Candelaria" class="mw-redirect" title="Maria Candelaria">Maria Candelaria</a></i> (1943) by <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Fern%C3%A1ndez" title="Emilio Fernández">Emilio Fernández</a>, was one of the first films awarded a <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d&#39;Or">Palme d'Or</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> in 1946, the first time the event was held after World War II. The famous Spanish-born director <a href="/wiki/Luis_Bu%C3%B1uel" title="Luis Buñuel">Luis Buñuel</a> realized in Mexico between 1947 and 1965 some of his masterpieces like <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Olvidados" title="Los Olvidados">Los Olvidados</a></i> (1949) and <i><a href="/wiki/Viridiana" title="Viridiana">Viridiana</a></i> (1961). Famous actors and actresses from this period include <a href="/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_F%C3%A9lix" title="María Félix">María Félix</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Infante" title="Pedro Infante">Pedro Infante</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo" title="Dolores del Río">Dolores del Río</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Negrete" title="Jorge Negrete">Jorge Negrete</a> and the comedian <a href="/wiki/Cantinflas" title="Cantinflas">Cantinflas</a>.
</p><p>More recently, films such as <i><a href="/wiki/Like_Water_for_Chocolate_(film)" title="Like Water for Chocolate (film)">Como agua para chocolate</a></i> (1992), <i><a href="/wiki/Cronos_(film)" title="Cronos (film)">Cronos</a></i> (1993), <i><a href="/wiki/Y_tu_mam%C3%A1_tambi%C3%A9n" class="mw-redirect" title="Y tu mamá también">Y tu mamá también</a></i> (2001), and <i><a href="/wiki/Pan%27s_Labyrinth" title="Pan&#39;s Labyrinth">Pan's Labyrinth</a></i> (2006) have been successful in creating universal stories about contemporary subjects, and were internationally recognized, as in the prestigious Cannes Film Festival. Mexican directors <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Gonz%C3%A1lez_I%C3%B1%C3%A1rritu" title="Alejandro González Iñárritu">Alejandro González Iñárritu</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Amores_perros" title="Amores perros">Amores perros</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Babel_(film)" title="Babel (film)">Babel</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Birdman_(film)" title="Birdman (film)">Birdman</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Revenant_(2015_film)" title="The Revenant (2015 film)">The Revenant</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n" title="Alfonso Cuarón">Alfonso Cuarón</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Children_of_Men" title="Children of Men">Children of Men</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Gravity_(2013_film)" title="Gravity (2013 film)">Gravity</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_del_Toro" title="Guillermo del Toro">Guillermo del Toro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Carrera" title="Carlos Carrera">Carlos Carrera</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/El_crimen_del_Padre_Amaro" class="mw-redirect" title="El crimen del Padre Amaro">The Crime of Father Amaro</a></i>), screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Arriaga" title="Guillermo Arriaga">Guillermo Arriaga</a> and photographer <a href="/wiki/Emmanuel_Lubezki" title="Emmanuel Lubezki">Emmanuel Lubezki</a> are some of the most known present-day film makers. Numerous Mexican actors have achieved recognition as Hollywood stars.<sup id="cite_ref-CoerverPasztor2004_417-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CoerverPasztor2004-417">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_television" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexican television">Mexican television</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Mexico" title="List of newspapers in Mexico">List of newspapers in Mexico</a></div>
<p>There are three major television companies in Mexico that own the primary networks and broadcast covering all nation, <a href="/wiki/Televisa" title="Televisa">Televisa</a>, <a href="/wiki/TV_Azteca" title="TV Azteca">TV Azteca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Imagen_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Imagen Television">Imagen Television</a>. Televisa is also the largest producer of Spanish-language content in the world and also the world's largest Spanish-language media network.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">&#91;417&#93;</a></sup> Media company <a href="/wiki/Grupo_Imagen" title="Grupo Imagen">Grupo Imagen</a> is another national coverage television broadcaster in Mexico, that also owns the newspaper <a href="/wiki/Exc%C3%A9lsior" title="Excélsior">Excélsior</a>. <a href="/wiki/Grupo_Multimedios" title="Grupo Multimedios">Grupo Multimedios</a> is another media conglomerate with Spanish-language broadcasting in Mexico, Spain, and the United States. The <i><a href="/wiki/Telenovela" title="Telenovela">telenovelas</a></i> are very traditional in Mexico and are translated to many languages and seen all over the world with renowned names like <a href="/wiki/Ver%C3%B3nica_Castro" title="Verónica Castro">Verónica Castro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A9ndez" title="Lucía Méndez">Lucía Méndez</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thal%C3%ADa" title="Thalía">Thalía</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Mexico" title="Music of Mexico">Music of Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:WP10GDL10.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/WP10GDL10.JPG/220px-WP10GDL10.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/WP10GDL10.JPG/330px-WP10GDL10.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/WP10GDL10.JPG/440px-WP10GDL10.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3472" data-file-height="2604" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:WP10GDL10.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mariachi" title="Mariachi">Mariachi</a> group playing at the 10th anniversary celebration of Wikipedia in <a href="/wiki/Guadalajara" title="Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a>. Mariachi is a musical expression inscribed in the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_List" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage List">UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage List</a> in 2011.</div></div></div>
<p>Mexican society enjoys a vast array of music genres, showing the diversity of Mexican culture. Traditional music includes <a href="/wiki/Mariachi" title="Mariachi">mariachi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banda_music" title="Banda music">banda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norte%C3%B1o_(music)" title="Norteño (music)">norteño</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ranchera" title="Ranchera">ranchera</a> and <a href="/wiki/Corrido" title="Corrido">corridos</a>; on an everyday basis most Mexicans listen to contemporary music such as <a href="/wiki/Mexican_pop_music" title="Mexican pop music">pop</a>, rock, etc. in both English and Spanish. Mexico has the largest media industry in Latin America, producing Mexican artists who are famous in Central and South America and parts of Europe, especially Spain.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_cuisine" title="Mexican cuisine">Mexican cuisine</a></div><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Mexican_wine" title="Mexican wine">Mexican wine</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Drinking_chocolate,_Portland.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Drinking_chocolate%2C_Portland.jpg/200px-Drinking_chocolate%2C_Portland.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Drinking_chocolate%2C_Portland.jpg/300px-Drinking_chocolate%2C_Portland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Drinking_chocolate%2C_Portland.jpg/400px-Drinking_chocolate%2C_Portland.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3776" data-file-height="2832" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The first <a href="/wiki/Chocolate" title="Chocolate">chocolate</a> version (liquid) was made by indigenous people in present-day Mexico, and was exported from Mexico to Europe after the Spanish conquest.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">&#91;418&#93;</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG/200px-Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG/300px-Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG/400px-Comida_en_la_Feria_del_Mole_2014_12.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4320" data-file-height="3240" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/Mole_sauce" title="Mole sauce">Mole sauce</a></i>, which has dozens of varieties across the Republic, is seen as a symbol of <i>Mexicanidad</i><sup id="cite_ref-Mole_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mole-420">&#91;419&#93;</a></sup> and is considered Mexico's national dish.<sup id="cite_ref-Mole_420-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mole-420">&#91;419&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In 2005, Mexico presented the candidature of its gastronomy for <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> of UNESCO, being the first occasion in which a country had presented its gastronomic tradition for this purpose.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">&#91;420&#93;</a></sup> However, in a first instance the result was negative, because the committee did not place the proper emphasis on the importance of <a href="/wiki/Corn" class="mw-redirect" title="Corn">corn</a> in Mexican cuisine.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">&#91;421&#93;</a></sup> Finally, on November 16, 2010 Mexican gastronomy was recognized as <a href="/wiki/Intangible_cultural_heritage" title="Intangible cultural heritage">Intangible cultural heritage</a> by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GastronomiaPatrimonio_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GastronomiaPatrimonio-423">&#91;422&#93;</a></sup> In addition, <a href="/wiki/Daniela_Soto-Innes" title="Daniela Soto-Innes">Daniela Soto-Innes</a> was named the best female chef in the world by <i>The World's Best 50 Restaurants</i> in April 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">&#91;423&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The origin of the current Mexican cuisine is established during the Spanish colonization, being a mixture of the foods of <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> with native indigenous ingredients.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">&#91;424&#93;</a></sup> Of foods originated in Mexico is the <a href="/wiki/Corn" class="mw-redirect" title="Corn">corn</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Capsicum" title="Capsicum">pepper vegetables</a> (together with Central and South America), <a href="/wiki/Calabaza" title="Calabaza">calabazas</a> (together with the Americas), <a href="/wiki/Avocado" title="Avocado">avocados</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sweet_potato" title="Sweet potato">sweet potato</a> (together with Central and South America), the <a href="/wiki/Turkey_as_food" title="Turkey as food">turkey</a> (together with the Americas) and other fruits and spices. Other Indigenous products are many <a href="/wiki/Beans" class="mw-redirect" title="Beans">beans</a>. Similarly, some cooking techniques used today are inherited from pre-Hispanic peoples, such as the <a href="/wiki/Nixtamalization" title="Nixtamalization">nixtamalization</a> of corn, the cooking of food in ovens at ground level, grinding in <a href="/wiki/Molcajete" title="Molcajete">molcajete</a> and <a href="/wiki/Metate" title="Metate">metate</a>. With the Spaniards came the pork, beef and chicken meats; <a href="/wiki/Piper_(plant)" title="Piper (plant)">peppercorn</a>, sugar, milk and all its derivatives, wheat and rice, citrus fruits and another constellation of ingredients that are part of the daily diet of Mexicans.
</p><p>From this meeting of millennia old two culinary traditions, were born <a href="/wiki/Pozole" title="Pozole">pozole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mole_sauce" title="Mole sauce">mole sauce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbacoa" title="Barbacoa">barbacoa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tamale" title="Tamale">tamale</a> is in its current forms, the <a href="/wiki/Chocolate" title="Chocolate">chocolate</a>, a large range of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_breads" title="Mexican breads">breads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taco" title="Taco">tacos</a>, and the broad repertoire of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_street_food" title="Mexican street food">Mexican street foods</a>. Beverages such as <a href="/wiki/Atole" title="Atole">atole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Champurrado" title="Champurrado">champurrado</a>, milk chocolate and <a href="/wiki/Aguas_frescas" title="Aguas frescas">aguas frescas</a> were born; desserts such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Acitr%C3%B3n&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Acitrón (page does not exist)">acitrón</a> and the full range of crystallized sweets, <a href="/wiki/Rompope" title="Rompope">rompope</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cajeta" title="Cajeta">cajeta</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jericaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jericaya (page does not exist)">jericaya</a> and the wide repertoire of delights created in the convents of nuns in all parts of the country.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Mexico" title="Sport in Mexico">Sport in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Azteca,_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Estadio_Azteca%2C_2015.jpg/220px-Estadio_Azteca%2C_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="126" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Estadio_Azteca%2C_2015.jpg/330px-Estadio_Azteca%2C_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Estadio_Azteca%2C_2015.jpg/440px-Estadio_Azteca%2C_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="618" data-file-height="355" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Azteca,_2015.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Estadio_Azteca" title="Estadio Azteca">Estadio Azteca</a>, regarded as one of the iconic football stadiums in the world, hosted the 1970 and 1986 World Cup finals</div></div></div>
<p>Mexico's most popular sport is association football. It is commonly believed that football was introduced in Mexico by <a href="/wiki/Cornish_people" title="Cornish people">Cornish</a> miners at the end of the 19th century. By 1902 a five-team league had emerged with a strong British influence.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">&#91;425&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">&#91;426&#93;</a></sup> Mexico's top clubs are <a href="/wiki/Club_Am%C3%A9rica" title="Club América">América</a> with 12 championships, <a href="/wiki/Club_Deportivo_Guadalajara" class="mw-redirect" title="Club Deportivo Guadalajara">Guadalajara</a> with 11, and <a href="/wiki/Deportivo_Toluca_F.C." title="Deportivo Toluca F.C.">Toluca</a> with 10.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">&#91;427&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Carbajal" title="Antonio Carbajal">Antonio Carbajal</a> was the first player to appear in five World Cups,<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">&#91;428&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hugo_S%C3%A1nchez" title="Hugo Sánchez">Hugo Sánchez</a> was named best <a href="/wiki/CONCACAF" title="CONCACAF">CONCACAF</a> player of the 20th century by IFFHS.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">&#91;429&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rafael_M%C3%A1rquez" title="Rafael Márquez">Rafael Márquez</a> is the only Mexican to have won the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League" title="UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_431-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-431">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Estadio_de_beisbol_en_Monterrey.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Estadio_de_beisbol_en_Monterrey.jpg/220px-Estadio_de_beisbol_en_Monterrey.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Estadio_de_beisbol_en_Monterrey.jpg/330px-Estadio_de_beisbol_en_Monterrey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Estadio_de_beisbol_en_Monterrey.jpg/440px-Estadio_de_beisbol_en_Monterrey.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1282" data-file-height="814" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Estadio_de_beisbol_en_Monterrey.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Game at the <a href="/wiki/Estadio_de_B%C3%A9isbol_Monterrey" title="Estadio de Béisbol Monterrey">Estadio de Béisbol Monterrey</a>. Baseball is most popular in the North (particularly Northwest) and Southeast of Mexico.</div></div></div>
<p>The Mexican professional baseball league is named the <a href="/wiki/Liga_Mexicana_de_Beisbol" class="mw-redirect" title="Liga Mexicana de Beisbol">Liga Mexicana de Beisbol</a>. While usually not as strong as the United States, the Caribbean countries and Japan, <a href="/wiki/Mexico_national_baseball_team" title="Mexico national baseball team">Mexico</a> has nonetheless achieved several international baseball titles.<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">&#91;431&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">&#91;432&#93;</a></sup> Mexican teams have won the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Series" title="Caribbean Series">Caribbean Series</a> nine times. Mexico has had several players signed by Major League teams, the most famous of them being Dodgers pitcher <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Valenzuela" title="Fernando Valenzuela">Fernando Valenzuela</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_431-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-431">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mexico City hosted the <a href="/wiki/1968_Summer_Olympics" title="1968 Summer Olympics">XIX Olympic Games</a> in 1968, making it the first Latin American city to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">&#91;433&#93;</a></sup> The country has also hosted the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> twice, in <a href="/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1970 FIFA World Cup">1970</a> and <a href="/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1986 FIFA World Cup">1986</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">&#91;434&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, <a href="/wiki/Mexico%27s_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Mexico&#39;s basketball team">Mexico's basketball team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2013_FIBA_Americas_Championship" title="2013 FIBA Americas Championship">Americas Basketball Championship</a> and qualified for the <a href="/wiki/2014_Basketball_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Basketball World Cup">2014 Basketball World Cup</a> where it reached the playoffs. Because of these achievements the country earned the hosting rights for the <a href="/wiki/2015_FIBA_Americas_Championship" title="2015 FIBA Americas Championship">2015 FIBA Americas Championship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">&#91;435&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Bullfighting" title="Bullfighting">Bullfighting</a> (Spanish: corrida de toros) came to Mexico 500 years ago with the arrival of the Spanish. Despite efforts by animal rights activists to outlaw it, bullfighting remains a popular sport in the country, and almost all large cities have bullrings. <a href="/wiki/Plaza_M%C3%A9xico" class="mw-redirect" title="Plaza México">Plaza México</a> in Mexico City, which seats 45,000 people, is the largest bullring in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">&#91;436&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:433px;max-width:433px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg/200px-Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg/300px-Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg/400px-Pelota_mixteca_de_forro_ball_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:232901774_10376f0786.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/232901774_10376f0786.jpg/225px-232901774_10376f0786.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/232901774_10376f0786.jpg/338px-232901774_10376f0786.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/232901774_10376f0786.jpg/450px-232901774_10376f0786.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="333" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:left;background-color:transparent"><a href="/wiki/Mesoamerican_ballgame" title="Mesoamerican ballgame">Mesoamerican ballgame</a> and <a href="/wiki/Charrer%C3%ADa" class="mw-redirect" title="Charrería">Charrería</a> are sports that were originated in Prehispanic and Colonial Mexico respectively, this last is considered a national sport.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">&#91;437&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<p>Mexico is an international power in <a href="/wiki/Professional_boxing" title="Professional boxing">professional boxing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_431-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-431">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup> Thirteen <a href="/wiki/Mexico_at_the_Olympics" title="Mexico at the Olympics">Olympic boxing medals</a> have been won by Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">&#91;438&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Professional wrestling (or <a href="/wiki/Lucha_libre" title="Lucha libre">Lucha libre</a> in Spanish) is a major crowd draw with national promotions such as <a href="/wiki/Lucha_Libre_AAA_World_Wide" class="mw-redirect" title="Lucha Libre AAA World Wide">AAA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Consejo_Mundial_de_Lucha_Libre" title="Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre">CMLL</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_431-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-431">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coat_of_arms">Coat of arms</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Mexico" title="Coat of arms of Mexico">Coat of arms of Mexico</a></div>
<p>The current coat of arms of Mexico (<a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i lang="es">Escudo Nacional de México</i>, literally "national shield of Mexico") has been an important symbol of politics and culture of Mexico for centuries. It depicts a Mexican <a href="/wiki/Golden_eagle" title="Golden eagle">golden eagle</a> perched on a <a href="/wiki/Opuntia" title="Opuntia">prickly pear cactus</a> devouring a <a href="/wiki/Rattlesnake" title="Rattlesnake">rattlesnake</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Minahan_440-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Minahan-440">&#91;439&#93;</a></sup> The design is rooted in the legend that the <a href="/wiki/Aztec" class="mw-redirect" title="Aztec">Aztec</a> people would know where to build their <a href="/wiki/City" title="City">city</a> once they saw an eagle eating a snake on top of a lake.<sup id="cite_ref-Minahan_440-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Minahan-440">&#91;439&#93;</a></sup> To the people of <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">Tenochtitlan</a>, this symbol had strong religious connotations, and to the Europeans, it came to symbolize the triumph of good over evil (with the snake sometimes representative of the serpent in the <a href="/wiki/Garden_of_Eden" title="Garden of Eden">Garden of Eden</a>).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Mexico" title="Healthcare in Mexico">Healthcare in Mexico</a></div>
<p>Since the early 1990s, Mexico entered a transitional stage in the health of its population and some indicators such as mortality patterns are identical to those found in highly developed countries like Germany or Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">&#91;440&#93;</a></sup> Mexico's medical infrastructure is highly rated for the most part and is usually excellent in major cities,<sup id="cite_ref-Health_Care_in_Mexico_442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Health_Care_in_Mexico-442">&#91;441&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">&#91;442&#93;</a></sup> but rural communities still lack equipment for advanced medical procedures, forcing patients in those locations to travel to the closest urban areas to get specialized medical care.<sup id="cite_ref-brit-mex_175-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brit-mex-175">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup>  <a href="/wiki/Social_determinants_of_health_in_Mexico" title="Social determinants of health in Mexico">Social determinants of health</a> can be used to evaluate the state of health in Mexico.
</p><p>State-funded institutions such as <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Social_Security_Institute" title="Mexican Social Security Institute">Mexican Social Security Institute</a> (IMSS) and the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Social_Security_and_Services_for_State_Workers" title="Institute for Social Security and Services for State Workers">Institute for Social Security and Services for State Workers</a> (ISSSTE) play a major role in health and social security. Private health services are also very important and account for 13% of all medical units in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">&#91;443&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Medical training is done mostly at public universities with much specializations done in vocational or internship settings. Some public universities in Mexico, such as the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Guadalajara" title="University of Guadalajara">University of Guadalajara</a>, have signed agreements with the U.S. to receive and train American students in Medicine. Health care costs in private institutions and prescription drugs in Mexico are on average lower than that of its North American economic partners.<sup id="cite_ref-Health_Care_in_Mexico_442-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Health_Care_in_Mexico-442">&#91;441&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:433px;max-width:433px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Biblioteca_Central..jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Biblioteca_Central..jpg/200px-Biblioteca_Central..jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="149" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Biblioteca_Central..jpg/300px-Biblioteca_Central..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Biblioteca_Central..jpg/400px-Biblioteca_Central..jpg 2x" data-file-width="2557" data-file-height="1910" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:ITESM_Monterrey_Rectoria_CETEC.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/ITESM_Monterrey_Rectoria_CETEC.jpg/225px-ITESM_Monterrey_Rectoria_CETEC.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="158" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/ITESM_Monterrey_Rectoria_CETEC.jpg/338px-ITESM_Monterrey_Rectoria_CETEC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/ITESM_Monterrey_Rectoria_CETEC.jpg/450px-ITESM_Monterrey_Rectoria_CETEC.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1980" data-file-height="1386" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:left;background-color:transparent"><a href="/wiki/Central_Library_(UNAM)" title="Central Library (UNAM)">Central Library</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a> and the Rectorate (left) and the CETEC towers at the <a href="/wiki/Monterrey_Institute_of_Technology_and_Higher_Education" title="Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education">Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education</a></div></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Mexico" title="Education in Mexico">Education in Mexico</a></div>
<p>In 2004, the literacy rate was at 97%<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">&#91;444&#93;</a></sup> for youth under the age of 14 and 91% for people over 15,<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">&#91;445&#93;</a></sup> placing Mexico at the 24th place in the world rank according to <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">&#91;446&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">National Autonomous University of Mexico</a> ranks 103th in the <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a>, making it the best university in Mexico, after it comes the <a href="/wiki/Monterrey_Institute_of_Technology_and_Higher_Education" title="Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education">Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education</a> as the best private school in Mexico and 158th worldwide in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">&#91;447&#93;</a></sup> Private business schools also stand out in international rankings. <a href="/wiki/IPADE" class="mw-redirect" title="IPADE">IPADE</a> and <a href="/wiki/EGADE" class="mw-redirect" title="EGADE">EGADE</a>, the business schools of <a href="/wiki/Universidad_Panamericana" class="mw-redirect" title="Universidad Panamericana">Universidad Panamericana</a> and of <a href="/wiki/Monterrey_Institute_of_Technology_and_Higher_Education" title="Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education">Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education</a> respectively, were ranked in the top 10 in a survey conducted by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> among recruiters outside the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">&#91;448&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright" style="margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em;border:solid #aaa 1px">
<ul style="display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold">
<li style="display:table-row"><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center"><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/32px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="18" class="noviewer thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/48px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/64px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="980" data-file-height="560" /></span><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Mexico" title="Portal:Mexico">Mexico portal</a></span></li></ul></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-337"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-337">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Defined as persons who live in a household where an indigenous language is spoken by one of the adult family members, and or people who self-identified as indigenous ("Criteria del hogar: De esta manera, se establece, que los hogares indígenas son aquellos en donde el jefe y/o el cónyuge y/o padre o madre del jefe y/o suegro o suegra del jefe hablan una lengua indígena y también aquellos que declararon pertenecer a un grupo indígena."<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup>) AND persons who speak an indigenous language but who do not live in such a household ("Por lo antes mencionado, la Comisión Nacional Para el Desarrollo de los Pueblos Indígenas de México (CDI) considera población indígena (PI) a todas las personas que forman parte de un hogar indígena, donde el jefe(a) del hogar, su cónyuge y/o alguno de los ascendientes (madre o padre, madrastra o padrastro, abuelo(a), bisabuelo(a), tatarabuelo(a), suegro(a)) declaro ser hablante de lengua indígena. Además, también incluye a personas que declararon hablar alguna lengua indígena y que no forman parte de estos hogares."<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup>)</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>

<li id="cite_note-wb-upper-middle-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-wb-upper-middle_35-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110318125456/http://data.worldbank.org/about/country-classifications/country-and-lending-groups">"Country and Lending Groups"</a>. World Bank. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://data.worldbank.org/about/country-classifications/country-and-lending-groups#Upper_middle_income">the original</a> on March 18, 2011<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">March 5,</span> 2011</span>. <q>Uppermiddle Income defined as a per capita income between $3,976 – $12,275</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Country+and+Lending+Groups&amp;rft.pub=World+Bank&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdata.worldbank.org%2Fabout%2Fcountry-classifications%2Fcountry-and-lending-groups%23Upper_middle_income&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>

Retrieved <span class="nowrap">October 3,</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Nombre+del+Estado+de+M%C3%A9xico&amp;rft.pub=Government+of+the+State+of+Mexico&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.edomexico.gob.mx%2Fidentidad%2Fcivica%2Fhtm%2FNomMexico.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-232"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-232">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/federal-district-is-now-officially-mexico-city/">"Federal District is now officially Mexico City: The change brings more autonomy for the country's capital"</a>. <i>Mexico News Daily</i>. <li id="cite_note-233"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-233">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20061113175736/http://constitucion.gob.mx/index.php?idseccion=12">"Article 115"</a>. <i>Political Constitution of the United Mexican States</i>. <li id="cite_note-Spanishhistory-311"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Spanishhistory_311-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Spanishhistory_311-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20050417234656/http://www.todaytranslations.com/index.asp-Q-Page-E-Spanish-Language-History--13053095">"Spanish Language History"</a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">October 1,</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Spanish+Language+History&amp;rft.pub=Today+Translations&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.todaytranslations.com%2Findex.asp-Q-Page-E-Spanish-Language-History--13053095&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES-312"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-EL_MESTIZAJE_Y_LAS_CULTURAS_REGIONALES_312-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nacionmulticultural.unam.mx/Portal/Izquierdo/BANCO/Mxmulticultural/Elmestizajeylasculturas-elmestizaje.html">en el censo de 1930 el gobierno mexicano dejó de clasificar a la población del país en tres categorías raciales, blanco, mestizo e indígena, y adoptó una nueva clasificación étnica que distinguía a los hablantes de lenguas indígenas del resto de la población, es decir de los hablantes de español.</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130823015618/http://www.nacionmulticultural.unam.mx/Portal/Izquierdo/BANCO/Mxmulticultural/Elmestizajeylasculturas-elmestizaje.html">Archived</a> August 23, 2013, at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-UN2017-313"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-UN2017_313-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-UN2017_313-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-UN2017_313-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/migration/data/estimates2/data/UN_MigrantStockByOriginAndDestination_2017.xlsx">"Table 1: Total migrant stock at mid-year by origin and by major area, region, country or area of destination, 2017"</a>. United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-406"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-406">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Gutierrez, Vanessa (January 14, 2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://porfiriatocultura.blogspot.com/2011/01/literatura-la-cultura-en-el-porfiriato.html">"La Cultura en el Porfiriato"</a> &#91;Culture during the Porfiriato&#93;. <i>Porfiriato Cultura Blogspot</i> (in Spanish)<span class="reference-accessdate">. Inegi.gob.mx. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.inegi.gob.mx/est/contenidos/espanol/rutinas/ept.asp?t=medu15&amp;s=est&amp;c=3283">the original</a> on July 22, 2011<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">August 8,</span> 2011</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=INEGI+literacy+report+%E2%88%9214%2C+2005&amp;rft.pub=Inegi.gob.mx&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.inegi.gob.mx%2Fest%2Fcontenidos%2Fespanol%2Frutinas%2Fept.asp%3Ft%3Dmedu15%26s%3Dest%26c%3D3283&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-446"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-446">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110722225628/http://www.inegi.gob.mx/est/contenidos/espanol/rutinas/ept.asp?t=medu16&amp;s=est&amp;c=3284">"INEGI literacy report 15+, 2005"</a>.
